summary: 129 bronze coins (1 provincial) unknown denomination: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (AD 157-158)
A roll of eight corroded and partly worn AE coins (Trajan to Lucius Verus), found within the group of furnaces north of the west gate (inside the Roman fort), in front of the furnace 5
24 sestertii found with a ceramic vessel: Claudius I to Commodus (AD 180-183).
Four Roman bronze coins, excavated in shell sand north of the island Süderoog. The find depth was approximately 6 m.
A hoard of 48 denarii, ranging from Vespasian to Commodus, discovered in the fortress of Gaṙni in 1955.
13 bronze coins: 9 sestertii, 4 asses: Domitian - Marcus Aurelius Aurelius (AD 166).

A hoard of 427 silver coins (426 denarii and one Lycian drachm), of which the first lot was found in 1910 in a clay pot, while ploughing a field. It comprised 367 Roman denarii (Nero to Commodus), one Lycian drachm of Trajan and one contemporary cast forgery, also from Trajan. A further lot of 50 denarii (Mark Antony – Commodus) was found between April and December 1988 by members of the Chesterfield Metal Detector Club, in the vicinity of the first lot and can be regarded as a further portion of the same find. A further 8 denarii (Vitellius - Antoninus Pius) were found with the aid of metal detectors in November 2012.
disposition: Doncaster Museum (part); Newark Museum (part); British Museum (part)

summary: The hoard was found in a heap of stones without any obvious container and comprised 'some Roman gold coins. There is some debate over the number of coins found. According to Chassant, there were 5, but Leclerc de Pulligny suggests there was 'a multitude'. Pulligny also mentions a coin of Lucius Verus, but this is not recorded amongst the coins examined by Chassant. Found in a pile of stones with no obvious container.
270 coins. Only 10 sestertii are known: Trajan, - Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: Collection vicar Verstraete, Kortrijk, Belgium (c. 155 coins), in 1846; collection .C. Lefèvre,Brugge, Belgium (10 coins), in 1846

summary: The coins were found in a block, stuck together with corrosion products and comprised 151 sestertii, dupondii and asses from Trajan to Commodus. The coins were found during gravel extraction in the river and may represent a hoard washed out from a riverbank or a votive deposit.
Around 70-80 denarii, 53 were recovered: Republic - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
Around 2,000 denarii found on the surface after the river outflow. Only 8 denarii were known: Trajan 2, Hadrian 1, Faustina I 3, Commodus 2.

The deposit was found under a second century occupation layer in the central part of the Gallo-Roman spring sanctuary and comprised 4 sestertii from Trajan to Antoninus Pius and two asses of Antoninus Pius with a tpq of AD 153 to 154.

Seven denarii (Trajan - Antoninus Pius), set on a goblet ('Pokal') dating to around 1830, which were part of a hoard found in a pot at the beginning of the 19th c. on the grounds of the mansion of Welsede.
45 denarii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 190-191); silver weight: 106.55 g. (41 coins)
disposition: Swedish History Museum, Stockholm (inv.no. 6293); Gotlands Fornsal, Visby, Finland A 1922 (inv.nos. A 2090, A 2091)

summary: Unknown originally number of aurei. Forty-five coins from Nero to Trajan were recovered. Seventeen coins were studied in detail. Nine coins were acquired in 1937 by the mayor of Villeurbanne.
Two denarii found together: Hadrian, Marcus Aurelius.
The hoard comprised '20 coins of which the most recent was an issue of Marcus Aurelius' The hoard was discovered by peat cutters.
(14) 10 coins of unknown denomination: Celtic, Republic, Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192).

Initially, circa 2,050 coins. Only 1,938 enter in the museum collection: 270 republican denarii, 1662 imperial denarii, 5 drachms, 1 as: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 165-166). Found with a bronze jar.
The hoard comprised a 'vessel containing 60 aurei, of which 17 were bought by the Cabinet des Médailles and 2 by the Musée de Rouen, although neither acquisition can be found today.'
A hoard of 30 Roman silver denarii, found at Waddow Hall, Waddington, and declared Treasure Trove. All the coins with the Lancashire Museums Service
175 silver coins: 173 denarii, 1 quinarius and 1 drachm: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Stadtmuseum, Neunkirchen (165 coins), private collection? (10 coins), Austria; lost (unknown no.)

summary: A potful of Roman silver coins. Only five coins have been poorly documented: L. Scribonius Libo, Marcus Aurelius, Faustina I, Faustina II, Commodus.
Originally circa 660 denarii, 290 coins were studied, 100 preserved: Titus - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194); silver weight: 270.19 g. (100 coins).

81 bronze coins (72 Dium, 3 Thessalonica, 1 koinon of Macedonia, 1 Philippi, 1 koinon of Thessaly, 3 Roman bronzes) ranging from Domitian to Antoninus Pius, found in the foundation level besides the east wall of the first (western) room excavated at the place of the former sanctuary of Zeus Olympios, next to two other hoards (Dion 1999 and Dion 2000). All three hoards were buried in clay vases. The exact function of the area where the hoards were found is unclear, but the hellenistic sanctuary of Zeus Olympios had been transformed in Roman times, the wall of the temenos built over, and a theatre established.
The hoard comprised 4 copper-alloy statues and 2 copper-alloy vessels. One of the copper-alloy vessels contained 6 bronze coins of Marcus Aurelius and Divus Lucius Verus. One coin was lost.
40 denarii: Titus - Pertinax (AD 193).
2 silver coins: Titus for Divus Vespasianus, Hadrian.
403 denarii: Tiberius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 167-168); bronze and gold jewelry and bronze tweezers.
300 aurei: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
23 denarii found with a money-box: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 175-176)
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie a Județului Vâlcea, Râmnicu Vâlcea, Romania

summary: A Roman coin hoard of 80-100 denarii was unearthed in Samenheim. The precise find location and circumstances are not further ascertainable. The bulk of the find is lost. Only 20 denarii, ranging from Nero to Hadrian, now part of a private collection, are preserved. It is possible that these 20 coins may represent the full chronological coverage of the original find.
The hoard comprised 461 bronze coins, including 4 dupondii and asses and 457 sestertii of Galba to Marcus Aurelius, with a tpq of AD 172 to 173.

The hoard comprised '27 aurei of Vespasian to Commodus along with some silver denarii.' The gold coins were distributed amongst the family of the landowner. Although 9 of the aurei were given to the Musée de Rouen by M. Esnault, these were later stolen.
disposition: Musée de Rouen, France (9 coins. stolen)

summary: 480 denarii: Republic – Antoninus Pius (Marcus Aurelius Caesar) (AD 155-156).

320 D: Mark Antony - Commodus (AD 180): Discovered in an onion field after it had been ploughed. The finder carefully collected the coins together, but discarded fragments of the pottery container. Found whilst harvesting onions in a field in the north-western part of the village, next to the road leading to Gruia.
The hoard was found during excavations and comprised two piles of 20 base silver coins (plated denarii?) from Augustus to Antoninus Pius or Marcus Aurelius.
Circa 50 denarii, kept in a belt? 49 documented: Galba – Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II/Diva Faustina II) (AD 161-180).
disposition: National Museum, Prague, (inv.nos. H5-27.066–27.073); Museum of Poděbrady (inv.nos. 15.566–15.574, 15.576–15.577, 15.579–15.591) (inv.nos. 15.575, 15.578 were stolen), Czech Republic. Some of the coins are missing today.

summary: 110 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). Dispersed.
35 denarii: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-162).
The hoard comprised 144 silver and two gold coins dated between 32-31 BC and AD 124-128, buried in a clay juglet.
14 bronze coins: 10 dupondii, 4 asses: Tiberius - Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla) (AD 164-169).
A hoard of an unknown originally number of coins found by metal detecting. 44 coins were recovered: Republic - Trajan (AD 102).
disposition: National Museum of Union, Alba Iulia, Romania

summary: The hoard comprised of 27 aurei from Nero to Hadrian. 26 are identified.
The hoard comprised 31 sestertii, stacked one on top of the other, suggesting that they may have originally been packed in a tube or similar which has not survived: Nerva - Commodus (AD 189).

This hoard of 43 aurei, ranging from Nero to Marcus Aurelius, was discovered in June 2000 during the archaeological excavation at Plantation Place, Fenchurch Street, in the City of London. The coins were discovered in situ within a uniform context of silty brick-earth with organic inclusions. The absence of coins of Commodus suggests a deposition date probably no later than AD 180.
Hoard of unknown originally number of denarii found with a ceramic vessel. Only 13 coins were bought: Trajan, Hadrian 2, Antoninus Pius 4, Marcus Aurelius 2, Lucius Verus, Faustina II, Commodus 2.
271 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Nero – Commodus (AD 184-185).
865 coins: 29 aurei, 833 denarii: Republic - Hadrian (AD 137-138)
Five denarii found during survey in small area. Interpreted as small disturbed hoard.
121 denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195); silver weight: 322.18 g.
Unknown originally number of coins. Only 11 denarii are known: Vespasian 2, Titus 1, Nerva 2, Trajan 3, Hadrian 3.
2 denarii: Commodus, 1 imitation of Marcus Aurelius; silver weight: 5.06 g.
Large hoard of silver coins. Only 7 denarii are kept in the museum of Pleven: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Okrazen Istoriceski Muzej, Pleven, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1452 1-7

summary: A hoard of approximately 100 sestertii, dupondii and asses (Augustus - Commodus), found 500 m east of the village of Allaman, while digging the ground to install phone cables. 58 coins are preserved today (= ca. 60% of the hoard). The coins were heavily worn.
disposition: Musée cantonal d'archéologie et d'histoire, Monnaies et Médailles, Lausanne

summary: Hoard of few kilos of denarii. Only 6 coins are known: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius 4, Lucilla.

In early June 1958, 368 coins (4 aurei and 363 denarii, 1 Lycian drachm and 1 as) were found near Barway, Soham in Cambridgeshire. Further finds made in 1977, 1989, 1990 and 1991 bring the total to 471 coins, ranging up to Commodus.
disposition: Ashmolean Museum (part); Fitzwilliam Musem (part); British Museum (part); returned to finder (part)

summary: A hoard of 298 aurei dating from Nero to Lucius Verus was discovered in Vienna in 1799 during the construction of the Wiener Neustadt Canal. Of the 298 aurei, 24 were stolen and 274 initially were recovered. There is information for 279 coins: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). The average weight of the coins was 6.3g.
disposition: Münzkabinett, Kunsthistorischen Museum, Vienna, Austria (191 coins)

summary: c. 800 aurei: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 180-192). No further information given.
26 bronze coins: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 183).
disposition: Musée Château d'Annecy, France; Registre d'entrée, II, p. 230, no. 12.428

summary: 68 coins: 67 denarii, 1 imitation: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (Julia Domna) (AD 193-196). Weight: 156 g.
78 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
16 denarii (Galba - Hadrian) coins were found, covered with a terra sigillata plate, on Tiefenthaler Str.
7 sestertii: Trajan 2, Hadrian (Sabina) 1, Antoninus Pius (Faustina I) 2, Marcus Aurelius 2 (AD 161-180).
11 bronze coins: 5 sestertii, 4 dupondii, 2 asses: Domitian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 177-179)
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles, Bruxelles, Belgium (11 coins), donations P. De Baeck.

summary: The hoard comprised 26 bronze coins dated between 175-164 BC and AD 113-114 with four intruding coins.
(200) 38 denarii: Galba - Hadrian (AD 117-138).

199 denarii found at wetland deposit. Not one hoard, but a collection of several all deposited together. The earliest known contexts for Imperial denarii in Scandinavia are the Illerup weapon sacrifice dated by dendrochronology to c. 210 AD.

A. Marsden writes: "Roman coin hoard of 17 coins, all asses or dupondii of the first or early second century. Many of the coins are corroded and in poor condition but the four coins of Hadrian appear to have seen relatively little circulation when they went into the ground. The earlier ones appear heavily worn. We might suggest a date of loss or deposition around the middle of the second century AD.1) Claudius, as, reverse Minerva advancing right, appears regular, weight 5.93g, AD41-542) Uncertain as or dupondius, perhaps Nero, ?AD64-83) Vespasian, as, reverse probably standing figure, AD69-794-6) Uncertain Flavian, asses or dupondii, AD69-96 (3)7) Hadrian, as, reverse female standing right, AD117-258) Hadrian, as, reverse female seated left holding cornucopia, AD117-38 .9) Hadrian, as, reverse standing figure, AD117-3810) Hadrian, quadrans, reverse probably rostrum, probably RIC II, 623, AD121-211-17) Asses or dupondii, illegible (7)"
272 denarii: Tiberius - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194); silver weight: 813.04 g
disposition: Complexul Muzeal "Iulian Antonescu", Bacău, Romania; inv.nos. 7008-7236

summary: In 1867 a hoard of denarii was discovered in a sand hill on the left bank of the Oste river two miles from the estuary. The six preserved coins run from Vespasian to Commodus. It is to be assumed that the hoard was composed of more specimens.

This hoard was found in three ceramic pots and contained more than 4000 silver coins from which H. Ceka has published a total of about 3900 Roman Imperial coins in 1958. According to the publication of the hoard, which refers to the inquiry held by the Albanian Institutions at the time of the discovery, the hoard was constituted by silver coins and gold jewelry (rings, necklaces) but the latter was dispersed immediately after the discovery. Also, more than 100 coins were dispersed after the discovery. The coins are mostly Denarius dating from Nero to Marcus Aurelius (54-175 AD). Based on the numismatic data (there is no archaeological excavation that can help at the precision of the hoard's burying date), it should have been buried around or short after 170 AD.
disposition: The hoard is actually part of the collection of the Coin Cabinet, Institute of Archaeology, Albania

summary: Hoard of 39 denarii, 26 glass and amber beads, several fragmentary specimens, and fragments of metal ornaments, including two silver brooches: Vespasian - Commodus. "Denarii are dated to the second half of the 1st century – the end of 2nd century AD, dating of the brooches, however, indicates that the hoard was deposited in the second half of the 5th century AD."
15 sestertii of which Antoninus Pius 1, Faustina II 1, Commodus 1 were found by fishermen in a dune.
2 denarii found in mound: Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius/Faustina II (Diva).
7 asses: Domitianus - Hadrianus (AD 121-122).
Some 650 provincial bronze coins of Alexandria: Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius (AD 149-150). 'Intact hoard belonging to "qualche officina monetaria".
"About 100 tetradrachms and denarii together with a few dozen Roman coins (the latest being a fresh Hadrianic denarius...)" (Mildenberg 1984, 55).
The hoard comprised 26 bronze coins and 3 silver coins dated between the reigns of Vespasian and Hadrian.
(460) 452 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: M. Antony - Marcus aurelius (AD 176-180).
The hoard comprised approximately 1,600 aureii, from Julius Caesar to Commodus. Most of the hoard was immediately dispersed and sold.

A hoard of ca. 639 Roman denarii, found in a 'crock' at Upwood Farm, near Handley, while digging up an allotment garden in 1877. A list of 571 coins (by emperor only, see NC 1950, pp. 311-312) was made by Dr. Blackmore who himself received 464 coins of the hoard. His list is as follows: Marcus Antonius 20, Nero 2, Galba 2, Otho 4, Vitellius 3, Vespasian 60, Titus 5, Domitian 31, Nerva 19, Trajan 55, Hadrian 78, Sabina 4, Aelius 4. Pius 79, Faustian I 44, Marcus Aurelius 63, Faustian II 23, Verus 14, Lucilla 13, Commodus 36, Crispina 5, Didius Iulianus 1, Severus 1, and Domna 1. What remains of these 464 coins is now preserved in the Dorchester Museum, but only 440 coins were catalogued by Roberston (NC 1950). These are all denarii (Mark Antony - Julia Domna), except for one Lycian drachm of Trajan.

18 Cappadocian silver coins (didrachms, drachms and hemidrachms), sold to the museum of Zugdid by a farmer in the 1930s. The coins range from Vespasian to Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161), with 10 specimens being illegible. The coins were examined by Zograf in 1937.
4 asses found during excavations: Trajan - Antoninus Pius (AD 143-144).
disposition: Muzeul Dunării de Jos, Călărași, Romania; inv.nos. 45373-45376

summary: (?) 29 denarii: Republic - M. Aurelius (AD 166-167?)

The denarii (Vespasian - Trajan) were found together with a bronze brooch in the main building of a villa rusticate, located between Altdorf and Jülich-Kirchberg, on the site of the Inden open pit mining site (Braunkohletagebau Inden).
A an aureus of Commodus and an imitation were acquired by Nagpur Museum.
The hoard comprised an earthenware vessel containing 100 Roman coins including denarii, sestertii and dupondii, nearly all issues of Antoninus Pius, Faustina I and Faustina II.

Circa 30 denarii: Republic - Septimius Severus (AD 194-197). Near the denarii, a silver "pendant" was found, a piece of a brown object of unspecified utility, coins from the 15th to the 20th century and sherds of pottery (probably modern). The coins from the hoard were identified based on poor or very poor quality photos.
Unknown originally number of denarii. 8 denarii, 1 drachm of Dyrrachium and 1 denarius Antoninus Pius (Faustina I/Diva Faustina I) were recovered.
Unknown originally number of denarii. Only 10 pieces are known: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 186-192).
65 Roman silver coins found a small urn or earthern vessel, while removing the root of a tree near the house of Mr. Burke, at Beaconsfield. The coins ranged from Vespasian to Faustina.
126 bronze coins:120 sestertii, 5 dupondii, 1 as: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD. Only 73 coins are kept in the museums' collections.
disposition: Landesmuseum, Klagenfurt; Stadt Museum Villach, Austria. (73 coins)

summary: 7 denarii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180). Two other coins, one bronze and one bronze of the 4th century were handed together to the museum.

A hoard of 111 Roman imperial denarii was found by five treasure hunters in 2013 in Chernivtsi region. Information about the find and photos of some of the coins of the hoard were published by one of the finders on January 20, 2014 on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity. According to the finder, the hoard was found late at night, but there is no more detailed information about the further circumstances of the find. Judging by the information from the treasure hunter, the bulk of the coins in the hoard were denarii of Vespasian, Trajan and Hadrian, although there was also a coin of Galba, several denarii of Nerva, and 10-12 coins of Antoninus Pius and Faustina (I or II). In the photographs posted with the hoard information, there are images of 26 whole and five fragments of denarii (Vespasian, Terva, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius) – these were probably some of the coins that the informant found. The further fate of the coins in the hoard is unknown.
200-150 coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 48 denarii are known today: Nero – Hadrian (AD 125-128).
The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing 122 denarii from Otho to Septimius Severus with a tpq of AD 193. There were also 'some illegible issues' and three silver spoons.
30-40 denarii. Only 15 were seen: Vespasian – Commodus (AD 180-192). No further details.
79 coins: 6 denarii, 45 sestertii, 16 dupondii, 12 asses found with shreds from the ceramic vessel: Galba - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
556 denarii found with a bronze vessel: Trajan - Septimius Sverus (AD 193). Silver weight: 1,694g.
514 imperial bronze coins: Nerva - Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: Collection J. Marcello, Soprintendenza Archeologica di Padova, Italy

summary: The hoard comprised a burned pottery vessel containing 6 sestertii from Trajan to Commodus.
Unknown originally number of coins. Only 9 pieces were recorded: 7 sestertii, 1 dupondius, 1 as: Claudius I Commodus (AD 184).

Approx. 200 Roman silver coins found by chance as a waggon had crushed the jar that contained them. One of the accounts relating to this find gives a list of emperors: Nero, Vespasian, Titus, Domitian, Nerva, Trajan, Hadrian, the two Antonines, Faustina and L. Aelius Verus.

A large hoard of gold coins (ca. 8 kg), found 40 km south of Mardin in 1890. Gnecchi also reports gold ingots, though Regling doubts this. The hoard was dispersed, but 302 aurei (Nero - Marcus Aurelius) have been published by Regling.
18 sestertii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-183).

15 Roman gold coins described in the Madras Museum Accessions Register as 'purchases through individuals through the Collector of Canara'. It is unclear whether rhey represent a genuine hoard. Possible part of the cache of Roman coins dating from the first and second centuries A.D. was reportedly discovered some 600 kms. further to the north, on Kadmat Island in the neighbouring Laccadives group (Indian Union Territory of Lakshadweep) during 1948
Uncertain whether the coins were found together or single finds. Only four coins were provided with some information.
700 aurei and denarii found with a pot, probably ending with coins of Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
76 gold coins found in the nineties: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD
The hoard was found in a female burial and contained a box or casket containing 18 Antonine coins, earrings, brooches, a belt buckle and a terracotta figurine in the shape of a small horse.
The hoard comprised 22 bronze coins from the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
Hoard of circa 86-87 aurei found with a ceramic vessel with a graffiti "IRENE": Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
115 denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 167).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 1617-1730 (115 coins)

summary: Two denarii of Hadrian (AD 134-138).
(over 100) 3 sestertii: Hadrian - Marcus Aurelius (Divus Lucius Verus) (AD 169).
Two coins of Antoninus Pius, one Marcus Aurelius and one of Hadrian found in 1725, as part of a large 'parcel' of coins.
4 coins: 1 denarius, 3 sestertii: Vespasian, Hadrian Marcus Aurelius (2)
Unknown originally number of coins. Six denarii of Marcus Aurelius were seen.

A hoard of 5+ Roman provincial coins (Thessalonica: 1; Amphipolis: 4, Marcus Aurelius and Commodus), found in a grave in Amphipolis (Grave 1) in 1953. Archives in the Ephorate mention 18 further coins, but these could not be traced any more.
Four bronze coins, three sestertii and 1 as, were found together in a wall: Domitian, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161)
2 denarii: Antoninus Pius, Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: Regional museum, Chrudim, Czech Republic (now, missing)

summary: Originally 17 denarii, 16 preserved: Trajan - Commodus (AD 183-184); silver weight: 44.65 g. (16 coins). Together were also found: 1 gold bracteate, 1 gold finger ring, 2 neck-rings of bronze with silver mountings, 2 somewhat smaller bronze rings, 1 bronze clasp, 1 bronze strap-end, several bronze spirals, 1 amber bead, 2 coral beads.
150 coins, of which 10 sestertii: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
Hoard of 340 denarii were found with a bronze cauldron. Together was a silver ring.
disposition: The State Hermitage Museum, St. Petersburg, Russia

summary: From information obtained by Khaled Ben Rhomdane, the hoard comprised 2000 Republican denarii, although there is some suggestion that there were also imperial denarii including issues of Antoninus Pius. The hoard was stolen.

A small hoard of 12 Roman Imperial denarii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192) was discovered by a treasure hunter in early summer 2020. According to the finder the coins were found in a “small area” and represent “the contents of a purse”. The further fate of the coins is unknown: Trajan (1), Antoninus Pius (4), Marcus Aurelius (4), Commodus (1), unknown (2).
600 denarii. 361 pieces were examined: Republic - Hadrian (AD 117-138); silver weight: 669.3-1389.9 g.
A small hoard consisting of 15 bronze coins ranging from Hadrian to the reign of Marcus Aurelius was found in 'Haus V der Kiesgrube Lerpscher' during excavations in 1932.

A hoard of 12 Roman coins (apparently silver), found in 1755 while building a road from Taymouth to Glenquaich, near the crest of the hill. The same find (but described as 14 denarii) is recorded as having been found while digging the foundations of a tower near Taymouth. The coins are from the Antonine period, none later that Marcus Aurelius. No further details given.
35 sestertii, 707.80 g, found on a field ranging from Vespasian/Titus to Commodus (AD 186).

Around 600 silver and bronze coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 10 denarii were identified. The hoard was lost during WWII: Vespasian 5, Domitian 1, Trajan 1, Antoninus Pius 2, Marcus Aurelius 1.
disposition: School Museum, Brăești, Romania. Today, lost.

summary: 8 sestertii: Antoninus Pius - Commodus (AD 191-192).
The hoard was found during the excavation of a Gallo-Roman villa and comprised 6 sestertii from Trajan to Commodus with a tpq of AD.
3 coins, unknown denomination: Trajan, Hadrian and Marcus Aurelius (Caesar) (AD 145-161).
29 aurei including coins of Trajan, Hadrian, Sabina, Antoninus Pius, Lucius Verus. Together were found two gold fingerings.
More than 188 billon provincial coins of Alexandria: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 161-169). 'Found at Avenue of the Sphinxes during clearance excavations.'
4,418 tetradrachms of Alexandria and three bronze coin: Claudius I - Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus). Three large amphorae, filled with coins, dug out of the cellar of a house.
disposition: Type set of 519 coins in Oxford. 114 in London. 80 billon coins, presented to Glasgow in 1902 by the Egypt Exploration Fund and now among the duplicates, probably belong to this hoard. The rest dispersed. Detailed list in Oxford

summary: A hoard of 296 denarii (Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius), found by a grave-digger in Allerton Bywater churchyard.
4 denarii part of a hoard found on the same field like GANDARVE 1927, 1928, 1928-1931: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Diva Faustina I, Lucius Verus (AD 163-165).

1,022 denarii: Republic – Commodus (AD 180-192). The first lot of coins was found in 1943, the second one it was pretended to have been discovered in 1970 at the same place and by the same person. In fact there was just one hoard.
disposition: History Museum, Piatra Neamț, Romania (537 coins)

summary: Three denarii: Republic 1, Hadrian 1, Antoninus Pius 1 (AD 138-161).
15 sestertii of which Antoninus Pius 1, Faustina II 1, Commodus 1 were found by fishermen in a dune.
38 bronze coins: Augustus - Commodus (AD 192).
Around 350 denarii found in Duurzerdiep near Balloo. Only 85 denarii are known: Nero - Commodus (AD 180).
disposition: Drents Museum, Assen (84 coins), RMO, Leiden (4 coins), KPK, Leiden (1 coin); most disappeared PMD 84 coins; RMO 1 coin; [KPK 4 coins]; PMD: 80 coins: 58 in collection van der Feltz, 3 bought in 1871, 4 bought in 1873, 3 bought in 1881, 12 in the Frisian

summary: 47 denarii ranging from Nero to Hadrian (1 Nero, 3 Vespasian, 4 Titus, 6 Domitian, 3 Nerva, 20 Trajan, 10 Hadrian) were given to the Historisches Museum in Olten by the Schmid family in 1901/1902, next to 13 other Roman coins. Records say that all of these belonged to a find made in the vicinity of Matzendorf in 1841, but probably only the denarii are part of a hoard. No further details of the discovery are known.
10 large Roman imperial bronze coins: Hadrian 3, Antoninus Pius 4, Faustina I 2, Lucilla 1.
20 sestertii and 1 as: Nero - Commodus (AD 180-192).
More than 80 gold coins were discovered as surface finds between 1830 and 1958: Domitian - Commodus (AD 180-192). Only seven of the coins were described sufficiently well to be accurately identified.
A hoard of two Antonine sestertii and several items of gold jewellery, found in grave 23 in the western cemetery of Pella.
2 denarii: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161). Found while ploughing.
Treasure numbers associated with this hoard: 2013 T096. Other PAS records associated with this hoard: DEV-269707
HER record of a first century hoard found on Sheringham Beach along with remains of a ceramic container, exposed through cliff erosion. Only 5 coins were examined but the hoard was much larger.
Penhallurick (2009, 245 no. 251) records a metal detector find of 9 sestertii found in an area of about 50 square metres in the same field. Considered to be part of a scattered hoard.
10 coins found in the bottom of a bowl in locus 29.
6 denarii: Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Faustina II (AD 161-180)
50 denarii: Nero - Commodus (AD 192); silver weight: 137.84 g.
Unknown initial number of denarii. 11 coins provide information on the issuers: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 180-192).

103 denarii (Nero to Antoninus Pius) found near a large stone building and a series of ditches identified by a geophysical survey in 1999 and described as a farmhouse. The site has turned up building debris, pottery, and a series of other metal finds, including at least 46 other denarii that might have come from the coin hoard (Treasure report SS 91 69).
Seven denarii found through several rounds of detecting.
Over 361 silver and bronze coins were found in five ceramic vessels. Only 191 coins were documented: 157 sestertii, 24 denarii were studied: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
Around 200 denarii. Recovered 135 denarii found with metal vessel: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 141-143).
disposition: National History Museum of Romania, Bucharest, Romania

summary: More than 100 denarii found in a ceramic vessel - metal detecting - within an ancient settlement. The latest coins are from Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
10 coins found compacted together during excavations in Tofts Field in 1974. Recovered from surface of first re-metalling of Dere Street, to the east of the later fort, in Tofts Field.
Eight denarii found at Testrup Teglværk with fragments of a clay pot. One additional denarius was found nearby also with fragments from a clay pot. The finds may represent a series of sacrifices.
1,300 Provincial bronze coins of Alexandria: . 'Acquired in Egypt by Dattari, who sold it to Milne and Currelly.'
disposition: Partly in Oxford, partly in Toronto.

summary: 34 coins found by Caspar Reuvens in 1828: 2 denarii, 3 sestertii, 15 asses, 6 dupondii, 6 dupondius/as, others unclear: Nerva - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
5, or possibly up to 8 aurei, from Nero to Diva Faustina I (AD 161). 5 aurei are listed here, and the other 3 ones (Bland/Loriot 343-5) are listed separately as single gold finds.
disposition: Harris Museum, Preston (part); Blackburn museum (2 coins)

summary: 666 coins: 665 denarii, 1 drachm: Nero – Antoninus Pius (AD 140).
The hoard comprised 171 aurei and 1 denarius from Nero to Marcus Aurelius.
disposition: União de Bancos Portugueses. Fundação Millenium, Oporto, Romania

summary: ca. 80 sestertii and dupondii, but not all of them are identified: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192).
25 coins? "Medium-sized hoard. Allegedly Bar Kokhba silver and bronze together with Syrian tetradrachms and Roman denarii" (Mildenberg 1984, 56).
14 Roman bronze coins and one autonomous Histrian coin found in a small ceramic vessel: Hellenistic - Hadrian (AD 117-138)
disposition: Coin Room, Institute of Archaeology, Bucharest, Romania

summary: The hoard comprised approximately 200 'small Roman bronzes' of the Antonine period, most of which were well preserved. Unfortunately, an acid bath rendered them indecipherable.
22 asses: Augustus - Antoninus Pius (AD 145-161) .
Hoard of 300 denarii found with a vessel. 130 pieces are known: Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: At the beginning of the 20th century, in the collection of the industrialist Hertig in Łódź.

summary: A hoard of denarii, found while digging sand in a sand-pit, between the Lion Foundry, Kirkintilloch, and Barley Bank houses. 24 coins were first published in 1894, followed by a more complete list in 1911 (42 coins). 5 more coins were found since, giving a total of 47 denarii (Vespasian - Faustina II) that were published.
270 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Nero - Commodus (AD 183-184).
Unknown originally number of coins. Only five coins are recorded. Uncertain whether they were found together.
disposition: Museu de Martins Sarmento, Guimarães. Portugal

summary: 4 denarii found in the lid from a wooden box (Cassette) found in a princely grave: Hadrian 1, Marcus Aurelius/Lucius Verus 1, uncertain 2. In the same grave was found on the left side of the Skeleton an aureus of Clausiud II (see single gold find WROCŁAW ZAKRZÓW).
240 silver coins: 228 denarii, 2 drahms found in a ceramic vessel: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 143-144).
disposition: History Museum, Razgrad, Bulgaria; inv.no. IF, hoard 8

summary: Upwards of 600 Roman denarii were found in 1851 in a field that was formerly a deep bog. The coins were all lying close together as if they had been enclosd in a bag. Also found at the same spot were an iron sword and an imperfect silver ornament thought to have been the crest of a helmet. A detailed account of 104 coins is given in 1852 and a further 26, found in a moss at Kirkness (Kinross) in 1851, were reported in 1934 and published in 1939. Coins range from Mark Antony to Septimius Severus.
Around 500 denarii. Only three are known from Domitian and Trajan.
disposition: Muzeum Archeologiczne i Etnograficzne w Łodzi, Poland (3 coins)

summary: IARCH record for a hoard of five denarii of Septimius Severus in a small conical lead-alloy container.

The hoard was found in the foundation trench of a Gallo-Roman wall. It comprised 43 denarii from Vitellius to Marcus Aurelius as Caesar (AD 148/149). It may originally have been placed in a small box, as fragments of copper-alloy scrap were found in association with the coins.
Unknown initial number of coins. 244 denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-175)
Hoard of 89 gold stateri of the Bosporan kings: Sauromates I - 3, Cotys II - 6, Rhoemetalkes - 11, Eupator - 69.

A hoard of 180 denarii, ranging from Nero to Commodus. 9 denarii (Otho-Commodus) were found in 1938, on Lord Clyde's estate of Briglands, Rumbling Bridge. Subsequent discoveries at the same place were made in 1948-57, two-thirds of the way up the steep left (east) bank of the River Devon, after a coin was found at the opening of a rabbit hole. One further coin was reported in 1972.

A hoard of 59 plated Roman silver coins (cistophori and denarii), found on the south slope of the Acropolis in excavations by the Greek Archaeological Service, near the central room of the Eastern Roman cistern. Of the 59 coins, 35 could be identified: 16 cistophoric tetradrachms (Claudius – Nerva) and 19 denarii (Trajan – Commodus).
The hoard comprised a large number of silver denarii of Clodius Albinus (approximately 15 pounds in weight or 2,000 pieces).
The hoard comprised 14 sestertii from Trajan to Commodus and was found placed next to two greyware ceramic vessels.
The coins were found together, in a burnt layer 25 cm deep under Plattenstraße at Ritona.
9 bronze coins from Trajan to Marcus Aurelius, most likely a part of a larger find.
Eight sestertii found in Pot Ridings Wood.
Originally 66 denarii, 55 preserved: Titus - Commodus (AD 188-189); silver weight: 155.21 g.
826 coins found with a ceramic vessel. 763 denarii were: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 167). The hoard was entirely recovered but not published accurate.
32 coins: 1 republican denarius, 31 bronze coins: Augustus - Septimius Severus (AD 197-198).
The hoard comprised a vessel containing several hundred bronze coins from Trajan to Antoninus Pius.
112 denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195).
Unknown originally number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 29 denarii were documented: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 180-19922).
Hoard of circa 350 silver coins. 26 denarii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192). A tetradrachm of Thassos (intruder?) were documented.
50 denarii ranging from the 2nd century BC Republic coins to Trajan, and including one plated specimen, found in a wooden building from the late 2nd century AD.
10 denarii (Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius) found corroded together with a bronze fibula and a clasp. They might have been contained in a purse.
Funerary find: 2 aurei in a grave: Nero, Marcus Aurelius
disposition: Musée Château d'Annecy, France; Registre des entrées, III, f. 114, nos. 3558-3559

summary: Around 100 hundred Roman bronze coins (sestertii, dupondii/asses): Domitian - Didius Julianus (AD 193)
disposition: Museum of Chambéry, France (partially). private collections: Conte, Faudrain, Fivel etc.

summary: 1 silver + 4 bronze coins: (1st century -2nd century AD), Augustus - Commodus (AD 192) found during archaeological excavations.
212 denarii found with a box: Nero - Septimius Severus (Cludius Albinus Caesar) (AD 194-195). Together were found 1 bronze box, 2 gold bracteates, 1 spiral rod and 1 gilt silver ring.
disposition: Swedish History Museum, Stockholm (inv.nos. 5204 coins; 4877 objects)

summary: 5 sestertii ranging from Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 173-174). Part of a larger hoard.
disposition: Narodni muzej, Ljubljana, Slovenia; 5 coins; dispersed.

summary: 7 coins found stuck together: 4 denarii, 1 plated denarius, 1 sestertius, 1 as: Mark Antony - Hadrian (AD 121-122).
disposition: County Museum of History and Art, Zalău, Romania (inv.no. CC 315/90)

summary: Denarius hoard consisting of 97 denarii found through metal detectoring and excavation. Vespasian to Antoninus Pius.
22 denarii: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 194).
49 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Republic - Antoninus Pius (AD 141-161).
Two denarii issued by Marcus Aurelius (AD 166-176) were bought from the same local person.
Around 200 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Trajan - Didius Julianus (AD 193).
disposition: Münzkabinett, Staatliche Museen zu Berlin, Germany (2 coins)

summary: Some aurei. Only five are presented from Nero to Antoninus Pius (Marcus Aurelius Caesar).

The hoard comprised a vessel filled with sestertii, which were shared amongst the finders. After an investigation by the Gendarmarie, 59 were found. In 1980, illegal metal detecting on the site recovered a further 5 coins which are likely to be part of the hoard.
The hoard comprised 100 Roman coins, including one of Antoninus Pius.
HER record of 30 to 40 denarii from Vespasian to Antoninus Pius found in the mid 1970s following dredging of the Little Ouse and not apparently recorded elsewhere.
A hoard of four aurei: Nero, Trajan 2, Antoninus Pius for Faustina I (Diva).
disposition: Madras Museum, Chennai except for Trajan coins

summary: Hoard of 17 aurei. Only two are known: Pertinax, Septimius Severus.

West Parade site Area III, Roman interval tower. In late Roman period, interval tower became derelict, & much of upper part prob. demolished/ robbed. Lower part of tower infilled with demolition debris, incl. ceramic tile frags. & mortar, animal bone waste from food consumption, & bird & animal skeletons, incl. ravens & dogs, frogs & toads, & remains of owl pellets. 3 silver denarii in fine condition also found amongst demolition debris, of Trajan, Hadrian & Faustina, minted in early to mid 2nd C. before tower even built; & it is likely that they were hidden & subsequently lost, poss. as part of a larger hoard, whilst tower was still in use.Gilmour, B. 1999. Excavations. In C. Colyer, B.J.J. Gilmour & B. Jones The Defences of the Lower City. Excavations at The Park and West Parade 1970-2 and a Discussion of Other Sites Excavated up to 1994. The Archaeology of Lincoln VIII-2. CBA Res. Report 114, pp. 191.
Grave find of 4 coins: 1 denarius, 1 sestertius, 1 dupondius, 1 as Trajan to Antoninus Pius (AD 141-161).
162 sestertii and 1 as. The origins of this hoard is doubtful. It is also possible that it contains 2 sestertii from Marcus Aurelius and 2 imitations of a double sestertius from Postumus.
102 sestertii, 5 dupondii and 1 as ranging from Domitian to Marcus Aurelius (AD 179-180). Hoard was originally larger.
(3043) denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180)
disposition: Regional History Museum, Pleven, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 1453 1-349; 1466 1-8; 1468 1-25; 1470 1-352

summary: Hoard consists of 70 Roman denarii (26 studied, 1 solidus): Vespasian - Didius Julianus (AD 193). Together with these coins were found: a solidus of Constantius II (Nicomedia/Cyzicus/Antioch, AD 340-355) as a pendant, two gold pendants slightly different in size, two belt buckles: one silver and one bronze, and a group of 13 silver pendants from a necklace.

The hoard comprised 60 silver coins from the reigns of Nero to Hadrian, deposited during the Bar Kokhba Revolt (AD 132-136). These coins were: 42 denarii (Vespasian to Hadrian), 10 tetradrachms and 1 tridrachm from Antioch (Nero to Trajan), 6 tridrachms and 1 drachm of Trajan from Arabia.
The hoard comprised a total of 22 denarii dating from the Republic to Antoninus Pius. There are no further details about the structure of the hoard.
disposition: National History Museum, Bucharest, Romania (22 coins)

summary: Unknwon number of denarii found with an iron vessel. Only 14 denarii were identified: Nero - Septimius Severus (Caracalla Caesar) (AD 196-198).
770 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. Among issuers: Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius.

The hoard comprised 23 sestertii struck for Trajan, Hadrian, and Antoninus Pius. Discovered at a depth of 4 metres when a drainage ditch was being dug during road improvement works to the south of the railway station in Kiesen.
39 Roman imperial denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Vitellius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
Over 200 silver coins from Vespasian to Hadrian (Ad 117-138). No detailed information.
The hoard comprised a ceramic urn containing 50 corroded, worn, illegible Roman coins, with the exception being two sestertii of Hadrian and Antoninus Pius.
Hoard of 800 denarii. Among them, three pieces of Pertinax
6 sestertii were found at a gravel pit close to Eisenfeld.

Funerary deposit of 5 denarii in a Late Roman grave: Trajan - Commodus (AD 192). In the same grave were found: a bronze brooch, an iron brooch, an iron bracket, one thorn, an iron firesteel and two knives.
Two denarii: Trajan, Marcus Aurelius for Lucilla. No further details.
Unknown original number of denarii. 32 denarii have been studied: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193).

Several hundreds coins (principally of Nerva, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, and Faustina), found in 1842, while removing some sods from the surface of a piece of moss land. Three publications (see under references) list groups of coins belonging to this hoard. Some coins had marks indicating that the hoard had been buried in a bag of coarse cloth. One further denarius of Trajan in HCC, p. 34, no. 207, Glasgow.
36 aurei: Vespasian - Trajan (AD 103-111) found hidden in the wall of a Roman house.
119 Alexandrian billon tetradrachms: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 155-156) Found during excavations.
disposition: Museum of Anthropology of the University of California, Berkeley, USA (1935), inv.no. 445

summary: 29 coins of unknown metal from "the 4th consulate of Vespasian to the 4th year of reign of Antoninus Pius " (AD 149.
175 denarii: Republic – Hadrian (AD 134-138).
Hoard of 125 denarii. The large majority belong to Trajan including the title DACICVS. The hoard was found with two silver vessels embedded each other.

An ensemble of 6 denarii (incl. Vespasian, Hadrian with Clementia on the reverse, 2 Antoninus, 2 Crispina), found during excavations at the broch of Lingro, 1870-71, in different parts of the outbuildings [i.e. of the broch], that may have come from a scattered hoard.
(ca. 600) 569 denarii: Mark Antony - Commodus (AD 180-192)
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. ХХХІІІ - 398 coins

summary: 91 tetradrachms of Alexandria in a small pot found during excavations. Range: Claudius I - Marcus Aurelius (AD 169-170).
disposition: 12 in London, 5 in Oxford. The rest dispersed. Detailed list in Oxford

summary: 102 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms found during excavations in the foundation of a house: Claudius I (Messalina) - Antoninus Pius (AD 149-150).

The Cabinet des Médailles de la Bibliothéque Nationale acquired 36 aurei on 17.03.1847 (Reg. C, nos. 1982-2017) and a further 44 on 8.2.1848 (Reg. C, nos. 2117-2160). 79 remain (with one swopped in 1939). The Musée Saint-Jean d'Angers bought 6 aurei on 3.4.1847 and 2 on the 13.06.1847, with fragments of the vase acquired on 04.03.1849 (Reg. I, p. 53-54, no. 209, p. 58, no. 217, p. 74, no. 269). They were stolen in March 1885.
17 denarii and 1 aureus: Gaius - Hadrian (AD 121-123).
18 bronze coins: Augustus - Marcus Aurelius
Hoard of 21 sestertii. Among them coins of Domitian, Nerva, Hadrianus and Antoninus Pius (AD 138).
The hoard was hidden inside the camp: 25 aurei, 610 denarii, 2 asses, 1 quadrans, as well as gold and silver jewelry in a bronze cauldron: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 165-166).
disposition: Historischen Museum der Stadt Regensburg, Germany

summary: Accidentally discovered by schoolboy Leonid Ryshchuk in 1974. The hoard was found on the territory of the Lyshchitsy peat enterprise, on the northern edge of the peat bog, near the bridge across the ditch, 250 m south of the field, south of the cemetery of the village of Ogorodniki. According to the discoverer, the total number of coins ranged from 350 to 500 pieces. Most of the coins were taken by local residents and collectors, only 48 denarii have survived from this find (transferred to the Brest Regional Local History Museum). In 1974, at the hoard find spot, L. Pobol carried out excavations, another 63 coins were discovered (transferred to the Museum of ancient Belarusian Culture of the National Academy of Sciences of Belarus). 5 coins from the hoard are in the private collection of V. Pinchuk in Minsk. A total of 116 coins are known: 115 denarii (Nero-Marcus Aurelius) and one imitation of denarius.
disposition: Brest Regional Local History Museum (48 coins); Museum of ancient Belarusian Culture of the National Academy of Sciences of Belarus (63 coins); private collection of V. Pinchuk in Minsk (5 coins)

summary: Originally, 55 denarii, 12 preserved: Trajan - Clodius Albinus (AD 193); silver weight: 32.07 g. Two silver rings were found together.
149 silver coins: 1 republican denarius, 147 imperial denarii, 1 drachm: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 168)
IARCH record for a hoard of 14 denarii. For further details and images see WMID-01F18E. Unpublished catalogue by Richard Abdy.
Unknown originally number of denarii found with a ceramic vessel. 63 coins were recovered, 62 denarii, 1 drachm: Vitellius – Marcus Aurelius (AD 162-163).
Six aurei found in grave of Asfagur: Titus, Trajan, Hadrian 4 (AD 117-138).
236 aurei and denarii from the time of Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
(c. 260) 77 sestertii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 163-164)
Found during excavations. Assemblage of 10 aes coins, Domitian to Commodus, in a roadside ditch, spread out over ca. 5x1 metres. The hoard comprised 3 dupondii and 7 asses.
18 denarii found on a field: Otho - Hadrian (AD 128-136).
The hoard comprised Roman gold and silver coins: Galba - Hadrian (AD 117-138).

At least 33 denarii (Vespasian to Marcus Aurelius) found in 1940 by gardeners engaged in converting a tennis court into a vegetable patch. Pye reports that the hoard was contained in a pot with a tile lid, since lost, and that one of the finders removed at least 27 of the coins, none of which were recovered. Four further reports of coins from Corton House appear in the Transactions of the Radnorshire Society over succeeding years; whether these were new discoveries at/near the same site or part of the original find is unclear. The original size of the hoard is, therefore, uncertain, and is likely to have been larger than the 33 denarii detailed here.
The hoard was found in a vessel containing coins of the Principate, including 2 coins of Antoninus Pius and Marcus Aurelius.
5 AE (2 Hadrian, 1 Antoninus Pius and 2 unidentified)
A concealed hoard of 22 aurei of 'Nero, Hadrian and the Antonines' found c. 1888. It is believed that the hoard was from Wanborough / Durocornovium, but this is not certain.
11 denarii found on the same field: Caesar – Vespasian (AD 69-79).
102 bronze coins found with an amphora and dispersed in the coin trade: Tiberius - Marcus aurelius (AD 161-180).

Originally 5 denarii, 2 preserved: Hadrian, Hadrian (Sabina), Antoninus Pius Antoninus Pius (Faustina I), Didius Julianus (Manlia Scantilla); silver weight: 4.61 g. (2 coins). Not certain that they were found together!
107 denarii were found in a ceramic vessel together with 6 silver bracelets (3 pairs), a plated silver brooch and glass beads. No further informationn
317 silver coins: 313 denarii, (2 copies and 2 Lycian drachms) with a ceramic vessel, ten meters from BIRNIE 2001: Nero - to Septimius Severus (AD 195-196).
At least 1381. Uncertain if all the coins belong to this hoard or they are contaminated from NIETULISKO MAŁE 1: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 197-198).
disposition: State Archaeological Museum, Wrasaw, Archaeological and Ethnographical Museum, Łodz; Museum in Ostrowiec Świętokrzyskie, Archaeological Museum in Krakow

summary: 6 Roman imperial bronze coins. The latest one is a sestertius of Antoninus Pius: Gaius - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
Circa 60 aurei. Disintegrated cloth bag found during excavations in the courtyard of a house.
Unknown initial number of denarii. 27 coins provide information on issuers: Nerva - Commodus (AD 180-192).

A hoard of 20 denarii (Antoninus Pius - Commodus, but no details known for 12 coins) was found between 1880 and 1890 in a glass bowl, between the city and the railroad, directly southeast of the confluence of the Horst- and Totengraben.
41 denarii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192).

A hoard of at least 50 Roman Imperial denarii and a silver and gold buckle were discovered by a treasure hunter no later than 2021, probably in Zhytomyr region. Information about the hoard and general photo of the coins with the buckle were published in one of the groups on Facebook, dedicated to treasure hunting on November 1, 2021. One of the group members (Vasyl Ugrynchuk of Volodarsk in Zhitomyr region) reported that the hoard was discovered by his acquaintances (possibly also from Zhytomyr region). On the photo denarii of Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius, Commodus can be recognized. The buckle is quite massive (ca. 5-7 cm), on the clip there is a gold plate with ornamentation. The further fate of the hoard is unknown.
The hoard comprised 10 sestertii from Trajan to Commodus with a tpq of AD 190. TAF interprets the hoard as being a purse drop.
The hoard was found in a ceramic vessel hidden under a stone and comprised 3 coins including a sestertius of Nerva, a denarius of Trajan and an as of Hadrian.
5 coins found scattered near a disturbed grave within a cremation necropolis: Hadrian 1 as, Antoninus Pius 4 sestertii (AD 152-153).
A hoard of 300 Roman denarii ranging from Vespasian to Commodus (AD 74). Only 19 coins have been recorded. Based on the portrait style, the coins seem to be imitations of known genuine types.
disposition: Private collection A.A. Tarpi, Dushambe, Tajikistan

summary: The hoard comprised 5 gold coins, 15 silver coins, and 4 bronze coins dated to the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
Three aurei are said to have been found by Landrat von Weyhe. These might be the remnants of a gold hoard. Apparently, there was another aureus found at the place.
Three denarii found in a funerary urn together with an amber bead and a wire link ring: Domitian, Hadrian Marcus Aurelius (Divus) (AD 180).
72 denarii: Antoninus Pius – Commodus (AD 180-192).
Hoard of 49 coins and jewelry was found with a ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192). Jewelry: bronze loop, bronze buckle, silver buckle, 7 silver rings, 39 pearls of amber, coral, glass.
disposition: Local history museum Cherkasy, Ukraine (inv.no. 190092 - vanished in 1941-1945)

summary: The hoard comprised 2 batches containing 24 bronzes from Trajan to Antoninus Pius for the first and 300 bronzes for the second.
25 bronze coins of which are know Augustus 1, Hadrian 1, and 1 of the two Faustinae (AD 138-180).
A hoard of approx. 35 gold coins (Vespasian - Antoninus Pius), scattered within a small space in fire debris of a destructed Roman house, found during work on the canalisation in the Leostrasse.
(c. 400) 3 denarii: Nero - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
disposition: Archaeological Museum Charleroi, Belgium 13 coins, only 5 retrieved)

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. 11 aurei: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 162-163).
The hoard comprised 4 aurei and 132 silver coins, as well as jewellery from the second century AD: Nero - Hadrian (AD 117-138). Associated with Bar Kochba revolt (AD 132-135).
Unknown originally number of denarii. 10 coins were seen: Vespasian 2, Trajan 4, Antoninus Pius 1, Marcus Aurelius 3. Possible, part of the same hoard with Strunga II and III.
Unknown initial number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. 350 coins were basically examined : Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Balaton Museum Keszthely (312 coins); Magyar Nemzeti Muzeum, Budapest (38 coins), Hungary

summary: 28 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms: Claudius I - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-139). Probably a hoard, found during excavations.
disposition: Museum of Anthropology of the University of California, Berkeley, USA (1935)

summary: A cultic area with two temples was excavated southwest of the intersection of Groß-Umstädter straße/Aschaffenburger straße. One of the two temples had a quadratic cella, corresponding to the Gallo-Roman type. A small hoard of 5 bronze coins (Trajan to Antoninus Pius) and a complete set of cultic vessels was found in its immediate vicinity.
(c. 40) 27 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Trajan - Commodus (AD 190-191).
disposition: Muzeul Naţional de Etnografie şi Istorie Naturală; Inv. 18.494/AR 6.698-6.724, N 6.110; acquisition document 86/22.05.1986.

summary: Around 1,200 aurei (according to Savio/Cavagna): Nero - Commodus (AD 180-192). Reported to have contained thousands of coins. The main part had been dispersed before the rest was confiscated.
8 coins: 7 denarii, 1 sestertius found in a destruction layer caused by fire: Vitellius - Antoninus Pius (AD 159-160).
The hoard comprised 18 denarii, sestertii, dupondii and asses dating to the second century AD. TAF interprets the hoard as the contents of a purse lost when the building was demolished.
200 aurei: Galba - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

469 (or more?) silver coins of Caesarea in Cappadocia found with a ceramic vessel. These range from Nero to Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 161-169). The hoard also included one denarius of Augustus and a barbarous imitation of a stater of Lysimachus.
disposition: National Museum of Georgia; National Museum of Abkhazia (91 coins); Pushkin Museum of Fine Arts in Moscow, Russia (104 coins)

summary: Hoard of an unknown number of denarii. Only 9 coins were documented: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 190). One nummus of Constantine I can be considered as an intruder.
disposition: Archaeological Museum Warsaw, Poland (donation R. Turkievich, 1936 )

summary: The hoard originally comprised 1,305 Greek/Roman imperial/Roman provincial silver and bronze coins together with gold and silver ancient jewellery. Nowadays 1043 bronze coins and two couple gold earrings are kept in the Archaeological Museum of Shahat. According to the 1934 find report, the missing silver part featured 32 Greek silver coins (280-50 BC, including 16 coins from the Achaean League and four Rhodian drachms), 39 Roman imperial denarii and quinarii (Otho-Trajan, AD 69-116, mint of Rome) and 45 Roman provincial drachms and hemidrachms struck under Trajan (RPC III, 1-3, AD 100). These, as well as 89 sestertii, 77 dupondii, and 128 asses, were probably made in Rome for circulation in Cyrenaica.
15 aurei and 470 denarii, ranging from the Republican period to Marcus Aurelius, found by a labourer at work in Rudchester grounds, while digging up the foundation of an old fence in 1766.
A hoard containing nearly 100 silver denarii from the period of Trajan and Hadrian was unearthed between Trostadt and Siegritz.

The hoard comprised a terracotta vessel containing a block of Roman bronze coins stuck together with corrosion products. Rever identified approximately 180 sestertii and 5 'middle bronzes'. The hoard was found by a labourer digging a hole to plant a tree.
The hoard comprised 53 copper-alloy coins from Trajan to Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

274 coins: 75 sestertii, 117 dupondii, 74 asses, 7 dupondii/asses, 1 bronze medallion: Gaius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 169-176). Together with the coins were found: 2 silver pans, 1 silver plate, silver wire bracelet.
(25) 15 denarii: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
disposition: Regional History Museum Vidin, Bulgaria; inv. no. 426

summary: 151 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms, 9 Greek bronzes, 1 provincial bronze and 1 ring: Ptolemaic dynasty - Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 166-167). Reported to have been found in an alabaster container. Mixed up with another hoard of over 130 coins not identified.
44 denarii: Trajan - Didius Julianus (AD 193). Found together with a silver brooch dated between the end of the 4th century beginning of the 5th century AD.
20 denarii, 15 studied: Trajan – Commodus (AD 189).
Unknown number of denarii hoard. 4 coins entered museum collection in Yambol: Vespasian 2, Nerva 1, Trajan 1.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Yambol, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2924-2929

summary: 10 coins. Unknown denominations: Augustus - Hadrianus (AD 117-138).
Seven denarii found under a pile of Roman bricks: Trajan – Septimius Severus (AD 197).

In 1900 the Hanauer museum acquired 44 denarii from an antique dealer in Büdingen, which obviously belonged to a find. The coins were supposedly found in 1899 in Marköbel during the construction of a house. The coins are today no longer present in the Hanauer museum. Coins range from Nero to Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus).
220 denarii: Republican (163), Imperial (57); Republican - Antoninus Pius (AD post 141)
disposition: Union Museum Alba Iulia, Romania (49 coins)

summary: Hoard of 100 denarii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-192).
The hoard comprised around 200 tetradrachms and 1,000 denarii from the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
(Unknown initial number of coins, 5.76 kg): 367 denarii: Nero - Commodus (AD 180-192).

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing at least 11 coins (10 sestertii and 1 dupondius) found during construction work. The pot and 11 coins were given to the Museum Laufen, where, ca. 2014, only these 11 coins could be identified: Domitian (1 coin), Trajan (1 coin), Hadrian (5 coins), Antoninus Pius (1 dupondius), M. Aurelius/L. Verus (1 coins), Commodus (1 coin), Crispina (1 coin).

83 bronze coins and (silver coins?) found in a marble rock. There is some information on 28 coins: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). The three denarii may not belong to this hoard (Dembski 1977).
disposition: Museum Carolino Augusteum, Salzburg, Austria (26 coins); Prähistorischen Staatssammlung, München, Germany (3 coins?)

summary: A small hoard of 15 Roman imperial denarii and one Lycian drachm: Vespasian – Commodus (AD 180-192) was found in April 2017 in Khmelnytskyi region. Information and general photo of the coins of the hoard were published on April, 29, 2017 on the Ukrainian treasure hunting forum Violity. By the treasure hunter himself, the hoard was called the “purse of denarii”. The coins have a fairly good preservation (weak wear). In early May 2017, the coins were sold at the auction Violity and their fate is unknown.
28 sestertii in a ceramic vessel: Domitian - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
The hoard comprised approximately 2,000 sestertii of the Antonine period.

33 denarii (Mark Antony to Antoninus Pius) found by a party of schoolchildren among rubble in a chamber of the prehistoric and Roman mine workings beneath the hill fort at Llanymynech Ogof. The coins were fused together before being separated by a local antiquarian. A piece of black pottery picked up on another occasion close to the site of the discovery may possibly indicate that the hoard has been disturbed at some time.
disposition: National Museums Wales, Cardiff (part); Oswestry Museum (part)

summary: The hoard comprised an unknown number of coins of which 24 denarii, including 11 Republican issues and 13 imperial issues from Vitellius to Antoninus Pius were recorded.

A hoard of 47 Roman imperial denarii: Vespasian to Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161) was discovered at the end of 2021 in Lviv region. Information about the hoard and photos of the coins were published in one of the groups on Facebook, dedicated to treasure hunting, by user Mikhail Tabachko (Михаил Табачко) on December 14, 2021. The finder reported only that the coins were found together somewhere in the Lviv region. The coins are well preserved. The further fate of the hoard is unknown.
14 denarii part of a hoard found on the same field like GANDARVE 1927, 1928, 1928-1931: Vespasian (Domitian Caesar) - Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II) (AD 161-175); silver weight: 22.67 g (8 coins).

54 Republican and imperial denarii issued by M. Fonteius, L. Marcius Censorinus, C. Naevius Balbus, M. Cordius, L. Plautius, A. PLautius, P. Clodius Turrinus, L. Thorius Balbus, Sextus Pompeius, Julius Caesar, Mark Antony's legionary denarii (III, VI, VIIII, XII, XIX, XII) des denarii of Sex. Pompey (with reverses of Amphinomos and Anapias), Julius Caesar and emperors to Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
The hoard comprised 2 aurei, more than 400 denarii and some bronze coins and was found in association with a grave: Vespasian Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

A hoard of at least 160 Roman imperial denarii was found by a treasure hunter in 2009 or 2010 near the village of Baikivka. According to his information, the hoard was partially ploughed, but the main part of it was at a depth of ca. 50 cm together with fragments of a vessel (pot?). The coins had traces of bronze oxides. Photographs of the deposit have not been preserved, but it is known that most of the coins date from the Nerva-Antonine dynasty, including coins of Antoninus Pius and Commodus. The fate of the coins is unknown.
Unknown number of aurei and denarii: Gaius - Antoninus Pius (Faustina II) (AD 145-161).
The hoard comprised 9 silver coins of the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).

The hoard originally comprised ca. 1,750 Greek/Roman republican/imperial/provincial silver and bronze coins ranging from 270 BC to the reign of Trajan (116 AD). 570 of them are know kept in the Shahat Archaeological Museum while further 84 specimens have been identified through photographic documentation.
The hoard comprised 16 denarii dated between AD 98/99 and AD 128/129.

2nd century. Hoard of 8 coins recovered with a frag. of a bronze vessel, possibly its original container. The coins all exclusively 2nd C terminating with issue of Crispina (AD 177-183), though hoard may have been deposited in 3rd C AD.Rudling, D. 1982. The Romano-British farm on Bullock Down. In P. Drewett (ed.) The Archaeology of Bullock Down, Eastbourne, East Sussex.
68 denarii: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 150-151).
16 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Commodus (AD 192).
Group of 5 coins: Tiberius (Divus Augustus) as, Claudius I as, Nero 1 denarius, 1 sestertius, Hadrian sestertius (AD 117-138).
8 denarii found on a field: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla) (AD 161-180).
Six denarii found together on a floor of a Roman edifice from the Dacian kingdom capital of Sarmizegetusa Regia Republic - Trajan (AD 101-102).
disposition: Muzeul Civilizației Dacice și Romane, Deva, Romania

summary: In 1908, 6 denarii (Domitian to Antoninus Pius) were found lying together at the entrance of cellar 208 (in the vicus surrounding the Roman fort).
13 silver coins: 10 denari, 3 cistophori: Domitian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194). Found with traces of a textile bag.
37 denarii part of a hoard found on the same field like GANDARVE 1927 and 1928, now, in a private collection: Vespasian (Domitian Caesar) - Commodus (AD 192); silver weight: 101.03 g.
disposition: Private collection Axel O. Larsson, Stockholm

summary: The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 840 well-preserved sestertii, of which 808 were identified by Auvray. The composition of this hoard varies slightly in lists compiled by Ledru and Cauvin. L'annuaire l'An VIII mentions coins of Septimius Severus and of Caracalla from the same parish. It is possible that these were also a part of the hoard, although they have not been added to the database record.
Unknown number of denarii. There is information on four coins: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius (Caesar), Faustina I/II (AD 138-180).
55 billon drachms of Alexandria: Hadrian - Antoninus Pius (AD 154-155) found at floor level in a room during excavations of a house.
Nine denarii placed in a cavity: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 185).
A hoard of 54 bronze coins (Tiberius - Diva Faustina II) found during excavations in the Roman vicus; it was unearthed in stages, in 1983 and then 1986.

A clump of at least 14 denarii molten together. The only reasonably identifiable coin is one of Antoninus Pius for Diva Faustina I, minted between 141 and 161 AD. Another denarius was likely issued under the authority of Marcus Aurelius.

Unknown originally number of denarii. 5 coins are kept in the History Museum in Bacău: Trajan 1, Antoninus Pius (Faustina I/Diva Faustina I) 1, Marcus Aurelius 2, Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II/Diva Faustina II) 1.
63 denarii found within the ruins of a Roman house: Galba - Antoninus Pius (AD 145-161). The silver link found with the coins may suggest a bag as the container.

Råmosen, the numerically largest denarii hoard in Denmark, was found in 1782. The hoard consists of 428 denarii. There are two lists of coins for the hoard; one lists the end coin as a Marcus Aurelius, but there are contemporary letters mentioning coins with a portrait of Crispina.
92 denarii: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). Found in a ceramic vessel together with a silver bracelet.
Five denarii found together following metal detecting: Hadrian (Sabina) - Commodus (AD 190).
4 denarii: Trajan, Hadrian, Marcus Aurelius, Commodus (Crispina) (AD 178-188); silver weight: 10.25 g.
Around 300 denarii possible found with a leather bag. 134 coins provide information on the issuers: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Krakow (132 coins); private collection, Gnojni (2 coins)

summary: 23 denarii: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (AD 160-161).
disposition: Museum of Dacian and Roman Civilisation, Deva, Romania

summary: Six (or more?) Roman gold coins found on a field. First, three were found by labourers in 1845: Domitian (1 coin) and Hadrian (2 coins). Then came a report that "two years ago" two aurei of Vespasian had been found in the same field, and probably more, thrown out by the labourers as brass items. In 1860 another gold coin found in the same field was reported. - The 3 aurei found in 1845 were described in detail and documented in sealing wax (lost) and later copied in drawings (preserved).
The hoard was found in a void within a Roman wall and comprised 5 sestertii: 1 Hadrian, 1 Antoninus Pius, 2 Marcus Aurelius, 1 Faustina II (AD 147-176).
Two sestertii found together and recorded as a hoard in the HER. The coins could not be closely identified and were returned to the finder as they did not meet the criteria for Treasure.
Hoard of circa 600-700 denarii. 433 pieces were studied: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194).
The hoard comprised between 1,400 and 1,500 'copper' coins from Nero to Antoninus Pius.
10 coins, a finger ring and a fibula in a wooden case with 3 hinges preserved
disposition: Musée communal des Beaux Arts et d'Archéologie de Nivelles

summary: 3200 silver coins found with bronze cauldron: 3197 denarii, 3 drachmas Lycia: Republic - Antoninus Pius (AD 158-161) . 10.8 kg
disposition: Museum ”Dr. Molnár István”, Cristuru Secuiesc, Romania (1965)

summary: 86 denarii: Mark-Antony - Commodus (Crispina) (AD 180-191).
62 denarii: Nero - Hadrian (AD 134-138).

Udmarken on Bornholm has yielded three hoards with a total of 217 denarii. All three, A, B, C, have been interpreted as being of either the same hoard or of chronologically identical hoards. A and B were found a week apart in 1853 and C was found in 1857. Udmarken C contains seven of the 217 denarii.
33 denarii: Republic - Hadrian (AD 125-128)
disposition: County Museum of Bistrița-Năsăud, Bistrița, Romania; Inv.no. MB 20918-20950

summary: Coin hoard consisting of 54 Roman sestertii (Domitian - Commodus) was discovered in 1922 while excavating an old lime tree. The coins were stratified in three layered rolls. They have been lost.
500 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166). TR POT XX IMP IIII COS III
disposition: Okrazen Istoriceski Muzej, Pleven, Bulgaria; circa 250 coins, inv.no. 853 1-128

summary: A hoard of 60 Roman imperial denarii was discovered by a treasure hunter at the end of September 2021: Vespasian – Commodus (AD 180-192). Photos of 45 coins were published on the Ukrainian forum for treasure hunters, Violity. According to the finder, the coins were in a “small pit”, not far from a settlement of the Chernyakhiv culture, on the depth ca. 15-30 cm. At the end of 2021, the coins were sold at the Violity auction.
Unknown originally number of coins. 86 bronze coins: Tiberius - Hadrian (AD 119-120).
disposition: Museo Arqueológico Provincial de Orense, Spain; private collections of M. Taborda and X. Taborda

summary: (8-900) 52 aurei: Domitian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 172-175).
disposition: Collection Rockox (37 coins), in 17th century; collection Van Gestel (1 coin), in 17th century; collection Christine de Suède (non-identifiable)

summary: The hoard comprised 118 sestertii found with a ceramic vessel: Domitian-Commodus (90-183 AD). Most of the coins are kept in a private collection (Antonio Egger).
disposition: Museo Civico di Bassano (26 coins); Museo Bottacin di Padova (6 coins); private collection Egger family (86 coins).

summary: 46 denarii: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 161-169).
310 denarii found with two leather bags placed in a ceramic vessel, ten meters from BIRNIE 1996-2000 hoard: Nero - Pertinax (AD 193).
A small hoard of denarii (6+ specimens, Antoninus Pius - Pertinax), found in or around Apelstedt.
46 bronze coins: 45 sestertii, 1 provincial coin: Trajan - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2287-2326

summary: 21 sestertii, 1 dupondius and 1 AE (copper or brass) found in the neighborhoud of a Roman building next to some clay sources.
80 denarii from Mark Anthony to Marcus Aurelius with a tpq of AD 165.
A hoard of silver and bronze (perhaps also gold) coins. There is only data for two coins of Antoninius Pius.
The hoard comprised 46 tetradrachms dated between AD 60/1 and AD 118.
24 denarii found ina lump of earth: Domitian – Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

Hoard of 126 Roman imperial denarii was discovered by a treasure hunter on the outskirts of Uman in mid-November 2014. Information about the discovery of the treasure and a photo of 53 coins were published on November 16, 2014, on the Ukrainian treasure-hunting forum Violity. The finder reported that the treasure was found on November 13, 2014, in the forest on the outskirts of Uman. The coins were dispersed over a small area, and on the first day of the search, four treasure hunters managed to find 62 coins. On the second day, the search was continued by three treasure hunters, they found an additional 32 coins. On November 18, 2015, the same informant reported that a total of 126 coins had been discovered. The further fate of the coins is unknown.
200 aurei, only 6 were available for study: Galba, Trajan, Hadrian, Marcus Aurelius, Faustina II, Lucius Verus.
Unknown originally number of coins. 34 bronze coins: 21 sestertii, 13 dupondii: Trajan - Antoninus Pius (AD 145-161).
(c. 220) 151 denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 197-198); silver weight: c. 367.1-588.9 g.
Hoard of around 100 denarii from the time of the Antonine dynasty. Only four coins are documented.
The hoard comprised six bronze coins dated between AD 70-81 and AD 117/118. It was deposited inside the hollow part of a door frame in the tepidarium of a Roman bathhouse. Votive role?
11 denarii: Republic - Trajan (AD 105).
8 Roman bronze coins to Antoninus Pius plus 8 Durotrigan cast bronze coins
Two denarii found above ground in 1921, assumed to have derived from a ditch dug at the site.
Hoard discovered on the surface and during the archaeological investigations: Trajan – Septimius Severus (Clodius Albinus Caesar) (AD 193).
disposition: History Museum, Târgu Neamț (23 coins); History Museum, Piatra Neamț (7 coins); private collections (6 coins)

summary: 771 denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 179-180); Septimius Severus coin is an intruder. There were two ceramic vessels buried at 2 m one from the other at the same depth of 0.25 m.
disposition: National Museum of History Bucharest; Museum of History and Archaeology Piatra Neamț (Romania)

summary: The hoard comprised approximately 40 tetradrachms and 150 denarii from the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
5 denarii (Vespasian - Hadrian) found together in Rottweil, in the south of the Roman city (Parzelle 969/3, Firma Mahle).

A hoard of at least 385 Roman imperial denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180) was allegedly discovered in the late 2010s in the vicinity of Ivano-Frankivsk. The hoard contained mostly coins of "early mintages", and the latest ones date back to the time of Antoninus Pius and Marcus Aurelius (10-15 such coins in total). No further information.

A hoard of 86 Roman imperial denarii (from Vespasian to Commodus) was discovered by a treasure hunter in 2015 or 2016. Information about the find and photos of the coins were published on 10 February 2016 on the treasure hunter forum Violity, but without specifying the exact location of the find. However, on May 25, 2017 on the YouTube channel “Poisk klada Alexander & Co” there was information about the location of the find, as well as photos of the coins previously published on Violity. There is no information about the conditions of the hoard discovery. The coins are of average preservation. In February 2016, the hoard was sold in one lot at Violity auction, the further fate of the coins is unknown.
A hoard of 10 aurei (Domitian - Antoninus Pius), found in the 1880s in Trier, in a small earthenware container; it was published in 1928 as part of the collection of Dr. Leopold Seligmann.
Hoard of circa 60 denarii: Nero - Commodus (AD 180-192). Only 18 denarii were documented.
20 denarii: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 191).

A hoard of 2000+ silver coins (mainly Cappadocian didrachms, drachms and hemidrachms; two Lycian drachms; c.100 denarii) deposited c. 185 and found in four bronze pots in the village of Sor, near Kayseri. It was dispersed in several batches in the art trade. A large portion was published by W. Metcalf (932 coins) and another by W. Weiser (178 coins, the 'Münchner Fundkomplex'). In addition, 140 coins were recorded in Paris in 1980 (RPC III, p. 376). They consisted in 26 denarii (Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius), and 114 coins from Caesarea (Vespasian - Commodus)

A hoard of at least 70 Roman Imperial denarii was discovered in 2018 (?) in the vicinity of Fastiv. Information about the hoard on the treasure hunting forum Violity was posted on 16 December 2018, probably by its finder, who also provided one general photo of the deposit. The coins were fused into one large ingot and had traces of heavy exposure to fire. Three coins were found separately. A silver item in the form of a ring-bent bar measuring ca. 2.5x3 cm (possibly a clasp from the pouch in which the treasure was hidden). There were also small fragments of pottery nearby, whose relation to the hoard is not clear. Judging by the photos posted on the forum, the hoard was sold at the Violity auction. The further fate of the deposit is unknown.
The hoard comprised approximately 15-20 tetradrachms and 70-80 denarii from the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
Four asses found during the excavations. To be checked whether were found together.
Three bronze coins in a small vessel: 1 sestertius Trajan, 1 AE Hadrian, 1 AE L. Aelius (AD 137-138).

The hoard comprised several hundred Roman coins (the majority being sestertii) contained in a wooden box. The hoard was found 2 or 300 metres from the conciergerie of the Hypogeum on the left towards the water tower.
Five denarii found together: Vespasian – Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
A hoard of 74 denarii (Republic- Hadrian), found in 1854 approx. 1 km north of the place, 100 m from the street next to Dahnsdorf behind a hill in a ravine.
The hoard comprised 3 Roman Provincial coins: (Cassandrea, Philippi, Koinon of Macedonia), found in grave 589 in Ierissos.
Hoard of 320 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Nerva - Pertinax (AD 193).
Six denarii (Domitian - Hadrian), found in the estuary of the River Weser in 1842.
A large hoard of denarii and a few bronze coins was found during construction works in 1957. Only 139 coins (Vespasian-Marcus Aurelius, 70-180 AD) were recovered but subsequently stolen in 1972-1973.
Around 100 denarii, among them, one of Antoninus Pius for Faustina II. No further details.

"In 1847 a small pot containing 8 Roman coins - a silver denarius of Trajan and 7 bronze coins, including one of Trajan - was found in cutting through a hedge or earth bank on the boundary between the parishes of Upton and Withiel Florey. Two of the coins are in the Spencer G Perceval collection" (Pastscape)
Originally 16 denarii, 15 preserved: Domitian - Septimius Severus(AD 193-211); silver weight: 42.63 g. (15 coins).
Around 200 denarii. Among them issues of Nero, Vitellius, Vespasian, Titus, Domitian, Trajan and Hadrian.

Roman settlement at Rowler Manor Estate first recorded in 1991 during archaeological watching brief, when Roman pottery & two coin hoards were recovered. Later investigation revealed stone building remains & 4th C. mosaic floor. APs suggest this just one of many buildings in much larger complex over 5ha in extent.During work in 1991, 6 sestertii found as small hoard, initially by detectorists. Coins stuck together in a column after probably being kept in a narrow textile wrapping/bag. Coins from Trajan to Lucilla.Guest, P. 2008. The Roman coins. In M. Dawson Excavation of the Roman villa and mosaic at Rowler Manor, Croughton, Northamptonshire. Northamptonshire Archaeol. 35: 45-93. Hoard identified by Curteis 2003.
Hoard found with an amphora: 2 aurei, 2,804 denarii, 2 bronzes: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166). Together was found a ceramic lamp.
disposition: Private collections: A. Ancona,F. Gnecchi (365 coins), M. Anti (1,080 coins) (in 1887)
