summary: Hoard of 177 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 197). Together were found two silver rings and one of gold.
Hoard of 300-400 denarii. Only two coins are documented: Trajan, Antoninus Pius.
21 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
The hoard comprised 4 tetradrachms, at least 20 denarii, and "a large number of bronze" coins of the Bar Kokhba Revolt (AD 132-135/136).
(c. 550) 165 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Nero - Commodus (AD 181-191).
15 AE to AD 195.
Circa 150 denarii. 100 were studied: Hadrian - Pertinax (AD 193).

A Roman coin hoard consisting of 106 denarii (Republic - Commodus) was discovered in 1908 during the renovation of a grinding mill, 2 km south-west of Unterammergau. The hoard was in earthenware jar, that had apparently been placed between rocks. The coins are now lost.
Hoard of denarii dispersed among locals. 88 denarii entered museums' collections. Six denarii can be entered at coin level: Antoninus Pius 1, Lucius Verus 1, Faustina II 3, Commodus 1.
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Warsaw (8 coins), Lublin (60 coins), Poland; Local museum, Lutsk (20 coins), Ukraine.

summary: Hoard of 120 denarii. Among issuers, Trajan and Marcus Aurelius. No further details.
The hoard comprised 77 silver coins dated between 32/31 BC and AD 125-128.
Around 40 silver coins. Only 4 denarii of Antoninus Pius are known.
Hoard of 50 denarii. Only 8 pieces are documented: Antoninus Pius 3, Marcus Aurelius (Antoninus Pius Divus), Commodus 4.
disposition: National Museum of History, Moscow, Russia (inv.nos. 14863, 14865-14869)

summary: 90 sestertii: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194).
Originally were 108 denarii. Nowadays, 80 coins: Otho - Commodus (AD 192); silver weight: 215.80 g. (80 coins). Found in a domestic building with bones fragments and an oval whetstone.

The hoard was discovered in 1993 by Vasily Prigodich (excavator operator), during the digging in a chalk quarry (between the villages of Malyech and Kabaki). The coins were in a hand made pot. In total, the hoard contained 408 (or 409?) coins, but to study preserved only 383 denarii (Vespasian-Septimius Severus) and four barbarian imitations of denarii.
disposition: National Historical Museum of Republic of Belarus

summary: Two denarii: Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus/Divus Lucius Verus) (AD 161-169). Militky considers a misidentification of this hoard with the one Dobřichov-Plaňany (PLAŇANY 1892).
79 denarii found circa 25 m from the Jerzmanowice 2005 hoard and one more denarius found in 2009. Most likely one owner: Hadrian - Septimius Severus (Julia Domna) (AD 193-196).
35 bronze coins: medallions and coins: Nero, Vespasian, Titus, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
14 denarii: Claudius I – Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla) (AD 161-180).
disposition: National museum, Prague, Czech Republic (11 coins)

summary: A hoard of 138 Roman imperial denarii: Galba - Marcus Aurelius (AD 180-161) was discovered by a treasure hunter in 2017 in the Kyiv region. The first information about the hoard and photos of 60 coins were published on the Ukrainian treasure hunting forum Violity on January 6, 2017. Then the treasure hunter went to the hoard findspot nine more times and found a different number of coins: 24 January (2 coins), 25 January (7 coins), 24 February (8 coins), 15 May (1 coin), 12 June (1 coin), 3 August (1 coin), 4 August (19 coins), 14 August (38 coins) and 20 August (1 coin). According to the finder, the deposit was found in the forest, under the trees. In the photograph on forum a small pit in the sandy soil (up to 50 cm deep) located on a slight slope can be seen. A few coins were closer to the surface, the main butch was deeper. The hoard was in a reddish-colored pottery vessel, of which several fragments have survived (according to the finder it was a “pot”, but judging by the photographs it was a pottery bowl). The coins are in very good condition (minimal wear). The coins were sold one by one at the Violity auction.
11 denarii found with a cooking pot: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 134-135)
6 denarii found on the construction site: Vitellius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166).
Circa 500 denarii, of which 264 were brought after 1873 to the National Hungarian Museum in Budapest. 168 coins were identified: Nero – Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) (AD 141-161).

A hoard of 19 provincial coins, found in grave T7 in the roman cemetery excavated at Strovolos. The coins are not described, but ill. pl. 18-19. They comprised 3 pseudo-autonomous coins of Thessalonica, 15 coins of Amphipolis from the Antonine period and 1 that remains to be identified.
5 denarii: Trajan - Antoninus Pius (AD 145-161) found during excavations.
disposition: Muzeul Dunării de Jos, Călărași, Romania; inv.nos. 46511-46514, 46518

summary: Unknown originally number of denaarii found with a ceramic vessel. Only 10 coins were recovered. Among issuers: Augustus, Tiberius, Nero, Antoninus Pius, Commodus and other emeperors.
100 coins of which one bronze coin of Marcus Aurelius/Commodus for Crispina (Augusta) (AD 178-183).
disposition: Private collection and museum Eindhoven, Netherlands

summary: 726 denarii: Nero - Commodus (AD 187-192).
Unknown originally number of coins. Circa 200 sestertii were seen From Flavians to Septimius Severus (AD 197). Only 29 were available for study.

Hoard of 36 coins (31 bronze and 6 silver) "from 76 BC to AD 180 or 270" found during Pitt Rivers' excavations at the settlement site of Woodcutts, Sixpenny Handley. Said to have been found with the remains of a bronze-mounted casket near a hearth, possibly within a house."... the discovery here, within an oblong area of ' depression ' and near a hearth, of the remains of a bronze-mounted ornamental casket, with glass, a silver spoon, a penannular brooch, etc., and 31 bronze and 6 silver coins, from Claudius I to Claudius II (268-70)". (Hawkes, C.F.C. 1947, 'Britons, Romans, and Saxons Round Salisbury and in Cranborne Chase: reviewing the excavations of General Pitt-Rivers, 1881-1898' Archaeological Journal 104, p.46).
The hoard was found in an ancient vessel and comprised between 500 and 600 bronze coins. Very close by, a large glass urn, pottery and three bronze basins were also found.
Hoard of circa 700 denarii. Only 350 pieces are known: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195).
7 bronze coins: 2 dupondii, 5 asses: Claudius I - Trajan (AD 101-102)
(52) 49 denarii found with a ceramic vessel of Carpic manufacture: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) (post AD 141).
12 bronze coins found stuck together, in a barrow: 5 dupondii, 7 asses: Hadrian - Antoninus Pius (AD 160-161).
disposition: National History and Archaeology Museum, Constanța, Romania (inv.nos. 81602-81613)

summary: 76 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Otho - Marcus Aurelius (AD 179).
6 sestertii: Domitian - Antoninus Pius/Marcus Aurelius for Faustina II (AD 145-175).

The hoard was found buried under a small heap of stones and comprised 22 bronze coins. Of these coins, 11 were identified as dupondii or asses of particular emperors. The others were not identified with any certainty, but were 'more or less recognisable' as issues of Vespasian or Titus, Domitian, Trajan and Hadrian.
It comprised c. 500 denarii found with a vessel:Domitian - Commodus (AD 180-192).

Eighteen Roman sestertii found close together by a metal detector user in the municipality of Gulpen-Wittem (in an area of ca. 1 m2). Two additional Roman coins (an as/dupondius and a coin of unknown denomination) were found within a ten-meter radius and can be part of the same hoard but certainty is lacking. The coins were reported in 2018.
255 denarii found and sent to the Ministry of Finance. The coins were found with pieces of an urn during the removal of stones from a field.

168 Alexandrian provincial bronze coins: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (AD 148-149). Found in the ground. All drachms, only briefly described. Oldest Vespasian, among the other coins are mentioned "interesting types of Antinous, Sabina, Aurelius Caesar, also some of the rare 'nome' types and few of the famous zodiacal series struck in the eighth year of Antoninus Pius."

1590 bronze coins (1452 Dium, 47 koinon of Thessaly, 39 koinon of Macedonia, 13 Thessalonica, 7 Philippi, 2 Edessa, 2 Corinth, 1 Amphipolis, 1 Magydus, 1 Tralleis, 10 uncertain, and 15 Roman bronzes), ranging from Claudius to Antoninus Pius, found in the foundation level besides the west wall of the first (western) room excavated at the place of the former sanctuary of Zeus Olympios, next to two other hoards (Dion 1998 and Dion 2000). All three hoards were buried in clay vases. The exact function of the area where the hoards were found is unclear, but the hellenistic sanctuary of Zeus Olympios had been transformed in Roman times, the wall of the temenos built over, and a theatre established.
181 denarii found in the foundations of a prehistoric house: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 197-198); silver weight: 491.23 g. Found together with sherds and animal bones.

A hoard of denarii, found in an earthenware container, together with three silver bracelets, during the construction of the road from Kindelbrück to Weißensee, under an area of arable land. The content of the hoard was dispersed, but it could have amounted to more than 230 denarii.
A hoard of ca. 300 denarii, found in 1842, during peat digging, close to the so-called 'Römerbrücke' in the Bourtanger Moor. The coins are now lost, except for two.
Grup of two denarii: Antoninus Pius, Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I); silver weight: 5.32 g.
During the excavation of the Sanctuary in Insula 20 of Colonia Ulpia Traiana, 6 coins were found deposited under wall plaster. The latest coins date to the period AD 103 to 111.
Unknown number of denarii. Only two of them are known: Hadrian, Marcus Aurelius for Lucilla (AD 161-180).

HER record of a hoard of 32 Roman copper coins, "chiefly of the Middle Empire" found in 1772 at North End in Turville. Eight of the coins were said in 1797 to be in the possession of Col Innes of Ibstone House, of which there were 2 of Antoninus Pius, 2 "Faustinas", 2 "Vespasians", 1 Trajan and 1 "Aurelius". Source: Thomas Langley 1797 "History and Antiquities of the Hundred of Desborough" p.383.

A hoard of at least 105, possibly up to 115, denarii found at the end of December 1930, of which only 105 are still identified in the records of Rabat Museum. Chatelain, the original excavator, listed 114 coins in the find, including two coins of Juba II, one of Nero, one of Galba, nineteen of Vespasian, seven of Titus, twenty-three of Domitian, three of Nerva, forty-eight of Trajan and ten of Hadrian. However it is clear that Chatelain misidentified two of the Republican denarii as coins of Juba II. The next publication of the hoard, by Ruhlmann, came in 1933. This list largely agrees with the records kept by Rabat Museum, but includes ten extra coins, taking the total up to 115, which must now be regarded as lost. The missing coins listed by Ruhlmann are as follows: one Republican denarius, one denarius of Vespasian, two denarii of Domitian, five denarii of Trajan and one Hadrianic denarius. There are no further details concerning the types of these coins, because Ruhlmann only published in detail the nine latest specimens from the find. The whole hoard was contained in a hollow bracelet and was probably buried circa 122.
23 denarii: Republic (L. Thorius Balbus) - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
The sculptor Zanda of Desulo discovered a deposit of Roman bronze coins, near the church of San Pietro. One of them belongs to Faustina I and one to Lucilla.
76 denarii: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 134-138).
disposition: Collection Baron of Senzeilles (76 coins), in 1890

summary: Four denarii (Vespasian - Trajan), allegedly found in 1845 in or around Minden. It is not impossible that these belonged to the Minden I find, made in 1844.
The hoard was found in a broken ceramic vessel. It comprised approximately 150 'large bronzes' likely to be sestertii. The hoard was discovered by a farm labourer on the plain of Saint-Rémy.
324 denarii: M. Antony - M. Aurelius (AD 166-167)
The hoard comprised a few tetradrachms and approximately 50 denarii from the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
Hoard of 37 coins: 6 republican denarii, 1 imperial denarius, 25 sestertii, 1 dupondius, 4 asses: Republic - Antoninus Pius (AD 157-161).
The hoard comprised 2 aurei from Antoninus and Faustina II and 5 denarii from Trajan, Antoninus, Faustina I, Faustina II and Lucilla. It's probably a part of hoard.
The hoard comprises a small greyware vessel containing 12 denarii of one of the Faustinas.
Two denarii: Antoninus I (Faustina I), Marcus Aurelius.

Over 112 denarii found on the top soil scattered. Only 8 coins could be described: Vespasian, Trajan (Marciana), Hadrian (Sabina), Hadrian (Aelius), Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla), Commodus, Commodus (Crispina), Spetimius Severus (AD 194). Circa 25 m from Jerzmanowice 2006 hoard. Most likely one owner.

The hoard comprised 12 aes coins (sestertii and dupondii) ranging from Domitian to Marcus Aurelius Caesar. They were recovered during the excavation of a inhumation burial (tomb 5/1966) in the necropolis and were interpreted as the contents of a purse.
disposition: Ufficio dei beni culturali, Bellinzona (12 coins)

summary: 9 denarii and 2 aes (Mark Antony to Antoninus Pius) found in Room 28.
47 denarii. Only 5 coins are kept in the Museum of Assen: Hadrian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 176)
141 denarii: Republic – Commodus (AD 180-192).

73 denarii (Vespasian to Commodus) found beneath a millstone by workmen removing "a quantity of loose stones and earth" near a lime kiln in a quarry. A pair of spurs was reportedly found at the same time. RCAHMW states that the precise location of the find is unknown "but there is apparently only one lime kiln on the estate" in a place still known as Limekiln Covert.
disposition: In the collection of T Assheton Smith Esq. M.P. (1849)

summary: 15 sestertii as a foundation offering: Trajan - Commodus (AD 190-191).
14 silver and bronze coins of unknown denominations: Republic - Antoninus Pius/Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II) (AD 145-176).
Originally 312 denarii, 299 preserved: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194); silver weight: 758.24 g. (299 coins).
Six coins found while extracting stone: Antoninus Pius 2, Faustina I 1, Commodus, 1 uncertain. No further information.
Hoard of 282 coins: 252 denarii, 1 quinarius, 29 bronzes: Augustus - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
237 coins: 11 denarii, 226 bronzes (most of them sestertii): Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
In 1934, 40 denarii and 12 sestertii were found with an urn in a field north of Narcott Lane. The coins range from Vespasian to Antoninus Pius.
1,776 denarii (5.5 kg): Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211). Most likely were kept in a wooden box, as eight silver rivets "have been discovered at the site".
The hoard was discovered after 1863 in the rubble from the excavation of the bathhouse. It comprises 21 aurei, ranging from Nero to Trajan.
Two aurei were found on the banks of the Paleru river.
Over 100 silver and bronze coins. 80 pieces were recovered: 1 denarius, 67 sestertii, 12 dupondii, 1 As: Vespasianus - Hadrian (AD 134-138).

6 denarii and 1 AE coin, ranging from Domitian to Commodus, found in cellar 207 between 1897 and 1908. These 7 coins of this find were not identified according to inventory number or type and could thus not be separated out from the list of single finds.

A hoard of at least 259 Roman imperial denarii was found by treasure hunters in 2016 in Cherkasy region. On October 4, 2016, a video of the process of sondage at the site where the hoard was found by seven treasure hunters was published on YouTube, on the “Sokrovische nacii” (“Treasure of the Nation”) channel. A few days earlier, another group of treasure hunters found a batch of denarii - 192 specimens - on the surface (up to 15 cm deep in an area of about 10x10 m) of a ploughed field. Then, on October 4, on this place was made several sondages (approx. 2-3x1 m), in which, at a depth of 40-50 cm was found another 67 coins (each of the seven treasure hunters took as many coins as they found). According to the assumption of one of the treasure hunters there may be more coins at this place. The video footage shows coins with traces of patina, among which can be distinguished denarii of Hadrian (incl. for Sabina), Antoninus Pius (incl. for Faustina I), Marcus Aurelius (incl. for Faustina II), Commodus. The further fate of the coins is unknown.
Three Roman bronze coins (Trajan - Marcus Aurelius Caesar) were found together in a field, inside an old foundation wall.
In 1867 west of Gräpel on the right bank of the Oste river coins were found 2 ft deep during the removal of sand from a ridge of hills. The find totals ca. 350+ denarii (Augustus? - Commodus).
27 bronze coins (Tiberius - Marcus Aurelius) found in an ash layer covered by a stone and interpreted as a votive deposit.

After the war in a building excavation pit, 30 Roman denarii (Galba to Lucilla) were found in an amber-glazed jar from the sixteenth century, wrapped individually in a linen cloth. It is likely that a Roman hoard was unearthed in the Renaissance, and has now been found for the second time.

The hoard comprised 13 denarii from Mark Antony to Septimius Severus. They were found concealed in the belt of male burial interpreted as being that of a Roman soldier. The burial was found in the courtyard of a building situated at No. 12 rue des Fantasques
A hoard of five bronze coins (Philippi, Koinon of Macedonia, Topirus), found in grave T2 in Lithochori.
10 denarii: Trajan – Marcus Aurelius (AD 162).
disposition: NPÚ-ÚOP Pardubice, Náchod Castle collection, Czech Republic (inv.nos. 2.920, 3.016-3.023).

summary: A hoard of 150 denarii found in a ceramic vessel, covered by another ceramic vessel: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 193).
(circa 400) 22 denarii: 2 republican, 20 imperial: Republic - Trajan (AD 105-107)

5 bronze coins (Hadrian - Marcus Aurelius), found dispersed across the excavation area. It is possible that an Augustan as (RIC 436) also belonged to this hoard. One interpretation is that these coins could have belonged to a small 'hoard' (or purse) that was later scattered across the site, though admittedly there is no sign of other artefacts being moved around the site.
101 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Vitellius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 175).
64 denarii found in a wall of a glass workshop: Nerva - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
918 silver coins found with a ceramic vessel: 916 denarii, 1 drachm, 1mitation denarius: Nero – Septimius Severus (AD 193-194).
A hoard of 138 denarii (Galba - Hadrian), found at Sleddle Mouth, Mallerstang Edge, concealed in a hole in the ground and covered by a flat stone.
disposition: Carlisle Museum and Art Gallery (part); British Museum (part)

summary: A hoard of about 20-25 Roman imperial denarii: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180) was discovered by treasure hunter in the late 2010s between the villages of Pysarivka and Hrushkivtsi in the Vinnytsia region. The coins were found on an area of ca. 20x20 m and all had the same traces of bronze oxides. The finder did not provide a photo of the coins, but said that among the coins were denarii of Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Faustina (I or II?), Marcus Aurelius (including those with the rank of Caesar). The further fate of the coins is unknown.
A hoard of 20 denarii (Vitellius - Marcus Aurelius), found in a Roman house, in a room next to the furnace of the hypocaust.
6 bronze coins: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).

97 coins: 1 denarius and 96 bronzes found concentrated around an earthenware dish within a level of a building: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166-167). The coins were found together with a brooch, as well as several pieces of pottery and nails.
The hoard was discovered in 2013 within the boundaries of Vaukavyski County. Consisted of at least 140 denarii (Nerva-Commodus). The circumstances and exact location of the find are unknown.
Only 4 sestertii are known: Hadrian - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
3 denarii (Antoninus Pius, 2 Marcus Aurelius Caesar) (AD 145-160).
Possible hoard of Roman denarii. Only two coins are known, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius.
disposition: History Museum, Riga, Latvia (entered in 1928) (inv. no. 120210/1-2)

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. 28 denarii are known: Antoninus Pius – Commodus (AD 190-191).

A hoard of 178 Roman denarii, ranging from Marc Antony to Hadrian, found at the bottom of an earthenware jar in 1934, in a field south of Louth, Lincolnshire. Among the coins, one hybrid of Domitian with a reverse of Hadrian (now in the BM).
disposition: Lincoln City and County Museum (part); British Museum (part)

summary: The hoard comprised 44 coins dated between the 4th-3rd century BCE and the reign of Hadrian (AD 117-138).
95 sestertii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 195).
The hoard comprised 5 drachms of Trajan minted in Bostra (AD 113).
The hoard comprised 16 coins with the denominations not given. The hoard was found on the Barre farm, while making repairs to the farmyard.
Unknown number of denarii. 5 pieces entered the museum collection in Kazanlak: Domitian 1, Trajan 4.
disposition: Museum of History, Kazanlak, Bulgaria; inv.no. 3994-3998

find_spot_name: VILLA DE LA FUENTE DE LAS PULGUINAS
summary: Five bronze coins found one next to the other: as Republic, 3 asses Hadrian, 1 dupondius Antoninus Pius.
The hoard comprised 17 silver coins (Vespasian-Hadrian) and 43 bronze coins.

The hoard was discovered in 1850 by a private person during a search quarry stones. The coins lay concealed without a discernible container in the wall aperture of a Roman cellar (Quintan- obere prätorische Straße)). The hoard is thought to have comprised 360-370 denarii. 280 of them are now in the collection of antiquities from Nassau, in Wiesbaden. Coins range from Nero to Antoninus Pius.
A hoard of 5 denarii (Vitellius - Lucilla), found while digging peat not far from Nauen. A connection with the hoard of BUCHOW-KARPZOW (ID 17335) has been postulated.

Arm purse containing 63 coins (3 aurei and 60 denarii), ranging from the late Republic to Hadrian, found while quarrying stones. Each of the gold coins was wrapped up in a separate piece of greenish leather or vellum, which was still quite tough and strong.
disposition: Clayton Memorial Museum, Chesters (purse). The coins are said to have been given to the Blackgate Museum, Newcastle, but have not been located there

summary: Four coins on PAS database centered to village - possibly a hoard or addenda to one of the previous hoards?Other PAS records associated with this hoard: CAM-531F17
Two aurei depicting Lucius Verus (AD 161-169). No description. Callu-Loriot record these coins as single finds, however, same findspot, same coin issuer (quite rare).
669 denarii found with a ceramic vessel near a Carpic settlement: Republic – Marcus Aurelius (AD 166-167).

The hoard comprised 4 coins including one earlier coin of Thasos (2nd c. BC) and two Roman Provincial coins: Philippoi (1 imperial period), Topeiros (1 Antoninus Pius) and a further 1 unidentified coin, found in grave T11 in Lithochori.
Unknown original number of coins. 15 pieces are known: 14 denarii, 1 dupondius: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Museum of Moravia, Brno, Czech Republic (7 coins); Collection Červinkova (8 coins)

summary: The find comprised 65 coins of Hadrian and Antoninus Pius, 7 copper-alloy figurines, a stone figurine of Sucellus, some copper-alloy and glass plates, a scythe, some knives, an amphora, moulded glazed cups, bells, an incense burner, a triangular stone pediment and some carbonised cereals.

Four gold coins found in a stone sarcophagus during excavations: Vespasian, Titus, Hadrian 2. Together were found four denarii: Augustus, Trajan, Hadrian, Faustina I. Together were found gold and silver jewellery, vessels, glass objects.
2 denarii of Hadrian (AD 117-138).

Hoard of 34 bronze sstaters of an autonomous (Agrippia) city and Bosporan kings: Aspurgus, Gepaepyris, Rhescuporis II, Sauromates I, Cotys II, Sauromates II and one issue of the mint of Agrippia Caesarea (Phanagoria).
disposition: Museum of Anapa, Russia (labelled as the "Gunyaevsky Hoard"; inv.nos. AM 10750/1-34)

summary: A hoard of an unknown number of coins. Only three coins entered a museum collection: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius. Another denarius of Nerva comes from the same place, most likely part of the hoard
22 denarii found on a cultivated field: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 174).
disposition: Gabinet Numizmatyczno-Sfragistyczny, Zakład Narodowy im. Ossolińskich, Wrocław, Poland

summary: Two denarii found on a field by chance: Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius for Antoninus Pius (Divus).
(2820) 2819 denarii: Republic - Septimius Severus (AD 205).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Ruse, Bulgaria; in.no. 1867

summary: A hoard of ca. 850 Alexandrian tetradrachms (Nero to Antoninus Pius) found at Amheida (Dakhla/Dakhleh oasis) in area 4, divided in three textile bags, on top of a mudbrick debris layer filling pit F90, immedialely adjacent to the temple of Thoth.
22 bronze coins found together: Obol, prutahs, local, provincial issues: Ptolemy VIII Physcon - Antoninus Pius (AD 158-159).

3,997 bronze coins recovered from a shipwreck on the bottom of the Garonne river. The coins were recovered in two stages: 939 in 1965, 3,058 in 1970. In total: 3,663 sestertii, 270 dupondii, 33 asses, 31 dupondii/asses: Claudius I - Antoninus Pius (159-161).
1,268 coins: 7 aurei, 1,261 denarii: Republic - Hadrian (AD 136-138). Total weight: 4,023.93g.
disposition: Historischen Museum der Stadt Wien (Karlsplatz), Austria

summary: 7 coins found at 30 cm deep: 2 sestertii, 5 asses: Augustus - Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla) (AD 161-180).
115 denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194); silver weight: 354 g
120 denarii. 32 were donated to the History Museum in Silistra: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
16 aurei: Vespasian - Trajan (AD 107-110).
645 Alexandrian tetradrachms: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166-167) purchased by Currelly and Frost from "native diggers".

A hoard of 49 denarii (Mark Antony - Commodus, including a Lycian drachm of Trajan), found while digging for peat in the vicinity of Dellstedt (Nordermoor). The coins were found in a cavity, reflecting the size of the original container (leather bag or wooden box). Eight coins have been lost.
The hoard comprised around 500 tetradrachms and at least 2000 denarii from the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
Unknown originally number of coins. 43 denarii are kept at the town museum in Piatra Neamț, Romania: Republic – Antoninus Pius (AD 147-148).
disposition: Town museum, Piatra Neamț, Romania (43 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 65 bronze coins dated between 294-283 BC and AD 117-138.
(50-60) 13 bronze coins: 12 sestertii, 1 dupondius: Domitian - Antoninus Pius (AD 153-155).
disposition: Collection J. De Bast (13 coins), in 1808

summary: 50 denarii: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). No information about circumstances.
8 aurei: Nero - Antoninus Pius: M. Aurelius (Caesar) (AD 140-161)
(62) 10 denarii of Tajan (AD 112-114)
Hoard of 200 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. Two denarii are documented: Faustina II, Commodus.
2 denarii - Antoninus Pius for Diva Faustina I and Marcus Aurelius found together with 4 gold bracteates.

A hoard of ca. 460 Roman silver denarii (Nero - Marcus Aurelius for 344 of them, the others are lost), found in an earthenware container 1 1/2 feet under the soil while removing stones ('Steineroden') in the heather, at Wassermühle on the Wingstberg.
800 denarii. 274 pieces were studied by V. Haralanov: Nero - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
Found during excavations, in an early medieval cemetery. Tomb 569B: inhumation, male; among grave goods 3 (?) Aes coins, part of the "Tascheninhalt".
50 denarii found in a ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
4 sestertii: 2 Marcus Aurelius, 2 Lucilla. Identification based on a picture. (Lang 2007, 257, fig. 153); weight, c. 80 g.
Large hoard of Roman denarii found in two ceramic vessels. Only 3 have provided some information on the issuers: Trajan 2, Antoninus Pius (Marcus Aurelius caesar) 1.
The hoard comprised approximately 46 tetradrachms and 200-350 denarii of the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136).
disposition: L. Hamburger (British Museum); Montagu Collection; J. Evans; Kelsey Museum of Archaeology in Ann Arbor, Michigan; Detroit Institute of Arts

summary: 12 denari: Vespasian - Trajan (AD 114-117).
A hoard of 257 denarii: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 175-176).
disposition: Museum, Dortmund (243 coins); the Ruhr Valley Museum in Schwerte and Fröndenberg (14 coins)

summary: 70 coins: 35 sestertii, 27 dupondii, 8 asses hidden in the wall of a Roman building: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 168).
Around 800 denarii, among them issues of Trajan, Hadrian and Marcus Aurelius.
Unknown number of coins. 46 coins of Nerva and 31 of Hadrian were in possession of the antiquarian Fornier.

The hoard was found in a well. It contained 57 aurei including issues of Nero, Vespasian, Trajan, Hadrian, Sabina, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius and Faustina). The coins were accompanied by 3 ceramic vessels, fragments of fineware pottery, 4 terracotta models in the form of portrait busts and a further figurine in the form of a miniature goddess in a biga.
Circa 150 bronze coins. Only 2 sestertii and 2 dupondii of Antoninus Pius and Marcus Aurelius were seen.
(1006) 978 denarii: Vitellius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 177).
Unknown originally number of coins. 26 denarii are known at the moment: Nero – Marcus Aurelius (AD 169-170).
15 sestertii found in a grave with ceramic objects: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
70 imperial bronze coins of poor state of conservation. Among them, issues of Antoninus Pius 12, Faustina I 1.
Around 400 denarii of the 1st-2nd centuries AD. 153 provided information on the issuers: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Tsarist Archaeological Comission, St. Petersburg, Russia (153 coins)

summary: Three coins found together by a detectorist and recorded by M. Lyne. Details from HER.
Coins found in sarcophagus no. 905: 34 gold and silver coins: 3 Aurei: Nero 2, Hadrian 1; 14 denarii: Augustus 12,Uncertain (Augustus?) 2; 1 hemidrachm of Hadrian, and 16 drachms of Gotarzes II.
126 bronze coins: 88 sestertii, 9 dupondii, 8 asses, 1 provincial coin; 20 bronze coins unknown denomination: Augustus - Antoninus Pius (AD 154-161).
disposition: Hungarian National Museum, Budapest, Hungary (1897); inventory list no. 460/1896

summary: c. 300 sestertii from Hadrian to Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). No further information about composition of hoard.
disposition: Archaeological Museum Zagreb, Croatia; dispersed; Ervin Meixner coll.

summary: Around 700 denarii found with a ceramic vessel, of which 167 provided information on the issuers: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) (AD 161-169).
disposition: Museum of History, Lwow, Poland; private collection

summary: Group of 3 Roman coins: Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) 1 denarius, 1 sestertius, Marcus Aurelius (Diva Faustina II) dupondius (AD 161-180).
Around 200 denarii of which only 8 have provided information on the issuers: Vespasian 1, Trajan 3, Hadrian 2, Antoninus Pius 2.
14 copper coins, reported as dated between possibly 69 and 117 AD, but inter alia Vespasian, Domitian, Hadrian, so 69-138 in any case.
The hoard comprised 35 aurei (Nero-Lucius Verus) and 29 silver coins (Nero-Trajan).
It comprised 210 sestertii found with a ceramic vessel, notably from Hadrian, Antoninus Pius and one of the Faustinas.
20 bronze coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only eight pieces were recovered: 2 sestertii, 3 dupondii, 3 asses: Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Museum History and Archaeology, Constanța, Romania

summary: 368 aurei: Nero to Marcus Aurelius (AD 166).
11 denarii: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2206

summary: The hoard comprised 8 bronze coins of the Second Jewish Revolt (AD 132-136) found with traces of a leather bag.
103 denari: Vitellius - Septimius Severus (AD 197-198); silver weight: 262.8-420.7 g.
disposition: History Museum, Razgrad, Bulgaria; inv.no. IF, hoard 12 (103 coins).

summary: Unknown number of Roman denarii, only 3 coins are known: Trajan 2, Hadrian.
disposition: Collection of Antonín Hofmeister (an archivist, 1945), Josefov, now missing.

summary: 204 aurei found with a ceramic vessel, 97 pieces studied: Nerva - Commodus.
13 coins (10 provincial coins of Philippi, 2 denarii of Trajan and 1 imperial bronze of Domitian) found in grave T45 in the eastern cemetery of Philippi.
16 sestertii: Trajan 13, Hadrian 3 (AD 121-122).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 13625-13640

summary: Several hundred denarii found with an iron jar. Only six provided data on the issuers: Hadrian - Commodus.
Unknown originally number of coins. 50 denarii were sent to the Sankt Petersburg. Among issuers: Vespasiaen, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Faustina I, Commodus (AD 180-192).
Large number of silver coins found with a ceramic vessel. The minting period run from 91 BC to AD 254. Only 69 coins are preserved: 1 aureus, 66 denarii, 2 drachms: Republic to Hadrian (AD 119-122).
Hoard of sestertii found while dredging the harbor: Hadrian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 177-178).

Four denarii, pressumably belonging to a hoard, found at the same place at different dates. ”The scientific literature has falsely perpetuated the locality of Mircești (situated 5 km to the west) as the place of origin for the coins.”
36 sestertii, but only 16 are identified: Trajan - Commodus (AD 180-183).

A Roman arm purse was found on a field, southwest of Hahn (today in the district of Pfungstadt), in the vicinity of the Hofgut Grabenbruch. The purse contained 8 Roman denarii, ranging from Galba to Trajan.
Initially, there were 1,500 aurei. 144 aurei studied: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-162). Together were found one gold and two silver ingots.
The hoard comprised 514 imperial bronze coins: Nero-Septimius Severus (AD 193-196).
disposition: Museo Archeologico Nazionale di Altino, Italy; private collection; some lost

summary: Three denarii of Hadrian, found around 1896 on the Debra, a plateau approx. 1.5 km northeast of Rudolstadt, near Debrahof, on Rudolstadt-Teichweiden road; the coins could form part of a larger hoard of denarii.
(200) 41 sestertii: Domitian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180)
disposition: Musées royaux des Beaux-Arts de Belgique (41 coins)

summary: Hoard of 375 denarii. Only 7 coins were mentioned: Antoninus Pius, Faustina I, Faustina II 3, Lucilla, Commode.
(260) 257 denarii found in a ceramic vessel: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
Two medallions (Hadrian, Commodus) were found with a vessel. Together were seven bronze tintinnabula, one patera, and two iron objects.
In 1937 a small hoard of 9 sestertii (Trajan - Commodus) was found in the north of Faimingen in the foundation walls of a Roman building, between the Roman road and the contemporary road.
8 bronze coins: 5 sestertii, 1 dupondius, 1 as, 1 AE: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
Unknown originally number of denarii. 8 coins are kept in the History Museum in Iași: Domitian 1, Trajan 1, Hadrian 2, Antoninus Pius 3, Marcus Aurelius (Divus Antoninus Pius) 1.
disposition: History Museum of Moldova, Iași, Romania (inv.nos. 680, 714/9, 744, 768, 774, 779)

summary: 64 denarii from Vespasian to Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).

453 denarii from Nero to Commodus (AD 180). The latest coin has the reversed inscription as: TR P V IMP IIII COS II P P. The composition of the hoard is described by D. Tacchella (1896) by of number types not by the number of coins (!). There are 224 types: Nero 1, galba 1, Vitellius 1, Vespasian 21, Titus 4, Domitian 9, Nerva 4, Trajan 13, Hadrian 34, Sabina 2, Antoninus Pius 54, Faustina I 23, Marcus Aurelius 30, Faustina II 12, Lucius Verus 6, Lucilla 5, Commodus 1, Crispina 1.
disposition: Some of the coins entered the National Museum in Sofia in 1895.

summary: A hoard of sestertii of which 4 pieces are known: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Faustina II and Lucilla.

100 denarii found in June 2008 (Oswestry Area I), followed by a further 23 denarii found in September 2008 (Oswestry Area II), both up to Marcus Aurelius. These were regarded as two separate groups, even if the date range is similar.
31 denarii found in a silo at the site of the Cherniakyv Culture: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192). Together were found two silver loops.
disposition: Institute of Archaeology of the Academy of Sciences, Kyiv, Ukraine (11 coins, 1 loop); School museum, Davydovka, Ukraine

summary: The hoard was found in a ceramic vessel and comprised 722 'bronzes'. It has been suggested that they were sestertii dating from the reign of Hadrian to Commodus. Found close to the brickworks.

In 1806, on the south-west side of Trinity Court, near the Turnpike Road, a hoard of nearly one hundred Roman coins was found. 79 of them were listed, ranging from the Republican period to Trajan. A few days after, a medal of Nero, and one of Antoninus Pius were found on the same spot. The Republican coins were certainly silver, but the metal of the others is uncertain.
Originally, 1,500 denarii and a drachm found with a clay vessel. 1,391 coins preserved: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 193-194); silver weight: 3,924.6 g. (1.391 coins).

28 bronze coins found near a skeleton: 27 provincial coins minted on Cyprus (uncertain mint under Augustus and Tiberius; Koinon of Cyprus for Claudius, Vespasian, and Trajan) and 1 sestertius of Trajan (AD 114-117).
38 bronze coins found in a small sewer found as one block: Vespasian - Commodus (AD
Originally, 78 denarii, 14 preserved: Antoninus Pius - Commodus (AD 189); silver weight: 36.63 g. (14 coins).
36 denarii found in the military amphitheater: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 166).
disposition: Museum Carnuntinum, Bad-Deutsch Altenburg, Austria (29 coins); 7 coins lost

summary: 5 denarii from Vespasian (Domitian) to Antoninus Pius (M. Aurelius). Part of a larger hoard, details unknown.
Unknown originally number of coins. Most likely there is just one hoard found here and 36 denarii are known: Vespasian – Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).

The hoard was found in a grave in the Gallo-Roman cemetery. A red ceramic urn was discovered, alongside a small bronze box containing a gold finger ring with glass setting and three aurei of Nero, Domitian and Antoninus Pius. It is not altogether clear whether the coins were found in the box or the urn.
12 bronze coins: 11 sestertii, 1 dupondius/as found stuch together in a layer of fire: Nero - Hadrian (AD 129-130).
Unknown initial number of coins. 183 denarii: Nero - Pescennius Niger (AD 193-194).
Group of 3 denarii: Nerva, Trajan, Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
Six aurei Possible part of a larger hoard.
62 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Claudius I - Hadrian (AD 127-128)
Originally, 47 coins. 33 denarii were described: Vitellius - Trajan (AD 103-111).
Denarius hoard consisting of 17 denarii. Vespasian to Commodus.
55 denarii found with a ceramic jar: Galba - Commodus (AD 189). Found one meter from STARYIE VALKY 2013 2, practically, one hoard.
Around 50 bronze coins were found in a money-box. Only 13 coins were recovered: 5 sestertii, 6 dupondii, 2 asses: Trajan - Antoninus Pius (AD 145-161) are kept in the National Museum in Ljubljana.
disposition: Narodni muzej, Numizmatični cabinet, Ljubljana, Slovenia (13 coins), inv.no.: 4584-4591; dispersed

summary: 16 coins: 1 denarius, 15 bronzes were found as "cast bronze core" of 570g.
A hoard of 121 denarii (Nero - Marcus Aurelius), found at the edge of the gravel pit northeast of Schwepnitz, approx. 0.3 km east of the Schwepnitz - Gottschdorf road.
Hoard of 23 denarii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 188-189); silver weight: 52.27 g.
(c. 3 kg, c. 900 coins) 196 denarii: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
157 denarii were found but details were only provided for 37 coins: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 117-138)
disposition: Archaeological Museum in Zagreb (37 coins); dispersed

summary: Five denarii (Vespasian - Commodus Caesar), found together on the premises of the Pipinsburg (a megalithic hillfort of Viking times), close to Sievern.
A small hoard of dupondii and asses was found during the excavation of Tomb 68 in excavations of the site: Nero - Hadrian (AD 117-138).
Hughenden - Upon Piggott Common: 24 Roman coins (copper) discovered 1795 in throwing up a bankan earthen vessel about 18 inches below the surface.
A find of 8 coins of Faustina II, made in the area of Panagia Vrontou in Salamina.

A hoard of 291 Roman imperial denarii: Hadrian – Commodus (AD 180-192) and their imitations was found by two treasure hunters in early June 2016 in the Kyiv region. Information about the find and photos of the coins were published by one of the finders on the Ukrainian treasure hunting forum Violity on June 21, 2016. The finder reported that the coins were collected from an area of 3 square meters. The first coins were found at a depth of 10-20 cm, although the pit for their search was dug about 1 m deep. Some coins have traces of bronze oxides. In general, the preservation of coins is good (weak wear). In August 2016, the entire hoard was sold at a Violity auction. The further fate of the coins is unknown.

Date of discovery is date of publication, so might be one year earlier. Uncertain number of bronze Tiberius and Marcus Aurelius coins, thus at least 2, found during dike reconstruction found together with glass, bronze objects, terra sigillata, jars, urns and rough earthenware. A bronze purse in the shape of a boat was found in or around 1939 in the same village and might be connected
Around 100 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. Only 29 coins were recovered and sherds from the vessel: Vespasian – Commodus (Divus Marcus Aurelius ) (AD 180).
30 denarii: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180), latest coin, AD 156-157.
disposition: Rijksmuseum van Oudheden Leiden, Netherlands; inv.no. 17379

summary: 180 coins ending with issues of Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180). Trajan was the other issuer recognized among the coins of this hoard.
105 denarii: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
110 denarii. Only 79 were recovered: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193); silver weight: 202.4-323.4 g.

Iron Age British silver and copper-alloy coins, Roman Republican silver denarii, Roman imperial denarii, Roman copper-alloy coins, totalling 465 specimens. The assemblage seems to constitute continuous votive deposition rather than a hoard.

A hoard of at least 60 Roman imperial denarii: Vespasian – Commodus (AD 180-192) was discovered by a treasure hunter in the late 2010s. The hoard was found in a forest, the coins were collected from an area of 10x10 m (slightly higher was another area of 30x40 m where several coins were also found). 60 coins were collected by treasure hunters during six trips. A fragment of an iron Roman sword blade was found 200 m from the hoard. The coins have a rather bad condition (heavy wear). The further fate of the coins is unknown.
Circa 350 republican and imperial denarii discovered. 79 denarii have been studied: Republic - Trajan (AD 103-111).
disposition: Muzeul Județean de Istorie și Arheologie Prahova, Ploiești, Romania (35 coins), inv. nos. 920730-920761; private collection (44 coins)

summary: Unknown original number of sestertii: Titus - Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: Town museum, Kaliningrad, Russia (inv.no. КГОМ 1.18842/1-119); Archive Rudau (in 1911) (inv.no. Rudau_wNL_SH_1_3-150_2, Rudau_wNL_SH_1_3-148_1, Rudau_wNL_SH_1_3-150_1)

summary: 13 denarii found in a room of a Germanic house: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 169-170).

Galba to Severus. The number of coins in the hoard is estimated and falls somewhere between 1200 and 1500 denarii and 1 drachm of Amisus for Hadrian. Found with a ceramic vessel and few silver ingots.
disposition: Odessa Archaeological Museum (64 denarii; 1 drachm of Amisus)

summary: The hoard comprised 15 copper-alloy coins from Hadrian to Commodus and we found next to a skeleton.
2 aurei: Nero, Antoninus Pius .
"1 litra" of coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 2 denarii are known: Domitian, Trajan.
disposition: National Archaeological Museum, Warszaw (2 coins), Poland

summary: 7 denarii, ending with Marcus Aurelius AD 176. No further information.
About 40 AR denarii found during construction of Bowers Fold redevelopment in 1963. The hoard was unreported and dispersed, two coins of Hadrian bought by Doncaster Museum.
Hoard of uncertain number of imperial denarii found while metal detecting. 28 coins were presented to the museum: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 191-192).
disposition: Grodno State Historical and Archaeological Museum, Belarus

summary: A hoard of 61 Roman coins to Hadrian and 616 Iron Age bronze coins found some years ago in Southants. It was contained in an earthenware pot which was broken in the course of the discovery.
disposition: British Museum (part); Hunter Coin Cabinet, Glasgow (part); Red House Museum, Christchurch (part)

summary: Around 418 silver coins: 416 denarii, 2 drachms: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla) (AD 164-180).
disposition: Muzeum, Koszalinie; Muzeum Zamojskie, Zamość; private collections, Poland

summary: In 1962 an excavator found a jar with 7 aurei, 1346 denarii (Nero - Marcus Aurelius), and 4 Lycian drachms (Domitian - Trajan), while building the foundations of the new building for the paper mill factory at Stockstadt.
disposition: The majority of the find was sent to Aschaffenburg Municipal Museum

summary: 11 AR denarii to AD 122. Latest coin is type of Hadrian-Fortuna referring to the departure of the emperor on his great expedition, AD 121-5. RIC assigns date range of AD 119-122.Addenda of 3 AR denarii to 117 in 2014 included here.

Penhallurick 2009, 269: "The museum on St Mary's has three sestertii found in a midden layer on the southern shoreline of Tean in 1956. Accompanying pottery indicated an occupation from the first to the fourth centuries and included sherds of samian ware and a bronze brooch (Thomas 1985, p.183)". He notes that the second sestertius of Marcus Aurelius listed here may have been turned into a brooch (bronze adhered to the bottom of the reverse), though this has not been verified.
70 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Augustus - Hadrian.
The hoard was found in April 1841, in an ceramic vessel under a stone. It comprised 140 sestertii, dupondii and 1 as, all from the antonine dynasty.

The hoard comprised a 'ceramic vessel containing approximately 20 kilos of Roman bronze coins (sestertii, dupondii and asses). Of 872 examples, only 423 were identified.': Vespasian - Septimius Severus for Clodius Albinus (Caesar) (AD 193-196).
disposition: Museé de Rouen, France (600 coins) (Inv. III, 2, p. 56, no. 1921)

summary: Initially were found 81 coins. 44 coins: 1 cistophorus, 1 sestertius, 9 asses, 33 unknown bronze denomination: Augustus - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
disposition: Arheoloski Muzej Istre, Pula, Croatia (44 coins); othewise dispersed

summary: 514 denarii found in a ceramic vessel: Augustus - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
2469 denarii and provincial silver of which only 210 were recorded - Otho to Antoninus Pius (208 denarii, 2 drachms of Amisus of Hadrian and Antoninus Pius)
disposition: Museum of Anatolian Civilisations, Ankara; Balıkesir museum

summary: The hoard comprised 45 silver tetradrachms from Claudius I to Antoninus Pius. It is not clear whether the coins represent a complete hoard or part of a hoard.
23 coins (2 denarii; 21 provincial coins: Dium, Thessalonica, Koinon of Macedonia) found in grave 12 in Sevasti.
160-180 denarii found in a ceramic vessel - metal detecting - within an ancient settlement. The coins are dated to the 1st-2nd centuries AD.

The hoard comprised '100s of bronze coins (150 coins according to Angot). The majority were of Trajan, Hadrian and of Antoninus Pius. In the 1860s, the vicar of Fougerolles, Charles Pointeau, examined 72 coins and Chevallier acquired 'a good number, all large bronzes of Trajan to Commodus'. It has therefore been assumed that this hoard was made up of sestertii.
58 denarii to Antoninus Pius (plus a probably unrelated IA stater) (not connected with the siliqua hoard from same parish)

A small hoard of 10 Roman imperial denarii: Hadrian – Commodus (AD 193-211) was discovered by a treasure hunter in March 2021 somewhere in Poltava region. Information about the find and photos of the coins were published on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity, March 18, 2021. The finder reported that the coins were discovered “in one pit”. The further fate of the hoard is unknown.
A find of 45 Roman denarii (Otho - Antoninus Pius) was made in a garden in Vicht. The coins were found in charcoal residues.

The hoard discovered no later than 1900; the total number of coins is unknown. A city dweller with the surname Shapiro bought 44 coins (Vespasian-Commodus; total weight 127.43 g), of which only eight were identified in the Imperial Archaeological Commission (by E. Pridik) and then were returned to the owner.
The hoard comprised approximately 250 sestertii dating to the second century AD and weighing between 5 and 6kg.
The hoard comprised 'more than 500 coins of uncertain denomination and type' but including issues from Vespasian to Commodus (AD 180-192).
278 denarii found with an small amphora: Trajan - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195).
disposition: National History Museum of Transylvania, Cluj-Napoca; Town Museum Gherla (20 coins), Romania

summary: Two denarii: Antoninus Pius, Commodus (AD 183).
Three aurei of Hadrian. Only one was seen.

A small hoard of 4 Roman imperial denarii: Marcus Aurelius - Didius Julianus (AD 193) was discovered by a treasure hunter in early July 2023 somewhere in Cherkasy region. Information about the find and photos of the coins were published on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity July 3, 2023. The finder reported that the coins were discovered “in one small pit”. The further fate of the hoard is unknown.
9 denarii: Hadrian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180)

Five denarii found at different dates, between 2005 and 007, on the same field using metal detectors: Vespasian, Trajan, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius (Caesar), Marcus Aurelius (Augustus) (AD 171-172).
disposition: Private collection (4 coins); National Museum of archaeology, Warszaw, Poland (1 coin)

summary: 15 sestertii, dupondii, asses: Augustus-Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
Unknown originally number of denarii. 27 coins are known at the moment: Republic - M. Aurelius (AD 161-175).
26 denarii: Republic - Marcus Aurelius (AD 176-177).
Circa 150 coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 5 sestertii are known: Hadrian 1, Antoninus Pius 1, Faustina I (Diva) 1, 2 uncertain issuer.

Hoard of 450 denarii found with a ceramic vessel covered by another pot: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (Clodius Albinus Caesar) (AD 194-195). Weight: 983 g. According to Kropotkin, the hoard ends with the coin of Clodius Albinus as all the coins of Septimius Severus are issues of AD 193-194.
disposition: Local History Museum, Uman, Ukraine (inv. nos. 1675/2760 et 2355/3440)

summary: 2 denarii of Trajan and Hadrian.
Four coins found in Jülich, during the construction of the technology center.

About 40 aurei were found by a peasant while he was digging, he also found a Hindu temple. This is the earliest recorded find of Roman coins on Indian soil. The hoard seems to have consisted exclusively of second-century coins.

A hoard of at least 595 denarii, ranging from Nerva to Crispina, found in the middle of the 19th century in the fortress of Krani in Cephalonia. The coins were given to the Numismatic Museum by the Phocas-Kosmetatos family (in 1970 and 1972).
16 denarii found by metal detecting: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-163).
disposition: East Fife Museums, St. Andrews, United Kingdom (5 coins)

summary: Unknown original number of coins. 36 denarii were recovered: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 169-170).
Grup of two denarii: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius (AD 145-161); silver weight: 5.52 g.
Six coins of Alexandria: Nero 1, Vespasian 2, Hadrian 2, Lucius Verus 1. No information about site or circumstances.
60 denarii: Galba/Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
282 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. 222 coins were recovered: Vitellius – Septimius Severus (AD 195).
disposition: National History Museum, Bucharest (182 coins); Institute of Archaeology ”Vasile Pârvan”, Bucharest (40 coins)

summary: 30 sestertii found stuck together in a Roman edifice: Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD162-163).
disposition: Museo de Arqueología de Álava, Spain

summary: A hoard of 32 Roman imperial denarii (from Trajan to Commodus) was found in April 2018 in Cherkassy region. Information about the hoard was published in three videos on YouTube, in the channel “Aleksander Mercedes w poiske klada”. The hoard was discovered by a group of treasure hunters on April 20, 2018 on ploughed field, at a depth of up to 15 cm. 21 coins and half of a bronze bracelet were collected from the surface of ca. 10-15 square m (the main concentration, 12 coins, in an area of 5x5 m). On April, 24 a sondage was undertaken at the findspot (ca. 3x3 m. with a depth of ca. 20-50 cm), and 6 more coins were found, including one broken into several pieces. On August 31, 2018, one of the finders found another 5 denarii at the site of the main concentration of coins. It is possible that further searches were also made at this site. The fate of the coins in the hoard is unknown. The identification of the coins was based on the photos that were posted in this video.
Hoard of 87 aurei: Nero - Commodus (AD 180-192).
The hoard comprised 1 dupondius and 5 asses terminating with issues of the period AD 178-183. The coins were found together, but without trace of a container.

The hoard comprised 1 denarius (Diva Faustina I) and 8-9 aes coins ranging fro Hadrian to Faustina II. They were recovered during the excavation of a inhumation burial (tomb 1/1965) in the necropolis and were interpreted as the contents of a purse. Only 5 coins are preserved today, but descriptions of the other ones exist.
disposition: Ufficio dei beni culturali, Bellinzona (5 coins); lost (4-5 coins)

summary: 3,728 denarii: Republic - M. Aurelius (AD 166-167)
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 2599-3353 (3626 coins)

summary: Hoard of around 2,000 denarii. 90 denarii entered the University Museum in Kyiv: Nero - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
Circa 300 denarii found with a ceramic vessel while metal detecting. At the moment, 17 pieces are available for description: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 151-160).

129 bronze coins (120 Dium, 4 koinon of Thessaly, 2 Thessalonica, 1 koinon of Macedonia, 1 Ilium and 1 uncertain), ranging from Claudius to Antoninus Pius, found in the foundation level besides the west wall of the first (western) room excavated at the place of the former sanctuary of Zeus Olympios, next to two other hoards (Dion 1998 and Dion 1999). All three hoards were buried in clay vases. The exact function of the area where the hoards were found is unclear, but the hellenistic sanctuary of Zeus Olympios had been transformed in Roman times, the wall of the temenos built over, and a theatre established.
The hoard was found during the 1988 excavation in the southern part of the Roman vicus. The coins (26 denarii, ranging from Nero to Antoninus Pius) were corroded together in a clump.
Unknown number of silver coins. One denarius of Trajan and one of Hadrian are kept in the museum in Ruse.
disposition: Ruse Regional Museum of History, Bulgaria; inv.no. 9, 553

summary: A hoard of 9 Alexandrian tetradrachms (Nero - Hadrian), found in house E.
53 large Roman imperial bronze coins (sestertii?): Vespasian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
343 bronze coins: 337 sestertii, 6 dupondii: Galba - Septimius Severus (AD 193-196). Weight:8205.03 g.
disposition: Saint-Remi History Museum, Reims, France; inv. nos. B-C

summary: Hoard of unknown number of denarii. Only for 7 cois is given Information on the issuers: Antoninus Pius - Marcus Aurelius/Commodus (AD 172-192).
Hoard of 35 Roman imperial bronzes: Antoninus Pius - Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: M.K. Ciurlionis National Museum of Art, Kaunas, Lithuania

summary: (10kg?) 18 denarii: Domitian - Commodus (AD 180-183).
Unknown number of coins found during construction work. Only five denarii are known: Republic, Vitellius, Antoninus Pius (2), Lucius Verus.
disposition: Before World War II some of the coins from the hoard were kept in the collections of the St. Elisabeth Gymnasium in Wrocław (Sankt Elisabet- Gymnasium in Breslau). Lost

summary: Hoard of unknown original number of coins found with a ceramic jug. 96 denarii: Trajan - Clodius Albinus (AD 193).
disposition: Museum of History, Kyiv, Russia (50 coins; inv.nos. AR/9256-9304); Local History Museum, Chernovitsy, Ukraine (46 coins)

summary: Hoard of 500 coins of the Bosporan kings: Ininthimeus, Rhescuporis IV and V.
Unknown originally number of coins. 59 bronze coins are known: 51 sestertii, 9 dupondii: Trajan - Commodus (AD 190-191).
Forty-eight Roman denarii were found with a ceramic vessel in the rubble of a Sarmatian house in 1995 in the area of ​​an Avar burial ground in Hetényegyháza.
311 denarii and 1 drachm, ranging from Nero to Commodus (AD 187-188), found in a leather purse while cutting peat.
Seven sestertii found sealing a child burial in one of the house of C. Iulius Silvanus: Domnitian - Antoninus Pius (AD 151-152).
171 coins: 169 denarii,1 sestertius, 1 dupondius: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 158-159).
disposition: Balaton Museum, Keszthely (91 coins); private collection (72 coins), Hungary

summary: The hoard comprised 57 dupondii and asses from Augustus to Antoninus Pius with a tpq of AD 150 to 151.
The hoard comprised 48 sestertii from Vespasian to Marcus Aurelius and was buried around AD 170.
13 bronze coins: 4 sestertii, 2 dupondii, 7 asses: Claudius I - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-175).
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie Națională și Arheologie, Constanța, Romania; inv.nos. 64682-64694

summary: 46 denarii (Vitellius to Antoninus Pius) discovered in a farm yard. Wynn Williams (1875) observed that the hoard was discovered at ground level, having been exposed by traffic and other activity in the farm yard: "The surface was very hard, and they were actually sticking out of the ground on their edges. Judging from a pen and ink sketch sent me, they must have been closely packed together side by side... evidently the road had got scraped and worn down by wheels, and thus exposed them; but they had been noticed before any one took the trouble to pick them up."

Ten Roman imperial denarii were found in the vicinity of ancient Olbia, to the west of Adzhigolskaya Balka, near the villages of Dmitrivka and Ivanivka (the exact location is not known). The coins have been identified by V. Stolba and U. Peter from photographs. The cirent location of the hoard is unknown.
47 de denarii with very poor information on the contents: Hadrian - Marcus Aurelius (AD 161-180).
Unknown number of denarii found with a ceramic vessel. Only two of them were known: 1 Trajan, 1 Faustina II.
Hoard of around 1,600 denarii found with a ceramic vessel. 573 coins were documented: Titus - Septimius Severus Severus (AD 193-211).
92 denarii: Vitellius – Commodus (AD 180-183).
The hoard comprised 22 denarii overstruck by the Bar Kokhba administration (AD 132-136).
The hoard comprised approximately 100 aurei from Nero to Hadrian. Only 7 were examined: Nero, Vespasian, Trajan 2, Hadrian 3.
disposition: Museo Arqueológico Provincial de Oviedo, Spain (7 coins)

summary: Around 600 denarii of which only 17 provide information on issuers: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 180-192).
31 bronze coins: 22 sestertii, 9 dupondii: Trajan - Hadrian
Three coins of Hadrian found in a tomb (1 aureus and 2 denarii), but the information does not look trustworthy and the coins are not preserved.
Around 150 denarii and a drachm. Only 43 coins provide information on issuers: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).
235 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Clodius Albinus (AD 193-197).

They were recovered during the excavation of a inhumation burial (tomb 2/1965) in the necropolis and were interpreted as the contents of a purse. 20 coins are preserved today, and reliable descriptions of the other ones exist.

Eleven coins found over three private searches; one in 2009, four in 2011 and six in 2012 (described as "being stacked"). The 11 coins are dated from Nerva to Antoninus Pius. It is not certain that all 11 coins are part of a hoard, but it is likely as they have been found within a small geographical area.

Udmarken on Bornholm has yielded three hoards with a total of 217 denarii. All three, A, B, C, have been interpreted as being of either the same hoard or of chronologically identical hoards. A and B were found a week apart in 1853 and C was found in 1857. Udmarken B contains 53 of the 217 denarii.

summary: 17 bronze coins: 3 dupondii, 15 asses: Vespasian - Hadrian (AD 117-138).

A hoard of four denarii (2 Domitian and 2 Trajan) was found during field-walking in the South Annexe of the fort at Newstead. The coins were recovered in a little roll, with possible traces of a copper/bronze container.
The hoard comprised 31 bronze coins from Augustus to Marcus Aurelius, not further described.

NA

100 denarii found in June 2008 (Oswestry Area I), followed by a further 23 denarii found in September 2008 (Oswestry Area II), both up to Marcus Aurelius. These were regarded as two separate groups, even if the date range is similar.

Found close to the Brotonne forest on the property of Thouzé, which was once part of the park of the Château de la Mailleraye, demolished in 1857. The hoard was found under a tree.
Grup of three denarii: Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius. Found in a plundered grave dated in the second half of the 6th century AD.

summary: Four denarii, unknown whether they were found together or were part of a larger hoard: Titus, Trajan, Antoninus Pius, Faustina II, Crispina. Most likely

The hoard comprised 5 sestertii, dupondii or asses from Tiberius to Commodus and was found in association with a key handle, an incense burner, two statues (one being of Mercury) and a statue base. The remains of a Roman building, the function of which was undetermined, was found close by.
1000 denarii found in a ceramic vessel - metal detecting - in an ancient building. The latest coins belong to Antoninus Pius.

The 16 coins listed here (14 sestertii and two dupondii, ranging from Trajan to Marcus Aurelius) were found in the area of the Dampfziegelei in 1897 and 1898. All coins have the same patina and corrosion, so it could be a hoard. Further particulars about the circumstances of the find are undetermined.
The hoard comprised 2 Roman Provincial coins: Dion (1 Antoninus Pius), Thessalonica (1 pseudo-autonomous Commodus), found in grave 4 in Sevasti.
Hoard of nine aurei found in a ceramic vessel: Hadrian, Antoninus Pius 3, Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) 1, Marcus Aurelius 4 (AD 177-178).
4 silver denarii: Hadrian (Sabina), Marcus Aurelius, Faustina II, Commodus (AD 180-192).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2562

summary: A hoard of 12 denarii (Vespasian - Hadrian) was found during the archaeological excavation of a building thought to be a granary and comprised of thirteen Denarii coins.

The hoard comprised 60kg of sestertii mixed with some middle bronzes (2,500-3000 coins). Only 26 sestertii and 1 dupondius were preserved: Trajan - Commodus (AD 98-117). The hoard was found by a worker, planting a vineyard.

summary: A hoard of ca. 1100 Roman imperial denarii: Trajan - Didius Julianus (AD 193) was allegedly discovered by a treasure hunter in the late 2010s near the town of Turbiv in the Vinnytsia region. The coins had a strong degree of wear. This information cannot be verified, as neither the coins themselves nor their photographs are available. The further fate of the hoard is unknown.
9 sestertii from Trajan to Marcus Aurelius (AD 177-178).
Ten denarii (Vespasian - Commodus), found in 1872 during peat digging. Two thereof arrived in the Oldenburg archive; an additional three were noted in 1905 in private possession.

A hoard of 9 provincial coins from Athens (periods VB and VC) and one sestertius of Commodus. The coins were excavated in 1936 in front of the north end of the Stoa of Attalos (grid P 7). When found, several of the coins were stuck together, suggesting that all ten were originally put away in a purse.
Hoard of 40 bronze coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 24 coins were documented: Nero - Antoninus Pius (AD 140).
At least 4 denarii found on a field: Hadrian - Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I).
110 denarii found in the Principia from the legionary fortress: Mark Antony - Marcus Aurelius (AD 168).
disposition: Museum Carnuntinum, Bad Deutsch-Altenburg, Austria (108 coins).

summary: 15 sestertii: Trajan - Marcus Aurelius (AD 174-175).
disposition: Groninger Museum (12 coins), private collection (3 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 83 silver coins from the Second Jewish Revolt dated between AD 132-135/6.

Found in the garden of one of the villagers. Consisted of denarii (quantity unknown), which were in a pot. The coins were taken by villagers. V. Lyaskoronsky in 1926 saw only two denarii from this hoard (Antoninus Pius and Marcus Aurelius). In 1964, L. Pobal examined the probable place of the find, but did not find additional information about the hoard.
15 coins of unknown denomination and issuer. According to NUMIS the tpq is around AD 180.
Seven bronze coins (asses): Trajan – Antoninus Pius (AD 140-144). The coins were placed in a cooking pot with lid together with seven clay lamps, type FORTIS.

A small hoard of 21 Roman imperial denarii (from Domitian to Commodus) and three bronze artefacts was found by a treasure hunter in March 2016 somewhere in Central Ukraine, probably in Cherkassy region. On March 10, 2016, on the Ukrainian treasure hunting forum Violity was published information about the hoard and a photo of the coins and items from it (the finder identified the deposit as a “purse of denarii”). There is no information about the conditions of the find. The coins have heavy wear, one of the coins has strong oxide traces. The bronze items are rectangular in shape and are most likely belt plate: two measure 4.5x0.7cm and one (with six rivets) measures 4.3x1.3cm. In March 2016 the hoard was sold at the Violity auction, and the further fate of the coins is unknown.
23 denarii, group of single finds, found within a settlement: Hadrian - Commodus (AD 183-184); silver weight: 57.89 g.

A hoard of 310 Roman imperial denarii (from Trajan to Commodus) and their barbarian imitations was discovered by treasure hunters in November 2017 in the Kyiv region. Information about the find and the first 104 coins were published on November 29, 2017, on the Ukrainian treasure hunting forum Violity, followed by the next 117 coins on December 6, 2017. The hoard was discovered by four treasure hunters in a ploughed field and appears to have been partially ploughed (the coins were collected from a relatively large area). A total of 310 coins were found, which were divided among the finders (two of the treasure hunters did not publish photos of their coins). The coins were in a hand-made vessel, a significant part of which has been preserved. A silver buckle, a bronze brooch, an iron knife with a bone handle and a “spinning wheel-like thing” (probably a knife tip?) were also found with the coins (all artefacts are specific for the Chernyakhiv culture). The coins are very poorly preserved (heavily worn). One of the coins was pierced, another had a plugged hole. The further fate of the coins is unknown.
10 denarii found within a cemetery together with other objects. The antoninianus (radiate) of Aurelian may be an intruder.
disposition: Initially in the collection of Councilor Scotti, later in the Museum of Wroclaw, Poland; today, lost.

summary: 124 denarii: Vespasian - Commodus (AD 186-189); silver weight: 43.80 g. (16 coins).
The hoard comprised a large number of Roman coins which were shared out between the finders. Fournier compiled a list, suggesting that 39 were of Nerva (and Trajan?) and 42 of Hadrian.
74 denarii: Vespasian – Commodus (AD 180-192).
Around 1,460 denarii - a number established based on an average weight of 3 g/coin (4.510 g)- comprising Republican issues to Commodus (AD 1180-192). 19 coins entered the collection of the Ermitage.
disposition: The State Hermitage Museum, St. Petersburg, Russia (19 coins)

summary: Hoard of unknown number of bronze coins. 1 coin of Antoninus Pius and 1 of Faustina I (Augusta/Diva) were seen.
This hoard was found in a Roman building. It consisted of 7 denarii, ranging from the late Republic to Antoninus Pius. The coins lay stratified in a roll and the find appears to be complete.
Around 100 denarii, 27 were studied: Nero – Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II) (AD 161-175).
A hoard of 3-400 aurei. 42 coins were recovered. They are all issues of Lucius Verus, 3 types (Coh. 157, 247, 248).
disposition: Royal Coin Room, Amsterdam, Netherlands (3 coins since 1894); 1 coin in Berlin

summary: Twenty-two denarii found on an agricultural land: Otho - Commodus (AD 187-188).
Over 26 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Hadrian - Septimius Severus (Julia Domna) (AD 193-196).

322 coins found in a ceramic vessel: 1 aureus, 302 denarii, 18 bronze pieces. Only 242 coins were recovered: Vespasian to Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161).

45 billon provincial coins of Alexandria: Claudius I - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161). Examined and photographed December 1962 in Athens by Hackens at a dealer of antiquities, who reported the hoard to have been found near Aswan.'
Group of six denarii found on the same area of an ancient settlement (?): Mark Antony - Antoninus Pius (AD 138-161/post). Similar structure with RATENICE 2002
646 denarii layed in the ground: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 194-195). 152 coins of this find disappeared between 1907 and 1975.

Discovered during agricultural work near the village, on a field belonging to the peasant Grigory Radzevich. The hoard included 21 denarii (Trajan-Commodus) and silver items (ingot and four rings). The hoard was sent to the Imperial Archaeological Commission in St. Petersburg, where the coins were identified by J. Iversen; then transferred to the State Hermitage

A hoard of 243 Roman imperial denarii and their barbarian imitations was discovered by a treasure hunter in late 2017 or early 2018 in the Sumy region. On January, 11, 2018, information and photos of the coins were published on the Ukrainian treasure hunting forum Violity. The finder reported that the coins were allegedly found in his vegetable garden (a common formula of Ukrainians treasure hunters to conceal information about the place of discovery). Photos of the coins have not been preserved. Forum experts have identified the coins as “standard”, singling out only separate coins of Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius (incl. for Faustina I), Marcus Aurelius (for Faustina II and for Lucilla) and Didius Julianus. In January 2018, the coins were sold in several lots at the Violity auction.
The hoard of 175 gold and silver Iron Age coins, and 23 Roman denarii, ranging from from c. 50 BC to the latter half of the second century AD, uncovered on a field at Waltham St. Lawrence.
Unknown originally number of coins, denarii and antoniniani (radiates). Among the coins were recognized those of Vespasian, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II).
The hoard comprised a broken ceramic vessel containing 30 bronze coins of Antoninus Pius. A bronze bell was found at the same findspot.
During the excavation of the Roman town, 2 small hoards of both silver and bronze were found from below the front of site VI. Hoard A comprised 23 coins, ending with Hadrian.
Over 1,000 denarii: Nero - Commodus (AD 186-191).
Hoard of two aurei - Claudius I, Trajan - and one imitation - Nero/Antoninus Pius.

The hoard comprised a broken ceramic vessel containing 400 sestertii, dupondii and asses from Vespasian to Commodus. Most were very worn.
The hoard comprised 86 denarii from Mark Antony to Antoninus Pius (AD 143).

During the construction of the protestant Alumneum (Gesandtstraße) in 1900, remains of a hypocaust system were found. Within the debris a group of 8 coins - 7 aurei and 1 denarius - were recovered, ranging from Nero to Antoninus Pius. They might have been stored in a wooden box or leather bag. The hoard's deposition is conjectured to have been linked to the Marcomannic Wars.
Five denarii: Vespasian, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius, Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II Augusta) (AD 172-173).
The hoard comprised 214 Alexandrian tetradrachms from Claudius I to Hadrian. They were found under a floor surface during the excavation of a Late Roman house.

2 denarii: Titus, Marcus Aurelius (Diva Faustina II); silver weight: 4.80 g. Together were found: loop of gold bracteate, 2 gold bands, 3 bronze pins, bronze sword (in miniature), 1 small bronze ring, various bronze fragments.

A hoard of more than 3000 coins was found opposite the church in Baarlo in 1830. More than 3000 coins (32 gold and the rest in silver) remained with banker Wolters. Further data is missing. Description is known for 5 coins. The first publication, in 1838, mention coins from Augustus to the Antoninians.
A hoard of around 270 copper coinage, only 229 were recovered and identified: Vespasian - Antoninus Pius (AD 158-161).

2 denarii part of a hoard found on the same field like GANDARVE 1927, 1928, 1928-1931: Trajan, Antoninus Pius; silver weight: 5.57 g.

White, in Lincs. Hist. and Arch., 12 (1977), 81; 13 (1978), 85
disposition: British Museum (part); Lincoln City and County Museum (part); Belton Trust (part); rest returned to finder

summary: The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing approximately 350 sestertii of which 250 were too worn to identify. Hahn compiled a catalogue of 107 examples which is given here. A news article mentions a sestertius of Severus Alexander which is not included in Hahn's catalogue which may or may not be part of the hoard.
(130) 79 coins: 3 denarii, 4 antoniniani, 71 provincial bronze coins: Elagabalus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).

583 antoniniani (radiates). The precise location is unknown. Based on the high frequency of coins minted in Antioch has been considered a site near this city. Coins: Elagabalus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
Unknown number of provincial bronze coins. 36 pieces entered the museum collection in Shumen: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).

67 antoniniani discovered in a room with hypocaust of a Roman edifice: Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) - Aurelian (AD 270-275).

Hoard of 166 denarii (512.94 gr.) found stack together: Vespasian - Septimius Severus. It was found within the settlement of Chernyakov culture.

(c. 300) 49 antoniniani: Elagabalus - Valerian I (AD 258-259); silver weight of 63.8 - 128.7 g.
"A considerable large quantity" of coins of "middle bronzes", all of Postumus (AD 260-268). Four

Unknown initial number of coins. Five coins are known: 1 Greek coin, 3 denarii, 2 plated denarii: 2nd c. BC - Septimius Severus (Plautilla) (AD 202-205). It may be a votive offering as suggested by some scholars based on the findspot.

77 coins: 11 denarii, 39 antoniniani (radiates), 12 AR, 10 sestertii 5 AE: Tiberius - Postumus (AD 266-267); silver weight: 31.3-136.1 g.

Hoard found during railway construction work, in a copper-alloy vessel (not preserved). Mainly Tetricus or Tetricus imitations (N. Dürr, Beobachtungen zur römischen Münzprägung. JbHMB 1953, p. 34, mentions Bonosus - this is wrong!). More than 5,000 coins. 5% of these were coins of Claudius II (mainly Consecration issues, mostly of barbaric fabric).
Three Roman hoards found in Stonea. This hoard comprises 22 denarii ranging up to Severus Alexander.

The hoard comprised two coarseware ceramic vessels containing approximately 5,000 radiates from Gallienus, Claudius II and Aurelian, as well as issues of the Gallic Empire. 16 coins from the hoard recently reappeared and comprised issues of Gallienus, Claudius II, Quintillus, Postumus and Victorinus.
698 silver coins: 1 denarius, 697 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Postumus (AD 268); silver weight: 190.0-1811.7 g.

summary: In 1959, D. Kienast may have investigated the listed series of coins in art-dealing, which reportedly were picked up as a hoard find in the city area.
4,116 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms, 2 bronzes: Greek - Diocletian/Maximian (AD 284-295). Acquired in Egypt by Dattari.
disposition: 185 were sent to Macalister. The rest is partly in Oxford, partly in Toronto. Detailed list in Oxford (Milne)

summary: The hoard comprised between 300 and 400 Roman coins, stuck together with corrosion products: Gallienus (sole) - Allectus (AD 286-293). Approximately 80 coins were destroyed during cleaning. Just over 220 coins were identified by A. Deville. In 1846, a further 4 or 5 argentei (?) and 40 antoniniani (radiates) said to be from the same hoard were noted by Joseph Curt. In 1862, Charles Roach Smith published an aureus from a Continental mint (RIC 621) from the Warne Collection which was reputed to be from the same hoard. The stated provenance for this coin should be treated with some caution. The nummus of Constantine I is also an intruder.
disposition: Musée des Antiquités, Rouen; Muncipal Library of Rouen; Cabinet des Médailles de la Bibliothéque Natinoale, the Musée de Boulogne-sur-Mer, the British Museum (fewer than 10 coins), the Ashmolean Museum (fewer than 3 coins

summary: At the beginning of 1884, a mass grave dating to the 1793 war was found south of the Hammermühle in Wiesbaden-Biebrich. At the same place was also found a hoard of ca. 30 Roman denarii, ranging from the Republic to Elagabalus. FMRD lists 32 coins. The composition of the hoard is highly unusual and FMRD considers the last 3 coins (Antoninus Pius and Elagabalus) as potential intruders. If that was the case, the hoard would end with Titus.
56 denarii found in the Seaside baths complex. Only 31 have survived: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 202-205).
22 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms found in a little home in a wall during excavations of a house: Carinus (Numerian) - Diocletian/Maximian I (AD 294-295).
It comprised 3,000 antoniniani from Gallienus, Claudius II, Postumus, Victorinus and Tetricus I (AD 271-274). Found with a copper vessel.
272 antoniniani (radiates) ranging from Caracalla to Trajan Decius (AD 249-251). 6 coins have been lost.
156 silver coins: 11 denarii, 145 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel: Septimius Severus (Caracalla Caesar) - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver weight: 55.0-394.8g.
72 denarii: Mark Antony - Septimius Severus (Caracalla Augustus) (AD 203); silver weight: 133.5-256.7g

1,300 antoniniani (radiates). "Due to the poor state of preservation of the radiates hidden in Varzi, which were completely covered by corrosive elements… The first group of 95 radiates were restored between 2020 and 2021 […] The issuing authorities are Gallienus (3%), Claudius II (64%), Quintillus (8%) and Aurelianus (3%). The remaining part (22%) consists of unidentifiable specimens.
