Only 43 radiates can be attributed (for now) to a specific mint: the majority to the Siscia one (86%), followed by Rome (11%) and Mediolanum (3%)."
disposition: Soprintendenza Archeologia Belle Arti e Paesaggio, Pavia, Italy

summary: Unknown original number of coins. Thre is some scarce information on 23 antoniniani (radiates): Claudius II - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).

7 antoniniani (radiates), all of Postumus from a single collection. The coins could be part of a hoard, or form a hoard in themselves. No information regarding the circumstances of their discovery are known.
27,735 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus - Tetrarchy (AD 294); + 3 silver plates; c. 114 kg
137 silver coins: 112 antoniniani, 25 denarii: Clodius Albinus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253); silver weight: 176.8-335.2 g.

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 460 silver coins. Auvray mentions Gordian III, Philip, Trajan Decius, Volusian, Trebonianus Gallus and Valerian. In 1834, Pesche compiled a more complete catalogue. His source (although he does not acknowledge it) appears to be a manuscript held by the Sociétè d'Agriculture which describes Roman coins found in the city of Le Mans and its environs. Pesche adds to his catalogue coins of Marcus Aurelius, Faustina II, Lucius Verus, Lucilla and Pupienus. It is not clear whether these coins are part of the hoard. Silver: c.460 (1, 173) coins; silver weight: c. 576.7-1295.1g.

The hoard was found in a large ceramic vessel. Within the vessel were five corroded blocks of coins, each coated with very hard clay. Two thirds of the hoard was cleaned (except for 2 blocks weighing 5.5kg) and it appears that there were approximately 1,500 coins (bronzes and radiates). Between 200 and 250 coins were of the emperors between Augustus and Gallienus. The others were of Aurelian, Probus and Diocletian. The hoard was found by a farm labourer.
The hoard comprised 'more than 8,100 antoniniani (radiates), weighing approximately 30 kilos: Gordian III - Victorinus (AD 270-271).
disposition: Musée des Antiquités de Rouen (172 coins; Inv. II nos. 606 and 680), France

summary: 1040 (996) antoniniani (radiates): Trebonianus Gallus - Tetricus I (Ad 271-274); silver weight: 281.8-1299.1g.
Hoard of circa 200 coins. Only 17 antoniniani (radiates) were recovered: Trajan Decius - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 259).
The six antoniniani (radiates) were interpreted as representing a purse hoard or being part of a larger deposit.
The hoard was discovered in a burial and comprised 38 radiates from Gallienus to Tetricus II. An as of Augustus was also recovered which may be intrusive.
Hoard of around 150 denarii: Vespasian - Severus Alexander (Julia Mamaea) (AD 222-235).
disposition: Statistical commission, Penza (in 1889); the high-school, Penza, Russia; old collection D. Ya. Samkvasov

summary: 20 denarii, 11 studied: Marcus Aurelius (Faustina II) – Severus Alexander (Julia Mammaea) (AD 222-235).
disposition: Museum of Týniště nad Orlicí, inv.nos. 63–73, today missing.

summary: 8 antoniniani ranging from Philip I to Victorinus 8, possibly part of a hoard found in 1935. The coins were found in northern area of Edlington Wood, below Crags.
The hoard comprised 438 (or only 380) sestertii found in a black coarse ceramic vessel: Augustus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
The hoard comprised 94 provincial bronze coins dated between AD 49/50 and 252/3.
A hoard of 96 Syrian tetradrachms (Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallus) and antoniniani (Gordian III, Philip I) from Dura Europos, found during excavations for the Expedition's house.
The hoard comprised 2 radiates and 17 Provincial coins (Thessalonica, Edessa and Koinon of Macedonia), found in Koufalia.
3 coins: Hadrian dupondius, Septimius Severus denarius, Gordian III dupondius (AD 238-244).
1,000 billon Alexandrian tetradrachms 'Acquired by Dattari, who sold it to Milne.'
disposition: Partly in Oxford, partly in Toronto. Detailed list in Oxford

summary: 2 antoniniani (radiates) of Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
Unknown number of silver and bronze coins. Two dupondii of Domitian and 5 antoniniani of Gordian III are known.

The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing 600 sestertii from Trajan to Marcus Aurelius. A further sestertius of Marcus Aurelius was overstruck with a double sestertius of Postumus. The coins were arranged in textile bags. Fragments of the bags survived where coins touched the walls of the vessel.

A small bronze cauldron containing a linen bag with the coins. The money consists of 889 antoniniani (radiates) from Elagabalus to Valerian I and Gallienus. Two pieces of silver-plated crockery, a plate and a platter, were found next to the cauldron.

Assemblage of 95 Roman coins (1st century BC to 4th century AD) and eight Roman objects submitted as a potential Treasure case (the objects were considered unrelated to the coin hoard). Those coins and objects were found within 50 yd radius on a possible Roman site beside the projected course of Ermine Street with the aid of a metal detector.V. Drost writes; "Among this assemblage are 66 copper alloy sestertii and sestertius fractions which could possibly be part of a hoard. The coins range from Vespasian (AD 69-79) to Gordian III (AD 238-44) and the composition is very similar to that of the Cowbit Hoard (BM ref.: 2003 T76). Most of the coins are dating to the 2nd century AD and are extremely worn as a result of an extended circulation until the deposition of the hoard well into the 3rd century AD. However, some of the coins struck under the Antonine dynasty are in a fairly good condition and it cannot be assured that all of the coins were originally part of the hoard. Eight silver denarii dating to the 1st and 2nd centuries AD could potentially be part of the hoard as well, even if hoards mixing silver coins and copper-alloy coins are not common. Nevertheless, it is difficult to ascertain that each one of those coins belong to the hoard. Note: a gold aureus of Trajan was previously found nearby.On the other hand, the 20 radiates or nummi dating to the 3rd and 4th centuries AD are very unlikely to be part of the hoard and can reasonably be considered as single finds." (Unpublished catalogue).The denarii of Augustus and Vespasian are plated.

find_spot_name: MADRID - REAL ACADEMIA DE SAN FERNANDO
summary: 15 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Claudius II (AD 268-270).
7 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus (sole) - Diocletian (284-293).

The hoard comprised 350 silver coins dating between the reigns of Nero and Trebonianus Gallus. This includes 10 denarii, 3 coins attributed to Caesarea in Cappadocia, and 227 Syrian tetradrachms, listed by Metcalf (= 240 coins, often quoted as the total number of coins of this hoard).
Hoard of 80 coins of Bosporan kings (AD 232-254). One denarius of Severus Alexander among the coins.

The hoard consists of 73 coins found with a patera: 5 imperial denarii, 6 antoniniani (radiates), 62 Roman provincial bronzes: Trajan - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253). Most of the provincial coins presents early 3rd century AD countermarks.

Mint totals are given but not linked with coins. This indicates that a full listing of coins must exist. The hoard was found not far from a Roman villa, next to the ancient road (cf. Gallia 20 (1962) p. 429) The hoard was deposited in the Cabinet des Médailles de la BN. Silver: 1098, 3602 coins; Silver weight: 2577.8-6108.2
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles de la Bibliotheque Nationale de France

summary: The hoard comprised a vessel containing approximately 150 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I to Galerius (Caesar) with a tpq of AD 293 to 294. It was found during the excavation of the Roman amphitheatre.
Originally there appear to have been 19 antoniniani (radiates) of Claudius II, However, Mattingly only reported on 18.
The hoard comprised about 4,000 coins of Gallienus, Salonina, Postumus, Marius, Victorinus, Tetricus I, Tetricus II, Claudius II, Aurelian and Probus in a vessel. There may be two hoards.
A hoard of 104 Roman coins (Philip I - Probus), found opposite the station of Mehrhoog, on a sand hill. The coins are lost.
The hoard was found in two vessels by workers. For the city master, it comprised c. 8,000 antoniniani (radiates). Among these coins, 796 from Valerian to Diocletian were identified.
176 coins: 3 medallions, 58 sestertii, 115 antoniniani (radiates): Domitian - Gallienus (AD 260); silver weight: 145.4-337.5 g.
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Namur, Belgium (171 coins); private collection (2 coins), in 1961

summary: The coins were found together with pieces of carbonized wood adhering to them: Antoninus Pius - Trajan Decius (Herennia Etruscilla) (AD 249-251).
Unknown number of silver coins found on a field where a grave was found: 1 denarius Augustus, 1 antoninanus (radiate) Gordian III. A brooch was found withe coins. No further Details on it.
7 silver coins: 6 denarii, 1 antoninianus (radiate): Republic - Valerianus/Gallienus (Salonina) (AD 253-268); silver weight: 11.8-22.8 g.
disposition: Musée Archéologique de Namur, Belgium (7 coins)

summary: 122 antoniniani (radiates)found with a purse and in a wooden casket together with other objects: Caracalla - Valerian I (AD 253-260).
310 antoniniani (radiates) found wrapped in a piece of cloth and placed in two ceramic vessels: Trebonianus Gallus - Tetricus I (Ad 271-274). The Tetricus I coins are imitations.

The hoard comprised a copper-alloy vessel containing approximately 2,000 coins from Elagabalus to Postumus with a tpq of AD 263. Only 701 coins were catalogued. Note that for Gallienus, Valerian II, Saloninus, Salonina and Postumus, mints are given according to RIC (Lyon), not Elmer (Cologne).
107 silver coins: Antoninus Pius - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238). No details on denominations.

In 1852 a hoard of antoniniani from the middle of the third century was discovered in the neighbourhood of Klugham. 31 specimens from the hoard fell into the possession of the Historischer Verein von Obb. 33 coins are listed in FMRD, including 2 denarii (Caracalla - Valerian).
Large number of denarii and antoniniani. Only 27 pieces were identified: Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-249).
651 denarii and antoniniani, ranging from M. Antony to Philip I, found in a Roman cellar south-west of the Roman fort.
A hoard of 13 provincial coins of Athens (period VI), excavated in 1934 near a late wall, north of the Tholos. Their burial has been ascribed to the sack of Athens by the Herulians.
1 as, 1 sestertius, 1 denarius and 7555 radiates and a bronze ring to AD 274.

The hoard comprised 23 bronze coins dated between AD 141 and AD 251-253. "The hoard contains a mixture of imperial asses and sestertii, with bronzes from regional 'provincial' mints (Gaza, Ascalon, Caesarea Maritima, Aelia Capitolina, and Nysa-Scythopolis), many of which are countermarked." (Kool, 41).
A hoard of 19 denarii and 31 antoniniani (radiates), ranging from Galba to Trajan Decius (AD 249-251), found during excavations in Bavay.
109 denarii and antoniniani: Commodus - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver weight: 134.3-277.1 g.
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1841

summary: 575 denarii: Nero – Gordian III (AD 238-244).
On an area of 3 sqm were found 22 silver coins: 2 denarii, 20 antoniniani of Philip I, beside a bronze lamp.

A small hoard of 9 antoniniani: Gordian III to Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253) was discovered by a treasure hunter in early September 2022 possibly near the town of Bar in the Vinnitsa region. Information about the find and photos of the coins were published on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity September 16, 2022. The conditions of discovery of the hoard are unknown. At the end of September 2022, five of the nine coins were sold at a Violity auction. The further fate of the other coins is unknown.

The hoard was discovered in 1933 by a farmer 100 m north of Rembrechts. 88 coins (mostly denarii, with some bronze coins, ranging from the Late Republic to Severus Alexander) were associated with jewellery. Most of the objects found with the coins were of silver.
A large ceramic vessel containing 15 kg of silver coins. 4453 antoniniani were published (Moushmov 1936): Aemilian - Carinus (AD 283-285).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. LXIX (in 1925); 1,231 coins

summary: 57 billon: Hadrian - Gallienus (Salonina) (AD 264-265) found as an unprotected heap on the floor of an underground room during excavations of a house. Range: Hadrian - Gallienus (AD 260-268).
disposition: 37 in Ann Arbor, the rest in various Egyptian museums

summary: 315 denarii: Vespasian - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 236).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2319/1-315

summary: 31 coins: 29 antoniniani (radiates), 2 sestertii found together: Philip I - Claudius II (AD 268-270).
Unknown initial number of coins. There is some information on seven coins: 1 denarius, 6 antoniniani: Severus Alexander (Julia Mamaea) - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
The hoard was found in a burial and comprised 8 coins of Balbinus and other contemporary emperors and a small gold chain with double pendant.
386 denarii: Mark Antony - Severus Alexander (AD 231).

The hoard comprises 32 antoniniani (radiates) from Aurelian to Numerian). The first publication by Taracena notes 1 coin of Aurelian and 2 of Numerian. However, Gurt notes 2 examples of Aurelian and 1 of Numerian.
50 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus - Claudius II (Divus) (AD 270).

The hoard comprised a finger ring with an intaglio depicting Mercury, a worn dupondius, 64 denarii and 75 antoniniani (radiates) from Septimius Severus to Trebonianus Gallus. The objects and coins were enclosed in a leather bag which had been placed in a small recess in the foundations of a third-century building.
1.616 antoniniani (radiates) found in a ceramic vessel which were deposit as a foundation offering beneath the theater orchestra: Gallienus (sole) - Probus (AD 276-282).
The hoard comprised 1 denarii and 25 antoniniani (radiates) from Elagabalus to Victorinus. The coins were stuck together with corrosion products.
Originally were 420 silver coins. 274 pieces were recovered: 1 denarius, 273 antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla - Gallienus/Postumus (AD 259-268).
disposition: Town Museum Koprivnica, Croatia (274 coins); partly dispersed - 1982

summary: Few hundreds coins found with a large ceramic vessel and wonderful jewelry. 53 coins were studied: Trajan - Gordian III (AD 239-241); silver weight: 75.8-153.3 g.
disposition: Museum of Oltenia, Craiova, Romania (53 coins).

summary: Ca. 100 antoniniani (Gallienus to Tetricus II) found in a pot behind the wall of a Roman house, close to the Schloßplatz. 65 have been described in FMRD, the others are lost.
The hoard comprised 42 bronze coins from Nero to Gallienus including imperial bronzes (sestertii) and Provincial bronzes from Knossos, Kydonia, Koinon of Crete and Alexandreia Troas.
The hoard comprised approximately 2,000 coins ending with issues of Gordian III (AD 238-244).
Unknown number of silver coins. 50 pieces entered the museum collection in Plovdiv: Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2391, 50 coins

summary: 24 coins: 2 antoniniani (radiates), 1 denarius, 6 sestertii, 4 dupondii, 12 asses: Tiberius (Divus Augustus) – Florian (AD 276)
2,290 silver coins found with ceramic vessel: Commodus - Valerian I (AD 257-259).
Originally 539 silver coins, 535 pieces recovered: denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus to Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
The hoard comprised one vessel containing 8,760 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian, Gallienus, Claudius Gothicus, Tetricus I, Tetricus II and Aurelianus. Silver weight: 1664.9-6394.3g.

The 9 coins (5 denarii, 3 bronzes and 1 antoninianus, to Severus Alexander) was found in 1780 with other relics, in a meadow near Marbach, at the confluence of Neckar and Murr. It is labelled as 'Kollektivfund' in FMRD, not as hoard.
The hoard comprises 1,931 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) from Vespasian to Philip I, as well as a single drachm of Geta from Caesarea in Cappadocia. Found with a ceramic vessel.
The hoard comprised 21 denarii from Vitellius to Septimius Severus with a tpq of AD 201 to 206. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 39.6-60.8 g.

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel including Roman coins. The hoard was dispersed immediately. The hoard was found during house construction on the site of the church of the Jacobins: Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
It comprised 42 denarii from Antoninus Pius to Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238).
2,060 silver coins: 1,849 denarii, 1 plated denarius, 209 antoniniani (radiates), 1 drachm: Vespasian - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-252).
disposition: History and Archaeology Museum Constanța, Romania

summary: Large hoard found while ploughing. Only 13 antoniniani identified: Caracalla 7, Philip I 6.
7 sestertii: Antoninus Pius - Postumus (AD 260-269); together with 3 bronze rings.

Unknown original number of denarii and antoniniani (radiates). Among issuers: Gordian III, Philip I, Otacilia, Gallienus, Salonina. Uncertain whether this is part of the 1840 hoard also found in Echternach.

Two radiate minimi (8 and 7 mm, 0.40 and 0.34 g., one with head to left, and one from dies too big for the flan), found with 'about seven others' and a coin of Victorinus (Elmer 743, slightly worn) were discovered on the 13th tee of Pyle and Kenfig golf-course, before 1955. There were also some fragments of pottery.
disposition: National Museum of Wales (part); Grosvernor Museum (part)

summary: Found during construction work. The subsequent excavations provided no information on any archaeological context. The findspot is situated in the slope above the vicus of Muralto. Hoard/deposition of 4869 aes coins: 1 as, 1 dupondius and 4867 sestertii, in an amphora, Claudius I to Gallienus (253/254).
18 (?) silver coins, found 1925 on the street 'Am Römerwall'. 21 coins are mentioned in the inventory of the Altermusmuseum, but the coins are now lost.
Circa 2,000 denarii but only 20 pieces indicate emperors from Antoninus Pius to Maximinus I Thrax.
79 denarii found en ruleau while digging a ditch: Vespasian - Severus Alexander (AD 223). Some coins may be intruders.
disposition: Collection of the public grammar school in Kalmar

summary: (30) 7 silver and bronze coins: 2 denarii, 1 antoniniani; 1 provincial bronze; 3 bronze unid. denom: Commodus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Private collection Andrei Pănoiu - architect, Bucharest, Romania

summary: 3089 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Valerian I (AD 257-258).

Found during excavations, in "Brandschicht" in a room in the western part of Insula 30. 4 coins, 2 antoniniani (Philip I and Volusian) and 2 missing, found together with fragments of a bronze vessel (lost).

The hoard comprised an enormous pot containing a very large quantity of Gallo-Roman coins. Although some of the coins were stolen soon after their discovery, the number of coins found totaled more than 2,000. Only 85 of these were described. After its discovery, the pot was left in the middle of the field overnight and some coins from the hoard went missing then: Valerian I - Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver weight: 541.0-2499.1g.

In a small Roman urn found in the bank of a pit at Wishaw (which adjoins Wig-ings-hill and Cat's Hill) were several Roman coins - seven Gallienus, two Victorinus, five Tetricus six Claudius and several uncertain.
6,000 copper coins found in a ceramic vessel. Coins of Gordian III, Tetricus I and other issuers.
disposition: Mr. de la Fontaine (purchased for 40 Fr.)

summary: HER report of a small hoard of 80 coins of the Tetrici in a coarse-ware beaker from Alton.

The hoard was found in 1906 after a farmer discovered some coins of Postumus, Victorinus, Tetricus and Claudius II at the same findspot where two years previously 100 antoniniani (radiates) of Gallienus, Claudius II, Victorinus and Tetricus I and II had been found. As a result, Vigneron-Jousselandière excavated the findspot, discovering 7 silver ligula and a ceramic vessel containing approximately 3,500 antoniniani (radiates). At the middle of the vessel was a radiate of Philip I, 39 worn denarii, 1 aureus of Postumus and a gold finger ring. The ligulae or spoons, the finger ring, the denarii, the aureus of Postumus and 450 radiates were acquired by the Musée départemental d'archéologie. Vigneron-Jousselandière possessed 2,651 radiates (in 1907).
967 coins, found in an amphora on a shipwreck: Domitian - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 256-257).
Of those seen (934), were denarii and antoniniani (radiates) from Septimius Sverus to Philip I (AD 244-249); silver weight: 1364.0-1708.8g.
115 antoniniani (radiates) ranging from Gordian III to Valerian I and Gallienus.(AD 257-258). Part of a larger hoard.
48 coins: 13 antoniniani (radiates), 16 denarii, 17 sestertii, 2 asses: Nerva - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
Unknown number of silver coins found in a ceramic vessel. 117 entered the museum collection in Sliven: 84 antoniniani, 33 denarii: Commodus - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver weight: 157.2-281.4 g.

The hoard was found along with several inhumation burials and the foundations of buildings and comprised a mass of 80kg of Roman coins. The successive editions of the museum catalogue have varied catalogues for this hoard. For example, the catalogue of 1856 notes 35 coins for Otacilia Severa and Trajan Decius; the catalogue of 1903 mentions 3 sestertii of Trajan, Hadrian and Antoninus Pius (possibly site finds?) and 'small bronzes' of Philip and Maximian Herculeus. The mention of Maximian, 60 years after the discovery of the hoard is considered by TAF to be suspect. The hoard was found during dredging and ground levelling work, along with inhumation burials and building foundations. Silver: c.25,000-30,000 (39, 2) coins; Silver weight: -
4957 radiates to Probus (AD 279), found in a jar, 10 miles south of Oxford. The hoard contained a second specimen of a coin of Domitianus (Domitian II), a Gallic usurper under Aurelian.
Unknown number of silver coins. 9 pieces entered the museum collection in Yambol: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).

On the 30.5.1862, approximately 4,000 billon coins and small radiates dating to the third century AD were found during marshland reclamation work. On 21.07.1862, an excavation of the site, recovered a further 3,000 coins of the same date. The coins were deposited in two piles 1.5m from each other at a depth of 0.95m. They were found in a layer of aquatic plant debris. Fillon lists the emperors represented as Volusian, Valerian, Gallienus, Salonina, Saloninus, Claudius II, Quintillus, Aurelian, Postumus, Laelian, Marius, Victorinus, Tetricus I and Tetricus II. There were no more than 100 coins dating to before the death of Postumus. According to Fillon, the radiates of Postumus without exception dated to the Ivth and Vth consulates. The coins of Tetricus made up 9/10ths of the hoard. There were about 10 coins of Aurelian (pre-reform) and for the most part were found in the second pile. Fillon's engravings indicate that there were also barbarous copies of coins of Divus Claudius, Victorinus and Tetricus. The hoard was found during drainage of marshland on the land of Mme de Craon-Beauveau.
1200 denarii found in ceramic vessel. 156 pieces entered the museum collection in Svishtov: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: History Museum, Svishtov, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 1072-1142

summary: The hoard comprised 372 coins that were fused together in a single lump. They comprised 1 denarius and 371 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I to Victorinus. The mint distribution is given in TAF (Rome: 210; Cologne: 93; Trier: 24) but not related to issues of particular emperors. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 100g to 111.0g.
94 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) - Tacitus (AD 275-276).
c. 100 antoniniani: Gordian - Philip I (AD 244-249). No further information.
28 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Valerian I (AD 258-259); silver weight: 35.0g.
62 coins: 1 aureus, 56 denarii and 5 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Valerian I (AD 253-256).
A large hoard of antoniniani (radiates). Only 204 coins were noticed: Gallienus (sole) - Carinus (AD 283-284); silver weight: 36.8-65.2 g.

The hoard comprised a Samian ware vessel filled with radiates. Although they were immediately dispersed amongst the group of workmen who found them, M. Le Pesant was able to examine 176 of the coins: Caracalla - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251). Sixty of the coins and a fragment of the base of the vessel were acquired by the Musée d'Évreux. Silver weight: 215.2-408.4 g.

A small hoard of 9 coins of Faustina II to Gallienus (sole reign), found at base of stone-lined pit at SE corner of ambulatory wall of later octagonal temple (building VI).Five of the coins could not be identified but were "not later than AD 270" (Wedlake 1982, 45). Denominations not given and the coins cannot be identified in the listing from the site. I have assumed them to be copper alloy. They are given as Faustina II (1), Gordian III (1), Gallienus (sole reign) (2) and unidentifed "up to AD 270" (5).
Unknown originally number of coins. Only eight silver coins are known: 5 antoniniani (radiates), 3 denarii: Caracalla – Gallienus (sole).
Hoard of 14 gold stateri of the Bosporan kings, Sauromates II (4) and Rhescuporis III (10) (AD 225).
Group of six coins: aureus of Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I), aureus of Postumus and 4 denarii of Augustus found in grave no. 8.
1,100 denarii and antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: Regional History Museum Vidin, Bulgaria; inv. no. 1426

summary: A hoard of 381 silver coins (denarii and antoniniani ranging from Geta to Postumus) and 1 provincial coin, found in a vessel surrounded by fire rubble in a building located in front of the SE corner of the Roman fort. The coins had been contained in a bag made of hemp. A large number of ornaments had been placed on top to the vessel.
A hoard of 260 provincial bronze coins (Domitian - Gallus, including one from the First Jewish Revolt), found at Dura Europos, in L8 W102, the street along the wall near the main Gate.
39 silver coins: 1 denarius, 38 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Postumus (AD 260-269)
disposition: Musées royaux des Beaux-Arts de Belgique (39 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised a vessel containing a copper-alloy finger ring, two gold finger rings, one with an engraved intaglio setting and 2,334 denarii and radiates from Antoninus Pius to Postumus. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 702.5g to 6042.8g.
The hoard comprised a vessel containing approximately 150 third century antoniniani (radiates.) The hoard was discovered by a farmer while cutting back an oak tree.
"A thousand coins hoard coins found with a ceramic pot". 874 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (Sole) (AD 253-268).
disposition: Fund 'Il Castello", inventory list; the hoard was probably sold on market

summary: The hoard comprised an urn containing 218 (or 318) Roman silver coins, both denarii and antoniniani (radiates). A silver statue depicting a 'wise old man' was also discovered at the same findspot a little later. The hoard was found by a farmer called Filliol while working in his field; silver weight: c.60.4-563.7g.
3456 antoniniani: Valerian I - Carinus (AD 283-285); silver weight: 623.2-4318.9 g.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Haskovo, Bulgaria; inv. no. N 326 - N 328

summary: 117 coins entered museum collection Yambol: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Yambol, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2409/0-65/, 2435/0-40/, 2547/0-7/, 2663/0-3/

summary: 21 aurei of Gordian III (Rome, AD 241-243).

The hoard comprised 59 coins, including one denarius of Maximinus and 58 Roman Provincial coins, found in a grave on the north side of the hill of the « Παλαιόν Ηρώον ». The coins of the Koinon are inscribed ΚΟΙΝΟΝ ΜΑΚΕΔΟΝΩΝ and ΜΑΚΕΔΟΝΩΝ ΟΜΟΝΟΙΑ.

The hoard was found in a barrel or box and comprised approximately 900 bronze coins arranged in stacks. The first account of the hoard gives the hoard as ranging from Domitian to Commodus, with coins of Hadrian and the Antonines (with the exception of Commodus) being particularly numerous. A catalogue of 36 of the sestertii was created. In 1843 or 1844, it was noted that there were also two later coins in the hoard. The hoard was dispersed immediately amongst collectors, with a small number of worn coins kept by the finder. The Musée du Mans acquired some coins (which are now mixed in with the La Quinte hoard).
disposition: Musée du Mans (coins are now mixed in with the La Quinte hoard)

summary: The hoard comprised 24 sestertii, asses and antoniniani (radiates) from Augustus to Probus and was found in the courtyard garden of a house during excavations of the Roman town of Clunia.
1700 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I/Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282).

(100) 75 silver coins found with a ceramic vessel: 44 denarii, 29 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-247); silver weight: 101.7-155.2 g; together with irregular pieces of gold (13.5 g) found in a vessel
disposition: Museum of Roman and Dacian Civilisation Deva, Romania (73 coins, gold pieces, and the 3 sherds), Museum of Petroșani, Romania (2 coins)

summary: 30 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. 17

summary: The hoard was found on the site of a Roman villa and comprised 4 vessels containing 4,399 coins. 156 were denarii from Antoninus Pius to Gordian III and 4,245 were radiates from Gordian III to Gallienus' sole reign and Postumus. Vessel 1 contained a single denarius of Severus Alexander and 1057 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Postumus with a tpq of AD 264-265. Vessel 2 contained 986 antoniniani (radiates) from Elagabalus to Postumus with a tpq of AD 268. Vessel 3 contained 155 denarii from Antoninus Pius to Maximinus I and 575 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Postumus with a tpq of AD 268. Vessel 4 contained 1,627 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Postumus.
(6-700) 23 coins silver coins: Marcus Aurelius - Valerian I (AD 253-260).
20 antoniniani. No further information .
Unknown initial number of coins found in a copper alloy vessel: Gordian III - Victorinus (AD 269-271).
A hoard of 751 AE radiates, & 1 AE denarius and pottery to AD 286 in a black burnished ware jar. Unpublished coin report by R. Abdy.
The hoard was found in a Roman theatre and comprised 1,065 coins. 12 imitations of antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I. 1,053 blanks and 6 rejected blanks.
33 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus to Aurelianus (AD 270-275).
disposition: Museo Arch. Reg. "P. Orsi", Siracusa, Italy

summary: 4-5 antoniniani (radiates) of which only 2 coins are known: Gordian III, Trajan Decius (Herennius Etruscus Caesar).
Initially 857 coins, only 168 silver coins are known, and jewelry found with a : Vespasian - Aurelian (Severina) (AD 270-275).
disposition: Museo Civico, Lodi, Italy (nowadays, 168 coins, 1 brooch and 1 silver ring); Biblioteca Laudense, Lodi, Italy

summary: 27 silver coins of unknown denomination and issuer. According to the NUMIS the tpq is around AD 250.
3,124 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 258).
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 572 worn sestertii of the second century to Gordian III.

The hoard comprised 'a ceramic vessel containing more than 300 middle bronzes. They were of Marcia Severa, the young Gordian, Gordian II. They were all different, but all base silver.' It is clear that the coins were radiates, although it is possible that there may have also been some denarii if the identification of coins of Gordian II is correct. The hoard was found by a labourer.
105 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Targovishte, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 31173-31277

summary: 88 antoniniani (radiates) found by metal detecting. Only 44 pieces were available for study.
Over 100 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani (radiates), and a bronze clasp. Among these coins were identified issuers such as Severus Alexander, Gordian III, Philip I.
It comprised c. 250 bronze coins found with a ceramic vessel. Only 75 are recorded: Valerian I and Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
Unknown number of silver coins were found in a ceramic vessel. N. Moushmov examined 119 pieces: Nerva - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
60 large bronze coins (i.e. sestertii) were found in a bowl in Trier, in the suburb St. Barbara inside Roman stonework.
Five denarii found on a field: Domitian - Severus Alexander (AD 231-235).
12 silver coins: 1 denarius, 11 antoniniani: Maximinus I Thrax - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 257-258).
118 coins : 114 bronzes and 4 denarii (1 nummus of Constantin intrusive)
Circa 3000 antoniniani (radiates) with portraits of Gordian III, Philip I, Otacilia Severa, Philip II "and other emperors and empresses of the 3rd century".
Although 17 sestertii were found, only 12 were described by Mattingly presumably because 5 were too worn to identify. Found stuck together in the "House of the two hoards".
(c.3.500-5,000) 61 antoniniani: Valerian I/Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282); silver weight: 721.1-4999.1 g.
disposition: Museum of Chambéry, France (2 kg), including the ceramic vessel

summary: The hoard comprised 13 sestertii from Trajan to Severus Alexander.

Unknown number of coins found in a ceramic vessel together with a bronze statuette of Mercury. 34 coins entered the museum collection in Plovdiv: 21 denarii, 12 antoniniani, 1 provincial bronze: Commodus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 5210

summary: Unknown original number of coins. 19 antoniniani (radiates) were sold to a goldsmith. Probably the same hoard mentioned as found with an urn.
84 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Valerian I nd Gallienus (AD 260); silver weight: 24.2-151.3 g.
The hoard was found in "Perron" locality, in a vase. It comprised 1,200 coins from Elagabalus to Postumus (AD 260-269).
A hoard of seven antoniniani (Gallienus - Postumus), found while extracting peat in the moor.
The hoard comprised 14 radiates from AD 253 to AD 259.
The hoard was found during the course of a rescue excavation and comprised 8 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Valerian and Gallienus.
89 antoniniani (radiates) ranging from Gordian III to Aemilian.
62 coins, mostly sestertii: Trajan - Gordian III (AD 238-244)
The hoard comprised 160 Roman bronze and billon coins from Severus Alexander to Aurelian (AD 270-275).

The hoard comprised one bronze vessel containing 7150 radiates from Tetricus I, Tetricus II, Valerian, Gallienus, Claudius Gothicus, Aurelianus and Probus. It must be linked to the treasure LA VINEUSE II
242 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel: Elagabalus - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver weight: 67.7-626.9 g.

80 bronze coins were bought by M. Alexandrov: 1 sestertius, 79 provincial bronze coins: Hadrian - Gordian III (AD 238-244). Mints: Nicopolis ad Istrum 38, Marcianopolis 30, Hadranopolis 4, Anchialus 2, Deultum 2, Augusta Traiana 1, Pautalia 1, Nicomedia 1.
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 927-991

summary: 17 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: History Museum, Razgrad, Bulgaria; inv.no. IF, hoard 21

summary: 26 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel: Philip I - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver weight: 8.0-31.5g.
disposition: Prof. J. Coupry, Faculté des Lettres de Bordeaux, Director of Bordeaux Department for Antiquities

summary: 32 gold staters of the Bosporan kings: Eupator, Sauromates II, Rhescuporis III.

The hoard comprised 39 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Valerian I and Gallienus. They were found under a layer of burnt material and many of the coins were blackened, melted or twisted. 34 coins were minted in Rome, 3 in Viminacium and 1 in Cologne with the latest coin being a Cologne issue from AD 256 to 258. Although TAF notes the mint distribution, they are not assigned to coins of particular emperors.
36 imitations of antoniniani (radiates) for the issuers of the Gallic Empire: Victorinus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles du Musée National d'Histoire et d'Art, Luxembourg, Luxembourg; inv.no. 1992-235

summary: 156 coins: 2 antoniniani (radiates), 143 sestertii, 3 dupondii, 8 asses; silver weight: 6.4-8.6g.

Between 296 and 334 coins. The coins came out following the blasting activities on the Lueg Canal. G. Dembski considers as hoard these coins due to homogenous aspect of this numismatic evidence: Vesasian - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
20 Alexandrian bronzes found in ceramic vessel in the courtyard just in front of a door during excavations of a house. Ranking: Cleopatra VII - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
103 coins: 7 antoniniani, 96 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: History Museum, Razgrad, Bulgaria; inv.no. IF, hoard 17

summary: A hoard of 12 provincial coins of Gordian III and Tranquillina (Thessalonica and Edessa), found during the excavations of a farmhouse in ancient Lete (preceding the construction of the Egnatia motorway) and linked to the Gothic invasions of the middle of the 3rd c. AD.

A hoard of 432 Roman silver coins (denarii and some antoniniani), ranging from Commodus to Trajan Decius, found in the summer of 1895 during draining works at Brickendonbury, south of Hertford. The coins lay partly in a small recess cut in the virgin clay, and partly in the soil above.
(c. 250) 216 silver coins: Vespasian - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235), silver weight: 301.0-629.2 g.
disposition: Okrazen Istoriceski Muzej, Pleven, Bulgaria; 204 coins; inv. nos. 843 1-122

summary: It comprised 187 sestertii found with a ceramic vessel: Nerva - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).

The hoard comprised a plain ceramic vessel containing 628 Roman coins from Trajan Decius to Tetricus I. These included 3 denarii of Postumus and 625 silver, billon or bronze coins (denarii and radiates) of several emperors. The coins of Claudius II and the Tetrici constituted 5/6ths of the hoard.

The hoard comprised 152 coins of which 128 were studied by Dancoisne. There were 12 sestertii and 116 denarii and antoniniani (radiates), although Dancoisne does not specify which coins are which! The hoard was found by workmen by the side of the river: -116 coins; silver weight: 34.0-336.1g.
14 sestertii found in a house: Nerva - Philip I (AD 244-249).
3,918 antoniniani of the second half of the 3rd century AD found on the territory of the village. No further information.
349 denarii: Vitellius - Severus Alexander (AD 222-228)
disposition: History Museum, Razgrad, Bulgaria; inv.no. IF, hoard 9

summary: In the vicus located at the Roman In the vicus located at the Roman crossroads near the La Mône a vessel of 40 kg (8-10,000 bronze and billon coins) was found. The sestertii run from Augustus to Postumus, while the denarii and antoniniani (radiates from Antoninus Pius to Macrinus and Quietus (AD 270).
Hoard of 96 bronze staters of Rhescuporis V (AD242-267).
186 denarii, ranging from Vitellius to Severus Alexander, found compacted together during building work on the Augustusplatz. A few coins were lost.

7 (!), but only 6 coins mentioned found with a ceramic vessel: Hadrian, Lucius Verus, Commodus 2, Trajan Decius and one unidentified coin. Together, it was found a bronze bar (59x16x 95 mm). Some doubts have been expressed about this discovery!
disposition: Coin Room, National History Museum of Latvia, Riga (inv.nos. LNVM NUM - CVVM 120192: 1-8).

summary: The hoard comprised 1,200 aurei from Hadrian to Elagabalus together with 16 artefacts of silverware. Two amphorae found close to the surrounding north enclosure of the Precinct of Amun-Ra in Karnak.

A hoard of 907 coins, found in a broken clay pot during building work carried out with a bulldozer: one Parthian drachm (Orodes I), 771 didrachms and 4 drachms of Caesarea in Cappadocia up to Geta, and 131 Roman denarii up to Alexander Severus, as well as one drachm of Caracalla attributed to Petra and dated to AD 211-12 (listed as a coin of Elagabalus from Caesarea by Dundua 2008).

The hoard comprised a broken ceramic vessel containing approximately 900 coins of which 200 were dispersed. They included issues of Trajan, Plotina, Hadrian, Sabina, Antoninus Pius, Faustina I and II, Marcus Aurelius, Lucius Verus, Lucilla, Commodus, Crispina, Clodius Albinus and Julia Domna. The cataloguer mentioned these coins in particular: one of Diva Faustina, 2 coins of Divus Antoninus Pius (RIC 1262/1265 and 1274) and one of Commodus with a quadriga on the reverse.
The hoard comprised 5 Roman Provincial coins: Thessalonica (1 Septimius Severus, 1 Julia Domna, 1 Elagabalus, 1 pseudo-autonomous), Edessa (1 Gordian III), found in a grave.
32 antoniniani ranging from Gordian III to Aemilian.
The hoard comprised an iron pot filled with several hundred denarii and radiates from Trajan to Postumus (AD 260-269).
1,049 bronze coins found in three ceramic vessels placed one next to the other: 1,045 sestertii, 3 dupondii, 1 as: Nero - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Cabinet des médailles de la Bibliothèque Nationale de France

summary: 14 coins found in a grave: 1 denarius, 13 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus (Caracalla) - Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268).
Circa 80 silver coins. Only 2 of Caracalla, 3 of Gordian III, 1 of Philip I are known.

The hoard comprised a vessel containing approximately 900 silver coins (denarii). The older coins show wear patterns consistent with long circulation, while the more recent issues were in mint condition: Hadrian (Sabina Augusta) - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
The hoard comprised a grey-blue ceramic vessel containing 217 antoniniani (radiates) from Trebonianus Gallus to Victorinus. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 66 g to 270.3g.

Approximately 10,000 coins. Information on only 925 pieces, billon Alexandrian. Portion of a hoard in the possession of Louis T. Dilauro, June, 1979. Some 400 additional pieces were said to have been culled at random, and the original size of the whole is said to have been in the range of 10000 pieces.
disposition: Louis T. Dilauro (June, 1979, part of the hoard); 3 in New York, the rest in trade. Detailed list in New York (William E. Metcalf).

summary: It comprised 23 coins found in "un grand mortier de pierre" (mortarium). Only 3 were identified: Augustus, Marcus Aurelius, Aurelian.

The hoard comprised between 960 and 1012 denarii from Galba to Elagabalus. Only 413 denarii from the hoard were studied. Silver: c.1000 coins; Silver weight: 1411.7-3148.3 g. Found under some stones by a farmer
disposition: Musees de Beaux-Arts, Quimper acquired 350 coins and Brest (Sociéte Academique) acquired 41.

summary: Unknown initial number of coins. 70 pieces are kept in the museum of Lovech: 12 denarii, 29 antoniniani, 29 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Aemilian (AD 253).
disposition: Museum of Lovech, department of Archaeology, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 1675-1676

summary: 4 antoniniani (Gordian III - Trajan Decius) found during field work.
The hoard comprised an unknown number of Roman coins of which 13 were kept and including issues of Trajan to Postumus.
78 sestertii including two imitations, Vespasian to Commodus with one Severus Alexander
The hoard comprised 93 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I and Gallienus to Probus with a tpq of AD 282.

The hoard comprised more than 1,000 (?) coins, which were either bronzes or radiates. 72 coins were preserved in Auzances. The bronzes were extremely worn and sometimes illegible. 62 were sestertii and 7 dupondii or asses, although TAF does not assign denomination by emperor.
1120 silver coins: 711 denarii, 409 antoniniani: Hadrian - Valerian I (AD 254-255); silver weight: 1401.3-2899.5 g.
disposition: County Museum Râmnicu Vâlcea, Romania (779 coins); County Museum Giurgiu, Romania (344 coins); Silviu Istrate Puerece Collection, Sibiu, Romania (4 coins)

summary: 100 silver coins were discovered. 24 have been seen: 9 antoniniani, 15 denarii: Caracalla - Philip I (AD 244-249).
1,680 silver coins: 1085 denarii, 595 antoniniani: Commodus - Valerian I (Gallienus (AD 254); silver weight: 2151.6-3837.1 g.
The hoard comprised 12 coins from Volusian to Salonina, found together in a single mass.
The hoard comprised 273 sestertii from Vespasian to Trebonianus Gallus.
In 1873, Alph. Frappier gavie to the Société de statistique des Deux-Sèvres, 37 silver Roman coins which were said to come from a hoard found in the region.
54 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (Herennia Etruscilla) (AD 249-25); silver weight: 68.1-139.3 g.
disposition: History Museum, Yambol, Bulgaria; inv.no. II-1768

summary: (3500-3600) 3106 antoniniani: Trebonianus Gallus - Tacitus (AD 276); silver weight: c.640.1-4436.6 g
disposition: Musée Chambéry, France, 1344 coins, Musée Château d'Annecy, France, Registre d'entrées, II, nos. 6480-6482, 9046 (137 coins and one vessel); Musée d'Art et d'Histoire de Genève, Switzerland

summary: The hoard was found north of the village, in three ceramic vessels. It comprised c. 500 bronze coins. 180 sestertii, dupondii and asses from Vespasian to Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238).
6 antoniniani (radiates) found in a small ceramic vessel: Gallienus (sole) 2, Claudius II 2 Probus 2.

M. Poilly donated a lot of 173 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) to the Societé archéologique de l'Orléanais' which were found 'in the environs of Dieppe': Maximinus I Thrax - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver weight: 44.4-232.4 g.
Unknown number of silver coins. 33 antoniniani seen by T. Gerasimov: Gordian III - Trajan Decius.
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 'several hundred', '75kg' or 'approximately 3,000 sestertii from Domitian to Maximinus I Thrax. The entire hoard was quickly dispersed.

29 3rd-century coins of Gallienus, Victorinus, Tetricus I & II. Scattered along the bottom of an internal drain in building 2170. Dated by the excavators to AD 290, presumably on the basis of the barbarous radiate, though this could be earlier (listed as "reverse Pax" by Reece in Woodward et al. 116).Woodward et al. 1993. Excavations at Greyhound Yard, Dorchester 1981-4. DNHAS Mono. 12, pp. 62, 82, 116, figs 23, 30, plate 30. Building 2170
5 antoniniani of Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2475

summary: The hoard comprised a funerary urn containing the remains of Sextus Polleius Solemnis, an oculist's toolkit and 16 coins from Trajan to Valerian and Gallienus. The latest coin was a radiate of Valerian, from the mint of Cologne dating to AD 259 to 260.
The coins were found during the rescue excavation of a villa: Trajan - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).

The hoard comprised 2,676 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I, Mariniana, Gallienus, Salonina, Quietus, Postumus, Laelian, Victorinus, Marius, Tetricus I, Tetricus II, Claudius Gothicus, Quintillus, Aurelian, Probus, Diocletian and Maximian I.
(+2000) 1478 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I - Probus (AD 276-282); silver weight: 361.1-2499.1 g+
11 antoniniani of Philip I found in a small ceramic vessel (AD 244-249)

Mints: Rome (332); Nicomedia (11: Elagabalus); Antioch (6: 1 Caracalla and 5 Gordian III); 3 copies of Gordian III. Silver: 139, 213 coins; Silver weight: 462.0-912.5g The hoard was found during levelling works at a sawmill.
Six silver coins found in a ceramic vessel together with a silver ring and a bracelet: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
Hoard of circa 350 coins. 285 were seen: 284 antoniniani (radiates), 1 aureus: Claudius II - Diocletian (AD 284-294); gold weight: 5.34g; Silver: 284 coins; silver weight: 51.2-90.8 g.

A hoard 437 coins (?), composed of 1 denarius (Maximinus) and 436 antoniniani (325: Julia Domna - Gallienus; 111: Gallic empire) to AD 263, found in excavations conducted by the curé M. Duchâtel in Noyers. Note that the catalogue only lists 324 antonininiani for the period Julia Domna - Gallienus and 109 for the Gallic Empire (i.e. 434 coins in total, and not 437).
The hoard comprised 8 dupondii, ranging from Titus to Gordian III (AD 241-244).
53 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Caracalla (Julia Domna ) (AD 211-217).

7 coins: 4 antoniniani, 2 sestertii; 1 medallion of bronze and gold and silver jewelry were found within a child grave: 4 antoniniani, 2 sestertii: Septimius Severus - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 257-258).

A small hoard in a clay vessel was found. It was apparently of the same type as TAF I. 4 from Bourg-d'Hem (4 radiates ending in Gallienus/Postumus). The hoard was dispersed before it could be studied although one coin of Postumus was acquired by the Musée de Guéret.
Hoard of 191 coins: 190 antoniniani (radiates) and 1 Roman provincial coin (Ephesus) found as a pile on the caldarium's floor: Valerian I - Aurelian (AD 272).

A hoard of 486 antoniniani, of which at least 467 are imitations of coins of Tetricus I or Tetricus II, Victorinus and Divus Claudius II Gothicus, probably buried AD 290. The hoard was found on a field between Welldorf and Jülich while metal detecting and the surrounding area was then excavated.

In 1958 a small collective find of 18 antoniniani ranging from Aurelian to Carinus Caesar was unearthed in a ditch during excavations conducted by the commission for archaeological exploration of late antique Raetia.
The hoard comprised 19 antoniniani (radiates) dated between AD 255-257 and AD 271-272.
4,000-4,500 antoniniani found in a cooking pot. 1501 pieces are presented here combining the evidences of Brunšmid from the year 1880 and the FMRSl I: Gallienus - Carinus (AD 283-284)
disposition: Narodni muzej Ljubljana, Slovenia (few coins); Kunsthistorischen Museums, Wien, Austria (coins of Claudius II); Collection Markl (coins of Tacitus); Collection Kolb. (coins of Florian); Archaeological Museum, Zagreb, Croatia; dispersed

summary: A hoard found in 1979 to the north west of Bath and thought to be complete except for six coins. Very little is known about the discovery of the hoard, except that it was associated with a few fragments of lead which may be derived from a container. 1'807 of the coins were cleaned and catalogued prior to the resale and dispersal of the hoard; 1805 antoniniani, 1 denarius and 1 quinarius, ranging from Gallienus to Allectus.
5 coins found in room 3 of the House of Four Season: Commodus 1 denarius, Septimius Severus 1 denarius, Caracalla 1 denarius, Julia Mamaea 1 sestertius, Maximinus I Trax 1 sestertius.
110 silver Roman denarii recovered by excavation by the FLO and WYAS after initial detector find. For full details and images see SWYOR-810366. Unpublished catalogue by R. Abdy and V. Drost.
The hoard comprised a coarseware urn containing 1,806 radiates from Valerian I and Gallienus to Allectus.

In 1927 about 360 denarii and antoniniani (Caracalla - Postumus) were unearthed. The coins were strewn on the ground, on a place located on the floodplain of the river Rhine. There was also half of a longsword, remnants of scissors, 4 bronze rings and 50 tokens of glass and glass base.
(c. 200) 40 silver coins: Hadrian - Philip I (AD 244-249); Silver weight: 46.4-91.3 g.
1269 silver and bronze coins: 1251 denarii; 7 plated denarii; 9 antoniniani; 1 drachm; 1 bronze: Mark Antony - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235); Silver weight: 1777.1-4207.8g
disposition: National History Museum of Transylvania, Cluj-Napoca, Romania

summary: 47 silver coins: 4 denarii, 4 antoniniani: Caracalla-Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 70.4-108.5 g.
The hoard comprised between 200 and 300 coins either in or close to a grave: Pupienus - Postumus (AD 260-269).
An amphora with 2 antoniniani and 7 nummi ranging from Tacitus to the first Tetrarchy found on the seabed.
596 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); Silver weight: 745.6-1548.5 g.
disposition: Museum of Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 9091-9632; 9469-9588 (557 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel 64 sestertii and 77 denarii or antoniniani (radiates) from Vespasian to Valerian I and Gallienus. There was also one gold finger ring and one silver finger ring. Hobbs estimates a silver weight between 22.3g and 197.1g

Unknown initial number of silver coins. According to some information from a private collector the number of coins was between 2,500 and 3,000. 26 coins entered museum collection in Sofia: Otho - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. 32865

summary: A hoard of 1,702 denarii and antoniniani, ranging from Clodius Albinus to Trebonnianus Gallus, found in the surroundings of Düren approx. 15 years before 1930 when it was published. It is not sure that the 1,702 coins listed there encompass all the coins that were originally part of the hoard.

The hoard was found deposited in an old wall and comprised 838 antoniniani (radiates). Hucher compiled a catalogue of 810 coins: Trajan Decius - Postumus (AD 260-269). Hucher acquired 351 coins for the Musée du Mans (Manuscript of entries 1863-1909, p. 4 and 5) and the Hospice kept 487 coins.Silver weight: 227.2-1046.5 g.
The hoard comprised about 200 silver coins from Antoninus Pius or Marcus Aurelius to Gallienus.
863 Roman silver coins (Republic - Severus Alexander) found in a leather bag contained in an earthenware vessel on the royal estate of Einsiedel in 1859, in a drainage ditch.

A. Marsden writes:Group of 14 copper alloy radiates of Carausius (7) and Allectus (7). Condition is generally poor (due to corrosion not wear) but the coins were retrieved from a small area and clearly form part of a dispersed hoardAs mentioned, most of the coins are corroded but it can be seen that their condition when they went into the ground was evidently very good. Given this lack of wear it is very tempting to connect the deposition of this coin hoard (assuming we are not dealing with an accidental purse loss) with the reconquest of Britain by Constantius Chlorus in 296. Certainly, given the demonetisation of these radiates in 296, the hoard cannot date to very much later.
At least 1,772 antoniniani (radiates) found with a copper alloy jug: Claudius II - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 287-288).
Unknown number of bronze coins. 90 pieces entered the museum collection in Pazardzhik: Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional History, Museum, Pazardhzik, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 2145-2230

summary: The hoard comprises 127 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani (radiates) from Commodus to Trajan Decius with a top of AD 250-251.

A hoard of 162 provincial coins, 27 of which were illegible. The remaining ones were: 134 coins from Sinope (Antoninus Pius - Valerian & Gallienus) and 1 from Trapezus (Gordian III). The hoard was found in a burnt and shattered container in the remains of a Roman villa, on the northern side of the Sinope peninsula.
41 coins: 39 denarii, 2 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253); silver weight: 57.5-75.2g.
166 sestertii: Nerva - Postumus (AD 260-269).
A hoard of circa 169 provincial coins of Tarsus found on the site of the ancient city ranging in date from Septimius Severus to Trebonianus Gallus.
203 silver coins, 5 denarii, 198 antoniniani (radiates), found in earthenware with two golden jewels: Republic - Postumus (AD 260-269).
The hoard comprised an 'unknown number of sestertii and 12 silver coins of Gordian III': Nerva - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
163 antoniniani (radiates) found with a storage jar: Valerian I and Gallienus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
40 imperial and provincial bronze coins in the museum collection in Shumen: Antoninus Pius - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 13629/1-22; 13634/1-18 (40 coins)

summary: 6 Roman provincial bronze coins were found in an ancient wall: Commodus and Caracalla. Mints of Serdica and Hadrianopolis.

The coins were found in the area of Fleischstraße 68-76 during excavation works for the construction of a store. They lay in a ceramic container (an amphora, according to some sources). Large parts of the hoard came in private possession and its full extent is unknown. FMRD gives three lists, totalling 3595 coins (all antoniniani, ranging from to ): 1) Part 1 (3351 coins; FMRD 3062,2) 2) Part 2 (Private coll.; 25 coins; FMRD 3062,3) 3) Part 3 (218 coins seen by K. Cibis, only a list of emperors is available; FMRD 3062,4) 4) Part 4 (Private coll., 1 coins; FMRD 3062,5)
14 silver coins: Trajan – Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268). At the same place as ČESKA SKALICE 1884
disposition: Museum of Náchod, Czech Republic (inv.nos. N 1605-1618)

summary: The hoard comprised 11 sestertii from Domitian to Balbinus. The coins in the hoard were stacked on top of each other and corroded together, forming a cylindrical shape. It appears they were originally in a small bag or pouch which has not been preserved.

Found during construction work, no container reported. Located probably in the area of a Roman villa rustica. Hoard of 2,377 radiates: Gallienus (4), Claudius II (2), Divus Claudius (1), Aurelian and Severina (1115), Tacitus (730), Florian (4), Probus (519), Tacitus or Probus (1).
700-750 bronze coins. 483 provide some information and 273 can be entered at the coin data level: Augustus - Postumus (AD 260-269).
The hoard was found 50 metres from a Gallo-Roman villa during excavation and comprised 40 coins including sestertii, denarii and radiates from Hadrian to Philip I.
13 denarii: Vespasian - Caracalla (AD 216); silver weight: 24.9-37.2g.

70+ AR and AE. The coins found in the period 1828-1833 are partly derived from the hoard and partly from discovered complexes. The coins from the complexes may not be included to the coin loss from Voorburg. A total of circa 200 pieces. Coins (81-269): Domitian, Trajan, Hadrian, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius, Faustina II, Lucius Verus, Commodus, Septimius Severus, Julia Domna, Caracalla, Elagabalus, Severus Alexander, Julia Mamaea, Gallienus, Postumus.
disposition: Royal Museum of Antiquities, Leiden, Netherlands

summary: Circa 1,000 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus to Aurelian; silver weight: c. 271.0-1249.0g.

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing approximately 300 coins, of which 196 were identified by A. Fillioux. The rest of the coins were small bronzes (radiates) of Gallienus, Salonina, Valerian-Saloninus and of Postumus, for the most part worn or copies. The latest coin of Postumus (E. 593) dating to AD 269. Silver: 1, 193+ coins; Silver weight: 54.9-502.2+

The hoard comprised 4 radiates of Probus and was found while enlarging a cellar in a house. It was originally stated that the hoard was found in a small silver vessel. However, TAF questions the metallic composition of the vessel.

The hoard was characterised as a 'cachette'. It comprised approximately 350 antoniniani (radiates) of Gordian III, Philip I, Aurelian and other emperors of the period. The coins were generally well-preserved.
(160) 130 silver coins: 129 denarii, 1 antoninianus: Antoninus Pius - Gordian III (AD 239); silver weight: 181.8-353.2 g.
49 denarii: Vespasian - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211). Found together with a gold pendant.
16 provincial bronze coins minted in Bizya: Geta 1, 15 Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria (11 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised silver denarii and radiates from Septimius Severus to Gallienus with a tpq of AD 254.
25 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) till AD 255-256.
102 coins: 80 antoniniani, 22 denari: Elagabalus - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 255-257).
45 denari: Nerva - Elagabalus (AD 218-222).
250 coins: 2 denarii, 1 antoninianus (radiate), 247 sestertii: Vespasian - Caracalla (AD 213-217); silver weight: 7.4-8.5 g.
Four provincial coins (Pella, Cassandrea) found in a grave in Potidaia in 1973.

43 coins (1 Iron Age silver unit, 42 denarii and antoniniani ranging up to Gordian III) discovered in 1922 in a cave in the cliff above the East Wood, Ashover. A silver ring was found at the same place, in a niche between two large stones.
65 antoniniani (radiates): Elagabalus - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 257); silver weight: 82.6-167.6 g.

170 bronze coins: 83 official, 87 provincial of Alexandria (Domitian - Maximian I). During excavations in this region, where many Roman settlements are known, this lot was presented to de Looz by the mayor of Hannut.
The hoard comprised an orange paste vessel containing 3 denarii and 214 antoniniani (radiates) from Septimius Severus to Aurelian and Victorinus.
6 silver coins: 3 denarii, 3 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-247) found during excavations
disposition: Muzeul Dunării de Jos, Călărași, Romania; inv.nos. 45361-45365, 52259

summary: A hoard of at least 202 radiates. The latest coin in the hoard is radiate of Gallienus (sole reign) from Milan mint dating to AD 262. Mint data exists for this hoard but TAF is not specific enough to allocate mints to rulers. Museum Inventory No: 75-7. Silver: 8, 223 coins; Silver weight: 71.8-592.1
The hoard comprised 20 silver coins from Julia Domna, Julia Mamaea, Gordian III, Philip I, Trajan Decius, Herennia Etruscilla, Volusian, Valerian, Gallienus and Salonina.

A hoard of ca. 2400 silver coins, most of them ranging from Septimius Severus to Gallienus, was unearthed in house no. 45 in 1902. 700 specimens arrived in the Kempten Heimatmuseum, several others in private ownership. The provenance of the coins in the Kempten museum can't be ascertained any more, but FMRD publishes a list of 21 coins with RIC references, and a summary list of 363 coins that probably came from this hoard.
5 antoniniani (radiates) of Probus and 'few hundred smaller bronze coins from the time of the thirty tyrants' (AD 260-274).

A large hoard of at least 295 denarii, ranging from Vespasian to Caracalla, was found in 1965 on Jakobstraße, while digging up the road. It lay in a broken fragment of an earthenware container. 162 coins arrived in the state museum of Darmstadt, oxidized together in a greenish clump, but more coins were dispersed. Of these, 133 could be traced and published with the coins in the Darmstadt museum. It is likely that in addition to these ca. 200 denarii have been lost for ever.
1089 silver coins: 14 denarii, 1076 antoniniani: Antoninus Pius - Valerian I (AD 259)
56 antoniniani (radiates) found on the western wing of the cryptopórtico of the forum of Conimbriga: Gallienus (sole) - Victorinus (AD 269-271).
58 antoniniani, ranging from Caracalla to Volusian.

The hoard contains 37 silver coins (18 denarii and 19 antoniniani-radiates): Septimius Severus - Valerian I (AD 253-259). This hoard has been discovered along with some single coins from the Celts and Romans (sestertii from Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius and Commodus).
450 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic urn: Philip I - Valerian I and Galienus/Gallienus (sole) (AD 253-268).
Over 3,500 silver coins. 322 coins studied: 2 denarii, 320 antoniniani (radiates): M. Aurelius (L. Verus) - Postumus (AD 260-269).
The hoard comprised 14 antoniniani (radiates) dated between AD 260/1 and 270.
disposition: The University of Michigan Kelsey Museum of Ancient and Mediaeval Archaeology

summary: 22 billon tetradrachms of Aurelian (AD 274-275) found on the still of a niche in a wall of a room during excavations of a house.

The hoard comprised 64 barbarous radiates of Postumus, Victorinus and Tetricus I and 26 unstruck flans. They were found during the excavation of a cave, not far from Berdorf. The presence of several identical coins and unstruck flans suggests that there was a forger's mint somewhere in the vicinity.
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles du Musée d'Histoire et d'Art, Luxembourg (84 coins); private collection (5 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 'a lot of 62 double sestertii of Postumus (AD 260-268). They were sold to a dealer in Rouen who claimed they had been found in Eu.

On 18 March 2018, photos of five Roman provincial bronze coins Prusias ad Hypion: Macrinus - Gordian III (AD 238-244) with countermarks were published on the Ukrainian forum Violity. According to the finder, they were found at the same site on the territory of Khmelnytskyi region. Given the close chronology of the coins and the fact that they were issued by one mint, most likely it was a hoard. Coins: Macrinus (1), Maximunus Trax (2), Maximunus Trax (Maxim) (1), Gordian III (1).
39 silver coins found with a ceramic vessel: 31 denarii, 8 antoniniani (radiates): Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-249). Found together with a brooch and a silver ring.

The hoard comprised 9 gold coins: 1 multiple of 6 1/2 aurei, 8 aurei: Trajan (Plotina) - Florian (AD 276). Together were found jewelry: small gold male bust, three old bracelets, three gold armillae, rolled gold band, jet (or black glass paste) bracelet, black material bracelet, six small jet (or black glass paste) pieces, bronze pin.
(750) 639 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253); silver weight: 937.5 g.
disposition: Museum of History, Silistra, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 468-1108 (641 coins)

summary: 2,648 antoniniani (radiates) in a lump of over 5 kg: Trebonianus Gallus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
disposition: Landesmuseum, Klagenfurt; Münzkabinett, Kunsthistorischen Museum, Vienna, Austria (16 coins)

summary: 159 denarii: 151 republican, 7 imitations; 1 imperial denarius of Severus Alexander. Uncertain whether the Severus Alexander coin belongs to thee hoard.
disposition: Hungarian National Museum, Budapest (20 coins: today, 9 denarii and 6 imitations are preserved)

summary: (30 kg) 10,700 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani: Caracalla - Probus (AD 276-282); silver weight: 1919.3-27660.6g
disposition: Académie florimontane, Annecy, France; Musée d'Annecy, inv.no. 3058; Schwizerisches Landesmuseum, Zürich, Switzerland (187 coins)

summary: 449 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-260).
A hoard of three provincial coins, found in a grave in Amphipolis.
Unknown initial number of silver coins. 35 coins entered the museum collection in Varna: Caracalla - Philip I (AD 244-249); Silver weight: 45.1-89.6 g.
The hoard comprised c. 700 coins including 200 sestertii and 500 antoniniani (radiates) from Septimius Severus to Claudius II.
A dispersed group of barbarous radiates noted by Penhallurick. Possibly a hoard. The identifiable prototypes are of Tetricus I and II.
Hoard of 493 silver coins found in a ceramic vessel: 492 antoniniani (radiates), 1 denarius: Septimius Severus (Caracalla Augustus) - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver weight: 134.9-1281.3 g.
41 antoniniani: Elagabalus - Regalian (AD 260); silver weight: 51.8-105.2g
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing approximately 250 Roman coins of Gallienus, Saloninus, Postumus, Marius, Victorinus, Tetricus, Claudius II, Quintillus and Aurelian.

A hoard of 180+ AE provincial coins of Thrace (1), Macedonia (2) and Asia Minor (177, mostly Pamphylia (64), Pisidia (50) and Western Cilicia (10)), dating from the first century AD to the reign of Aurelian.
The hoard comprised an earthenware vessel containing 700 silver and billon coins (denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Severus Alexander - MArius (AD 269).
8 bronze pieces: 6 sestertii, 2 medallions: Antoninus Pius (Diva Faustina I) - Septimius Severus (AD 210).

IARCH record for scattered hoard of radiates (for full details see DOR-5D3543). Another hoard was previously found on the same field in 2013 (2013 T221 'Holt') with an addenda found in 2014 (2014 T962).
A hoard of 6 Roman Provincial coins (Thessalonica and Pella) ranging from Julia Domna to Philip I, found in the remains of a Roman building.
(700) 607 antoniniani: Gordian III - Claudius II (AD 268-270); silver weight: 153.8-706.5 g.
disposition: History Museum, Targivishte, Bulgaria; inv.no. 352 (597 coins); History Museum, Omurtag, Bulgaria; inv.no. 4-14 (12 coins)

summary: A corroded metal container was found in 1937, in the garden of a house. It contained either 20-30, or ca. 15 Roman coins. The 4 coins that were inventoried in 1957 are antoniniani dating from Claudius II to Tetricus I. Coins are lost today.

find_spot_name: ROME 1911 - BETWEEN VIA G. BRANCA, B. FRANKLIN AND THE TIBER
summary: 885 silver and bronze coins: Antoninus Pius - Gallienus (AD 260-268).
The coins (9 sestertii, Marcus Aurelius to Gordian III) were found during building work on the premises of Neckarhalde.
5,000 antoniniani (radiates) found with more ceramic pots. Only 2,249 were available for study: Valerian I and Gallienus - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 272).
disposition: Museu Nacional de Arqueologia, Lisboa; Museu Municipal do Bombarral; Museu Municipal Pedro Nunes, Alcácer do Sal, Portugal; private collection, Barcelona, Spain

summary: 40 asses and sestertii. 18 coins entered the collection Gerville: 1 Antoninus Pius, 1 Marcus Aurelius, 16 Postumus.

Chappée and the Vicomte d'Elbenne bought two lots of coins (approximately 2,000) which were sold as part of a hoard weighing 20kg. They were found in a ceramic urn in a field next to the station in Sillé-le-Guillaume or in Rouessé-Vassé or in Mayenne (Voutré or Sainte-Suzanne). The Musée du Mans has preserved a manuscript note related to a lot of 583 coins weighing 1,453g and quantifying these coins by emperor: Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
Unknown initial number of coins. 34 antoniniani: Gordian III -Valerian I (AD 259-260); silver weight: 42.5 g+

110 denarii and 1 radiate to Elagabalus, discovered 1999 in a Buckinghamshire field, with an addenda of 2 denarii (Trajan and Caracalla Caesar). On the same day in the same field a hoard of nummi was also found, the 'Prestwood B' hoard.
123 sestertii, ranging from Caracalla to Valerian I.
67 silver coins: 63 denarii, 4 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Direction des antiquités historiques, Paris, France

summary: The hoard comprised c. 200 antoniniani (radiates) (tpq AD 274).

A hoard found in 1865 under a mound of quarry stone in the middle of the locality. It comprised perhaps 800 denarii, dating from Trajan to Maximinus I. 765 (the catalogue is numbered to 766, but no. 677 is omitted) of these are recored in in detail by FMRD. The coins were in a pot, next to which a bracelet and a fibula were also found.
The hoard comprised 84 tetradrachms dated between AD 211-217/8.

The hoard was found inside a coarse-ware vessel, of a blackish colour. The coins were within a compacted, ferruginous mass and comprised 47 antoniniani (radiates) from Elagabalus to Valerian I and Gallienus with a tpq of AD 259.

Unknown number of coins found in the vineyard, on an ancient settlement area. 30 coins of Gordian III are known: 15 antoniniani for Gordian III, 15 provincial bronzes minted in Deultum for Tranquilina.
Hoard of 105 coins of the Bosporan kings: Rhescuporis II, Sauromates I, Cotys II, Rhoemetalces, Sauromates II, Rhescuporis III, Cotys III, Sauromates III, Rhescuporis IV, Ininthimeus.
1233 silver coins: 2 denarii, 1231 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Valerian I (AD 258).

A hoard of originally more than 200 antoniniani of which 147 were split up between different museums and a private owner. 116 of these were published in detail by Laser in 1972 (114 of these could be documented de visu by M. Schlapke in 2015) and FMRD gives a full list of all 147 coins. Unfortunately, the FMRD list is faulty. The mistakes are difficult to correct, as the coins are not all accessible any more today. As a result, all coins ever documented have been listed here, with three FMRD entries having their quantity set to 'zero' (0), as no matching coin exists among the ones seen by M. Schlapke. Surviving coins range from Valerian to Postumus. No trace of a container could be seen.
disposition: Weimar, Museum für Ur- und Frühgeschichte Thüringens (96 coins); Sondershausen, Schlossmuseum (8 coins); Gotha, Stiftung Schloss Friedenstein, Münzkabinett (31 coins, which cannot be identified any more within the collection) and 12 coins in private hands

summary: 2,567 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel: Gallienus (Sole) - Probus (AD 276-282).
disposition: Gradki muzej Varaždin (2567 coins); finder (19 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 586 bronze coins: Augustus-Philip I (AD 244-249).
11 silver coins: Nerva – Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268). At the same place as ČESKA SKALICE 1884
disposition: Museum of Náchod, Czech Republic (inv.nos. N 4007/1-11)

summary: The hoard comprised an unknown number of sestertii from Augustus to Septimius Severus. Blanchet compiled a catalogue of the 45 coins which he saw. He noted that the coins of Antoninus Pius were very worn.
1,103 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Gallienus (sole) - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 296) found in a disintegrated cloth bag in an underground room during excavations of a house.

The hoard comprised a total of 130 coins including 6 sestertii from Hadrian to Trajan Decius and 124 Roman Provincial coins from Athens dating to Periods V and VI (Hadrian to Gallienus). This hoard is linked to the invasion of the Goths in AD 267. It was found 300 m north of the archaeological site of Eleusis.
The hoard comprised 39 sestertii from Vespasian to Julia Domna, 4 denarii from Septimius Severus to Severus Alexander and 7 radiates from Gordian III to Otacilia Severa with a tpq of AD 248 to 249.
108 bronze coins of Postumus: double sestertii, sestertii, imitations (AD 267-269).

The hoard was found during the demolition of the praefurnium by M. Plessis. It comprised 4,625 coins weighing 12kg. Hucher compiled a catalogue of 4,518 coins (14 worn bronzes; 4504 radiates and imitations). Imitations account for approximately 44% of the coins in the hoard of which 2.8% were minimi. Silver weight: 1219.4-16076.0 g.

The hoard comprised 2000 coins of 'copper, silver alloy and silver'. In the report compiled by P. Ilarregui the hoard contained pieces of the emperors: Pius Gordianus, Philip, Trajan Decius, Trebonianus Gallus, Volusian, Gallienus, Saloninus (Caesar), Saloninus (Emperor) and Postumus. A small selection of 10 coins was sent to the Real Academia de la Historia.
disposition: Real Academia de la Historia, Madrid, Spain (10 coins)

summary: (+200) sestertii: Septimius Severus 2, Severus Alexander 12: Nerva - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235)
(+hundreds) 94 denarii and antoniniani: Caracalla - Valerian I (AD 253-259); silver weight: 118.9-243.0 g

It is not certain whether there were one or two hoards. The hoard(s) seems to have comprised between 100,000 and 380,000 coins: Mark Antony - Maximinus I Thrax. Two hoards were found in a short period of time, 40 m from one another in January 1936 in March 1936.
disposition: National Museum, Niš (3,941); National Museum, Belgrade, Serbia (3,123); Archaeological Museum, Zagreb, Croatia (4,096); National Museum, Ljubljana, Slovenia (c. 830); National Museum, Prague, Czechia (15,000); Šipuš collection (64 coins);

summary: The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 2,600 antoniniani (radiates) from Caracalla to Postumus with a tpq of AD 263.
16 silver coins: 4 denarii, 12 antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla - Postumus (AD 260-269).
A possible hoard (or part of a hoard) of 40 sestertii from Trajan to Valerian I (AD 253-254)?
The hoard was found with several fragments of a red-orange ceramic vessel which presumably was its original container.

942 coins: 1 aureus (Caracalla) mounted in a necklace, 939 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani: Vespasian to Philip I, and 2 bronze coins (missing today). The hoard comprised gold (600 g) as well and silver jewellery (400 g), a shallow silver dish and a silver salt box.
Circa 2,000 antoniniani (radiates) of Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268).
The hoard comprised 2,186 antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I and 'other emperors of the same century.'

49 coins: 2 denarii, 7 antoniniani, 40 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); 28 provincial bronze coins of Marcianopolis and Nicopolis ad Istrum: Septimius Severus - Gordian III; silver weight: 12.1-19.7 g.
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing 600 coins. They are described as being base silver coins from Caracalla to Gordian III. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of between 751.3g and 1558.7g
The hoard comprised 252 denarii and radiates from Commodus to Quietus with a tpq of AD 260. It was found in two ceramic vessels.
1258 silver coins: Vespasian - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 1623.4-3383.4 g.
c. 50 antoniniani (radiates): Postumus (AD 260-269).
29 antoniniani (radiates) found buried under the floor and covered with a tegula: Gallienus (sole) - Divus Claudius II (AD 270).
21 silver coins: 9 denarii, 12 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus (Geta Caesar) - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).

summary: The hoard comprised 40 sestertii and dupondii or asses from Trajan to Gordian III. They were accompanied by a small copper-alloy figurine. The hoard was found by a worker in a vineyard in a semi-circular niche hollowed out of the rock.
244 silver coins: 117 denarii, 127 antoniniani: Nero - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253). Found in a bronze vessel.
155 silver coins: Vespasian - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 216.6-451.6 g.
(+38) 38 antoniniani (radiates): Aurelian - Probus (AD 276-282); silver weight: 7.9-46.6 g.
(?) 112 silver coins: 17 denarii, 95 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Valerian I (AD 257-258); silver weight: c. 875.6-1818.9 g
disposition: Town Museum Marienmont, Morlanwelz-Marienmont, Belgium (109 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 'approximately 510 ancient coins including Iron Age Gallic coins and approximately 500 denarii and antoniniani (radiates).' The hoard was immediately dispersed in Rouen. The hoard poses some problems of interpretation. The wife and son of the finder claimed that the coins were discovered in an ancient shipwreck, whereas Gaillard saw them as 'a precious collection of Roman coins gathered together by generations of citizens from Juliobona'

In 1946 during peat digging the find was discovered in a marsh, between St. Annen and Lunden. The find consisted of a wooden box (not preserved) containing a small silver vessel (destroyed) with 9 pearls, one sestertius of Antoninus Pius, rolls of 23 denarii (Antoninus Pius - Caracalla), and 2 small bronze rings.
31 billon tetradrachms of Alexandria: Valerian I and Gallienus - Aurelian (AD 272-273) found in a pottery jar during excavations beneath the floor in room of a house.

According to Liger, the hoard comprised a black ceramic vessel containing 62 coins of the Early Empire. However, according to Barbe, there were 15 coins discovered in the vessel including one of Claudius II. TAF notes that Liger often exaggerated his descriptions of hoards.
The hoard was placed next to the skull of a skeleton in an inhumation grave and comprised 33 small bronzes antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
