The hoard comprised a ceramic urn containing an unknown number of third century Roman coins stuck together with corrosion products. They were found on the site of an Iron Age oppidum. 141 coins: Septimius Severus - Quintillus (AD 270)
Hoard of 109 gold stateri of Sauromates II found during the excavations (AD 205-206)
357 silver coins: 154 denarii, 203 antoniniani: Hadrian - Philip (AD 244-247); silver weight: 470.8-965.3 g.
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Burgas, Bulgaria

summary: 9234 denarii, 3 Lycian drachms and 1 drachm of Caesarea in Cappadocia ranging from the Republic to Severus Alexander, found in 1998 and 2000. The vast majority of the coins are from the mint of Rome, though 10% of the coins from the reign of Septimius Severus were from mints of the East of the Empire.
NMR record of a small radiate hoard of 8 coins found whilst building a house in Keighley in the late nineteenth century.
Silver: 3 denarii, 208 antoniniani (radiates): Severus Alexander - Diocletian/Galerius (Caesar) (AD 293); silver weight: 43.8-497.0g.
disposition: Landesmuseum Niederösterreich, St. Pölten (in 1977 in Wien), Austria

summary: The hoard was found mixed in with earth, without an obvious container. The excavators suggested an organic bag.

A hoard of 788 tetradrachms (Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallus), denarii (Julia Mamaea) and antoniniani (Caracalla - Gallienus) found during the excavations at Dura Europos, in a jar under the embankment beside the Palmyra Gate.

7,426 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Victorinus (AD 270-271); silver weight: 1783.8-13513.7 g.. It is not clear whether this hoard was part of the deposit found on the site in the nineteenth century, or whether it represents a separate hoard on the same site. The hoard was found during rescue excavations by the Direction des Antiquités Historiques des Pays de la Loire after an individual found coins scattered on the ground surface on several occasions on the site of a Gallo-Roman villa.
(c. 7 kg) 300 silver coins: Hadrian - Maximian I (A284-293); silver weight: 56.7-852.5 g.
The hoard comprised 150 antoniniani (radiates), of which 129 survive from Philip I to Claudius II/Victorinus. This is one of four hoards from the site. Silver weight: 31.3-233.2g.
175 antoniniani entered museum collection in Kardzhali: Gordian III - Philip I (AD 244-249). No further information.

The hoard containing over 193 specimens dated from Tiberius to Caracalla was found in 1992. It included slashed coins, coins transformed into ornaments, and an unknown number of imitations. Unfortunately, the find was never published.
Group of 5 coins discovered in an ancient cellar: 4 double sestertii of Postumus, 1 imitation of antoninianus (radiate) of Victorinus (AD 269-271).

The hoard was found in 1989 in a field near Chalfont St Peter. The coins were contained in four pots, of which pots I, II and III were buried close together, and pot IV at a distance of four metres. The total number of coins in the hoard was 6,682: 15 bronze coins, 45 denarii, 2511 antoniniani of the Central Empire, 3560 antoniniani of the Gallic Empire, 197 irregular coins, and 354 uncertain coins.
disposition: British Museum (part); Bucks. County Museum, Aylesbury (part)

summary: Hoard of circa 4,000 coins. 400 coins entered the collection of Gh. Georgescu-Corabia, including issues of Pupienus, Gordian III and Philip I.
7 antoniniani: Tacitus - Carinus (AD 283-284)

find_spot_name: SIRACUSA, EX VIGNA CASSIA, PRIMA TOMBA (GRUZZOLO B)
summary: Hoard in grave, 13 antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus (sole) - Quintillus/Aurelian (Divus Claudius II) (AD 270-275).
600 imperial and provincial bronzes found in a ceramic vessel during excavation work. Dr. Harlanov has examined 384 pieces: Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-249).
(250) 180 silver coins: Hadrian - Gordian III (AD 238-244); silver weight: 314.1-710.9g.
disposition: Museum of Slavonia Osijek, Croatia (250 coins) - 1981

summary: The hoard comprised a coarseware vessel containing 196 bronze coins from Trajan to Valerian and Gallienus and a small silver bracelet.

The hoard comprised a redware ceramic vessel containing more than 200 silver coins (denarii and antoniniani (radiates) of which 185 were catalogued by A. Dubiez: Hadrian - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver weight: 251.6-568.4g.
disposition: A denarius of Macrinus was acquired for the Claudius Côte Collection in Lyon.

summary: 50 silver coins, 10 seen: Caracalla - Trajan Decius (AD 250-251).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.no. CLXIV in 1957

summary: It is alleged that more than 3 kg of coins were found. 34 denarii: Galba - Elagabalus (AD 218-222); silver weight: 67.2-111.4 g.

The hoard comprised a coarseware vessel containing 600 coins, apparently antoniniani (radiates). A further 9 coins were recovered from the bed of a small stream that ran into the pond. These coins were of the same emperors as those contained in the hoard.
21 denarii: Republic - Severus Alexander (AD 233-235).
3 aurei: Trajan, Septimius Severus, Caracalla (AD 213).
874 antoniniani (radiates) found in a ceramic vessel: Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
229 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I and Gallienus - Diocletian (AD 284-293).
disposition: Museum of Pavia, Coin Room (inv.nos. 4.54, 4.59, 4.82, 4.101-4.866 not always in sequential order)

summary: Between 1,500 and 3,000 coins found in a ceramic vessel. 185 coins seen: Julia Domna to Tetricus II Silver: c.1,500 coins; Silver weight: c.287.4-3897.6g.
Uncertain originally number of coins. 66 silver coins: 6 denarii, 60 antoniniani (radiates): Antoninus Pius - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253); silver weight: 84.9-171.3 g.
The find consists of 10 late Roman bronze coins (Tetricus, and other Gallic emperors), found in the area of the 'Kulturhaus am Hexenturm'
(896) 890 silver coins: Septimius Severus - Trebonianus Gallus (Ad 251-253).
Three coins found on surface one next to the other (AD 260-274).

The hoard was found hidden in the hollow base of a statue and comprised coins of Postumus, Victorinus, Tetricus, Claudius II, Probus and Tacitus. The nummus of Constantine I/Gratian, probably, a intruder.

The hoard is composed of 10 poorly preserved Antonine bronzes. It was found during three archaeological(?) surveys of Noires-Terres in the Bois-en-Ardres in February 1980, at the end of 1981 and in early 1982) and interpreted as the remains of a dispersed hoard, as they were all found in the same place.

A hoard of 551 coins, found in a drainage ditch on farmland half a mile from Llanarmon Dyffryn Geiriog, Denbighshire. Of these, 507 coins (502 denarii and 5 antoninianii, ranging from Mark Antony to Severus Alexander) are now in the British Museum. Three further coins were reported in 1929, but the remaining ones are lost.
(53) 50 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
Unknown initial number of coins. 18 antoniniani (radiates) are kept in a private collection: Gallienus - Quintillus (AD 270).
"Few hundreds" Roman coins found in a field. Only 33 coins provided some information and some of them have been entered to the level of the coin. The precision is not certain.

in 1917, the museum received a small bronze container without lid that was said to have contained 18 coins (antoniniani, Gallienus to Tetricus), and probably found in Mainz-Kastel. The coins are lost.
340 denarii: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 202-210).

465 AE radiates to AD 289. This debased radiate hoard was clearly quite scattered as it was found with late Roman bronzes of other periods. The material from Valerian to the Tetrici seems to form a discrete group, with the coins of Carausius also regarded as part of this hoard.
circa 150 denarii, 30 preserved. Nero-Seveus Alexander (AD 227). 1 nummus of Constantius II is an intruder.

The hoard comprised two separate deposits. The first contained 28 sestertii, dupondii and asses from Trajan to Postumus. The second contained 622 radiates from Philip I to Victorinus with a tpq of AD 270. The circumstances of discovery means that a clear relationship between the two hoards cannot be established with any certainty.

The hoard comprised a whiteware vessel containing approximately 2,000 'small bronzes.' These are considered to have been antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla - Postumus). The latest coins (E332,334 and 336) were struck in Cologne in AD 263. Archives of Musée des Antiquités de Rouen: Inventory III, p. 78, no. 2316 (12.06.1912)
298 provincial bronze coins found within the ruins of an ancient settlement: Commodus - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria, inv.no. 3634 (262 coins - 218 were stolen)

summary: 500 provincial bronze coins. N. Mouchmov saw 6 of them: Marcianopolis: Septimius Severus 2, Macrinus 1, Elagabalus 1, Severus Alexander 1; Nicopolis ad Istrum: Macrinus 1
(c. 300,000) silver coins: 1 denarius, 4,463 antoniniani/radiates: Marcus Aurelius - Tacitus (AD 275-276).
A hoard of 13+ Roman coins (Caracalla - Gallienus), found after 1850 during house construction in Cottbus.
Three denarii were found in a ceramic vessel: Julia Domna 1, Severus Alexander 1, Julia Mamaea 1 (AD 222-235).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2724

summary: 385 antoniniani (radiates found in a ceramic vessel: Elagabalus - Aurelian (AD 274); silver weight: 90.9-998.6 g.
17 sestertii and middle bronzes from Augustus to Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
261 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel: Valerian I and Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282).

Around 500 radiates (Valerian I to Diocletian) found by a workman in a rock crevice inside a coal mine near Aberkenfig. The coins were apparently lying on a fragment of decayed cloth, suggesting a container. Three different lists of this hoard exist, totalling c. 530, 500 and 492 coins. The list here follows the one given by Robertson, based on the 492 coins deposited at the National Museum Cardiff.
313 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268).

A hoard of 653 denarii (Mark Antony – Geta) and 1 drachm of Caesarea in Cappadocia (Trajan), found in a garden at Muswell Hill in 1928, together with a silver spoon and a bronze ring, and pieces of the earthenware pot which had contained them.
(+1000) 92 antoniniani: Gordian - Valerian I (AD 253-259
disposition: Archaeological Museum Zagreb, Croatia (63 coins); dispersed -1981

summary: The hoard comprised a greyware vessel or 'olla' containing approximately 2,000 antoniniani (radiates) or nummi, of which 1863 were recorded by Léon Coutil. The hoard was found in a gravel quarry at the edge of the road to Bacqupuis, close to two ancient wells.
11 denarii from Lucius Verus to Elagabalus/Severus Alexander (one denarius of Julia Soaemias is a hybrid with a reverse of Severus Alexander). Found during the excavation of the cathedral apse
The hoard comprised 5,200, 1 denarius and antoniniani (radiates) found with ceramiv vessel: Maximinus I Tharx -Diocletian and Maximian I (before AD 294).
101 coins: 21 denarii, 74 antoniniani, 6 provincial bronzes: Marcus Aurelius (Lucius Verus) - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2780

summary: The hoard comprised 180 tetradrachms (Nero-Macrinus), 22 denarii (Septimius Severus-Geta), and 35 bronze coins (Alexander Severus-Philip I). Details for 145 of the coins have been published.

Over 3,000 antoniniani (radiates) (8 kg) found with a amphora-like vessel. The largest number of coins belongs to Postumus. Other issuers: Valerian I, Gallienus, Salonina. An Alexander is mentioned among issuers, Severus Alexander (?).
53 coins (denarii, ranging from Nero to Macrinus) found in a bag, north of the Fort Stahlberg, within the perimeter of the city's hospital.
86 denarii found in a ceramic vessel: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
An Antoninianus of Gordian III, discovered along with 10 other similar coins in 1909 during the construction of the Baumgartenbridge over the Havel-Schielow lake.
Recorded by the Somerset Levels Project. Hoard comprised just 3 radiates, found during peat digging. No archaeological context.
Unknown initial number of coins. 6 antoniniani of Trebonianus Gallus are kept in the Regional History Museum Vidin (AD 251-253).
disposition: Regional History Museum Vidin, Bulgaria; inv. no. 11759-11764

summary: The hoard was found in two boxes next to a lead coffin in a Gallo-Roman cemetery. The boxes contained masses of radiates and included amongst them, issues of Postumus and Tetricus I. Found in a sandpit.
Gold and silver coins found together with tableware, two gold bracelets and rings in a lead chest. At least two aurei of Philip and Gallienus. Gold: 2+ coins; Gold weight: 10.2g+;

The hoard comprised a cylindrical copper-alloy vessel containing 450 bronze coins, of which the majority were sestertii. Not all the coins were identified but those that were dated from the reign of Domitian to that of Severus Alexander.
167 silver coins: 39 denarii, 128 antoniniani: Marcus Aurelius - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv.no. CXLI

summary: Circa 95 antoniniani (radiates). Dembski 1977 gives the evidence for 89: Trebonianus Gallus - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver weight: 26.6-117.8g.

The hoard was found in a coarseware vessel which was broken. It comprised a block of Roman silver and bronze coins which had been stuck together with corrosion products. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of 249.6-505.0 g.
The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing approximately 300 sestertii from Hadrian to Septimius Severus.
Few hundred coins. Only 98 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) are recovered: Elagabalus - Gallienus (sole) (AD 267-268).
14 denarii (late Republic to Severus Alexander) were found in 1906 in front of the door sill of cellar 83 (in the Roman settlement).

A hoard of 14 coins, found in sector SO-XIII, in the area of the vicus surrounding the Roman fort of Apsaros. The coins were 8 silver coins of Caesarea in Cappadocia (Hadrian to Caracalla) and 6 bronzes from Trapezus (Marcus Aurelius to Alexander Severus). All coins were burnt.
27 antoniniani: Elagabalus - Philip I (AD 244-249).

The hoard comprised 606 radiates from Balbinus to Postumus with a tpq of approximately AD 263. The hoard contains official issues up until Postumus' Issue 1c (AD 261) but there are two radiates which copy coins of AD 263. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of between 141.2 and 1222.6g.
128 provincial bronze coins: Antoninus Pius - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 1022-1141

summary: 16 bronze coins found in a destruction layer scattered on a very small area: Claudius I - Gordian III (AD 241-244).

A hoard of ca. 677 provincial coins, ranging from Commodus Caesar to the joint reign of Valerian and Gallienus (AD 253-60), found in the sanctuary of Apollo Smintheion. Coins were mainly minted in Alexandria Troas (665 coins), but also in Parium (6 coins) and Abydus (1 coin). Çizmeli connects the deposition of this hoard with the invasions of the Goths in Asia Minor.
disposition: Laboratoire du Musée des Civilisations Anatoliennes, Ankara, Turkey

summary: The hoard comprised originally ca. 2,400 coins (2,384 coins were mentioned in 1960), of which a small proportion has been lost. The coins were found in a copper-alloy vessel. 2 denarii and 2,302 radiates (incl. 7 imitations) ranging from Valerian and Gallienus to Diocletian have now been published. Tpq is AD 293.

In 1978, Mr. Charles Pire, a coin dealer from Brussels, bought about 500 pieces from a lot of 972 coins found in the region of Amiens. It consisted generally of about fifteen antoniniani (radiates) of Gallienus and Salonina, a dozen of Postumus, a hundred of Victorinus, around 20 of Claudius II, about 300 of Tetricus I and II from the mints of Trier and Cologne. Other 30 pieces consisted of imitations of Tetricus I, large module. 235 coins are presented in detail: Trebonianus Gallus - Tetricus I (AD 271-273); silver weight: 185.7-1213.9 g.
disposition: Private collections: Ms. A. Wattecamps; Mr. S. Genvier; Mr. J.-M. Doyen; Mr. Pire

summary: 462 coins, mostly provincial issues of Caesarea in Cappadocia (150 coins) and imperial bronzes (130 coins), other bronze provincial issues and some imperial silver, closing with Gordian III, found in a deposit associated with the mid-third-century destruction of Zeugma.
c. 200 Alexandrian tetradrachms. 'Probably a whole hoard, offered for sale in Belgium.'
27 silver coins: denarii and antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 34.3-69.1 g

In 1951, 119 Roman bronze coins of Claudius II, Tetricus I and II were found under a heavy slab of stone while clearing wasteland. Almost all are imitations, possibly produced nearby as most are also mint fresh.

116 coins found in 1870 close to Moneybury Hill, with articles of metal, animal remains, and broken Roman pottery. The coins range from the first half of the 1st century AD to ca. AD 270 and included 2 denarii, 8 antoniniani, 78 bronze and 28 cast coins. These coins could have formed two separate hoards (one consisting of AE up to ca. AD 249; the other ranging down to AD 270).

A hoard of 34,000 coins (100 kg), comprising large numbers of antoniniani from the period of the 'Gallic Empire' (AD 260-274), found in two storage ceramic vessels. A few denarii were also recorded. Coins range from Hadrian to Probus (276-282).

A hoard of 358 tetradrachms (Septimius Severus - Philip II), denarii (Crispina - Gordian III) and antoniniani (Julia Donna - Trebonianus Gallus) from Dura Europos, found in a common-ware jar near the citadel.
67 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III to Diocletian (AD 284-293).

Depression F2409. Contained 12 re-deposited (curated?) Palaeolithic flint handaxes in gravel at bottom of feature, also 3 3rd C. coins. Then an octagonal stone font inserted. After font fell out of use, depression filled with series of black upper fills, poss. derived from midden material, containing large quantities of animal bone, oyster shell & pottery; but also objects incl. a silver pin, a copper alloy enamelled fitting, decorative strips & frags. of finger & ear rings & bracelets (some chopped up), pins, copper beads, door fittings, and an iron latch lifter, hand saw, auger & trowel, an iron wool carding comb, a stone cult figure, & 32 4th C. coins
749 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I and Gallienus - Carinus (AD 284).

c. 1300 billon provincial coins of Alexandria: Vespasian - Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-261). 'Common terracotta vase buried in a fairly deep hole, dug out in the sandstone. Found during excavations for a monumental tomb in the Armenian cemetery.'
The hoard comprised 1,147 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) from Septimius Severus to Gallienus (AD 260-268).
2669 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver weight: 721.6-3335.3 g.
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. CLVII

summary: 12,000 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) - 33 Kilos - found with ceramic vessel: Antoninus Pius - Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268).
Unknown originally number of coins. 19 pieces are known - 7 denarii, 12 antoniniani (radiates): Commodus - Filip I (AD 244-247).
An uncertain number of coins. Only two denarii of Caracalla were identified.

306 coins: 255 antoniniani (radiates), 50 denarii, 1 sestertius: Antoninus Pius - Gallienus (AD 253-268). Together, were found jewelry: 2 silver rings, 1 pair of gold earrings and 1 gold children’s earring.
Hoard of 600 coins of Sauromates I, Cotys II, Eupator, Sauromates II, Rhescuporis III, Cotys III.

find_spot_name: CANTERBURY, MARLOWE CAR PARK AREA M II
summary: Marlowe Car Park Area M II, scattered hoard of 119 coins, found in flood silts sealing Structure R22. Contains coins of Constantine & Valentinian (intrusive), but also of Carausius, Gallienus & barbarous radiates, latter make up approx.. half of group.

The hoard comprised an unknown number of Roman coins, which was divided in two by the finder. One part was melted down and used to make buttons, chains and a watch. The other part included 3 sestertii and 5 radiates from Trajan to Trajan Decius. It is possible that this hoard is part of one known as Lusigny A.
Hoard of 1,040 silver coins (?) found in a small ceramic vessel of which only 394 silver coins are known: Vespasian - Philip I (AD 247-249).
disposition: Museum, Panagyurishte; Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria

summary: This hoard of twenty three coins was found in 1928, and it consists mostly of cast imitations of the second-century aurei. Many of them are mould-linked.
370 Roman provincial bronze coins of the 3rd century AD. No further infiormation.

The hoard comprised two aurei of Commodus, some silver denarii and an unknown number of bronze denominations. A further three solidi, including one of Constantine I and one of Constans, as well as a poorly described issue were also found although it is to be doubted whether they formed part of the hoard.
(1430) 976 denarii: Nero - Severus Alexander (AD 222-228). Found together with silverware and jewelry.
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria (976 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised approximately 400 coins (although Ledru states the total was more than 1400 coins - an error?). Hucher compiled an inventory of 260 sestertii which were bought by the Musée du Mans Found in a field on the Villeneuve farm. Hollard gives a total number of 280 coins: Vespasian - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Musée archéologique du Mans, France (1892) - 260 coins

summary: 2,382 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver weight: 644.1-2976.5 g.
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles, Bruxelles, Belgium (110 coins and fragments and casts); collection Meire, in 1950

summary: The hoard comprised 57 radiates recovered by excavators from the Touring Club de France in 1966. To these it is possible to add another 40 coins of the same date found at the same findspot in 1899 and likely to be part of the hoard. The hoard was found on two separate occasions. The first coins were found in 1899. The circumstances of their discovery are unknown. A second group of coins were then discovered during an archaeological excavation in 1966. Silver: 9, 48 coins; Silver weight: 2.7
A hoard of 1,016 of coins was found with an amphora. The majority of coins were bronze issues of the Bosporus kingdom. A billon antoninianus (radiate) of Gordian III was found among the coins.
disposition: Institute of Archaeology of the Academy of Sciences, Simferopol

summary: Mints are quantified but not allocated to issues. 28 Cologne, 15 Rome, 3 Milan: Gordian III - Victorinus (AD 269-271).
Total amount of coins is unknown. The hoard contains 1 denarius and 236 antoniniani (radiates): Caracalla - Valerian I (AD 253-260).
1,545 coins: 1 denarius, 1544 antoniniani (radiates): Trajan - Tetricus I (AD 271-273).

The hoard comprised several hundred coins of which only 150 were catalogued. They included a dupondius of Marcus Aurelius, a denarius of Plautilla, a few denarii and radiates of Caracalla, Geta, Elagabalus and Maximinus, numerous radiates of Gordian III, as well as Philip I, Trebonianus Gallus, Aemilian, Valerian I and II, Saloninus, Salonina, numerous examples of Gallienus, and some of Postumus.
Large hoard of 160 denarii found in Præstemosen ("the Priests Bog") in the town of Gudme, close to a pond. The hoard had been totally ploughed up.
146 antoniniani (radiates) found with a ceramic vessel: Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269); silver weight: 40.4-181.5g.
Within an ancient settlement was found a deposit of iron tools. Beneath were discovered 280 silver and bronze coins. The latest one from the mid-3rd century AD. No further information.
The hoard comprised 36 silver coins - antoniniani (radiates) - of Gordian III to Postumus and 6 copper-alloy coins from Trajan to Faustina II.
508 silver coins: 19 denarii, 489 denarii: Septimius Severus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
A hoard of 7 antoniniani (Gallienus and Claudius II), found in a destruction layer of Monument H in the Sanctuary of Poseidon and Amphitrite.
1,361 coins: 451 antoniniani (radiates), 909 denarii, 1 as: Vespasian - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 257-258). Found with a limestone mortarium.

Over 500 coins were discovered on a parcel by a collector. G. Dembski have seen 68 denarii. Other scholars (Al. Ruske) expressed some doubts about these coins being part of a hoard: Hadrian - Severus alexander (AD 230).
The hoard comprised 50 antoniniani (radiates) from Victorinus, Tetricus I and Tetricus II.
14 silver coins: 13 denarii, 1 antoninianus: Antoninus Pius - Gordian III (AD 238-244); silver weight: 20.8-37 g.
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2247

summary: Around 50 antoniniani were discovered. Coins were issued by Gordian III, Philip I, Philip I for Otacilia Severa, and Valerian I (AD 253-259).

The hoard comprised a total of either 5027 (according to Vlachogianni) or 5044 coins (previous reports). These include radiates from Caracalla to Gallienus and Salonina and 1 Roman Provincial bronze of Augustus from Sparta.
Hoard of 12-15 kilos of coins - 5,500 pieces - found with a ceramic vessel. Only 270 were recovered: Trebonianus Gallus (Volusian Augustus) - Cludius II (AD 268-270).
The hoard comprised 327 sestertii and 3 dupondii from Galba to Severus Alexander with a tpq of AD 233.
28 sestertii: 15 Severus Alexander, 13 Gordian III found in the Dominican convent area.
195 silver coins: 102 denarii, 93 antoniniani: Commodus - Philip (AD 246); silver weight: 232.3-420.8 g.
disposition: County Museum Gorj, Tg. Jiu, Romania; Ion Luben collection, Bucharest (3 coins)

summary: Over 2,897 antoniniani (radiates): Treboninaus Gallus - Claudius II (AD 268-270).
disposition: Landesmuseum Joanneum, Graz, Austria (for restoration work - in 1977)

summary: The hoard comprised fragments of a greyware vessel containing 90 sestertii from Trajan to Postumus with a tpq of AD 261.
+1000 silver coins, according to Gerov, B. 640 studied: Elagabalus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 800.6-1662.9 g.
disposition: Regional Museum of History, Stara Zagora, Bulgaria

summary: 35 coins (3 sestertii, 9 radiates and 23 Provincial coins from Athens. The Athenian coins range from the time of Augustus to Gallienus), that were part of a larger find made in the region of Corinth (?). Its composition is similar to the hoards from Eleusis.
7 antoniniani (radiates) of Aurelian found in a grave with a skeleton (AD 270-275).
Unknown initial number of provincial bronze coins. 520 coins have been examined by Dr. Haralanov and 468 described: Commodus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 1962/1-30 (30 coins)

summary: Unknown initial number of coins. 86 silver coins seen: 58 denarii, 28 antoniniani: Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver weight: 117.6-231 g.
Hoard of antoniniani (radiates). Only 30 coins were seen: Gallienus (sole) - Maximian I (AD 284-293)
47 coins - 1 antoninianus (radiate), 45 sestertii, 1 as - found with a ceramic vessel in a Roman villa: Antoninus Pius - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 258-259).
The hoard was enclosed or set within a square-cut stone and comprised 11 antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I and Gallienus to Postumus (including E.384 and E.385).

Unknown originally number of coins found with a linen or leather bag placed in a bronze vessel. Only 12 antoniniani (radiates) are known: Aurelian - Carus/Carinus (AD 283-285). Probably, part of the hoard VALHASCOS 1880-1890.
disposition: Museu Nacional de Arqueologia, Lisboa, Portugal

summary: The hoard comprised 119 antoniniani (radiates). However, only 109 are preserved in the Museo Arqueológico Provincial de Tarragona as 10 were lost during successive renovations of the museum: Gallienus - Quintillus for Claudius II (Divus).
The hoard comprised two black ceramic vessels containing approximately 20,000 coins from Gallienus to Carinus (AD 283-285).
2 antoniniani (radiates) of unknown issuer. According to the NUMIS the tpq is around AD 256.
376 silver coins from Elagabalus to Gordian III (AD 238-244). Found in a cooking pot together with silver brooches, bracelets, fingerings, chain.
disposition: Brukenthal Museum, Sibiu, Romania; mixed with the rest of museum collection; National History Museum of Romania, Bucharest; jewelry.

summary: NA
25 provincial bronze coins found in a ceramic vessel: Antoninus Pius - Severus Alerxander (AD 222-235). Mints: Nicopolis ad Istrum, Marcianopolis

29 Roman silver coins found at Chew Stoke, ranging from Republican denarii to the 3rd century AD. This may be the hoard mentioned by Rahtz (1957, 114) as having been found on Pagan's Hill by its then owner Mr Gray in 1870, though 40-50 silver coins were found. Very wide date spread, which may indicate a shrine or temple in use for a long time rather than a specific hoard (EG).
Found during excavations in the pars urbana of the Roman villa rustica of Osterfingen, below an ash layer. 18 sestertii, Antoninus Pius, Faustina, Marcus Aurelius, Severus Alexander, Maximinus Thrax.
24 coins: 1 antoninianus (radiate), 22 sestertii and 1 dupondius. The latest coin is a sestertius of Trajan Decius for Herennia Etruscilla (Augusta) (AD 249-251).
Two aurei found in a lead sarcophagus: Trajan Decius, Tacitus (AD 275-276).
An unknown number of silver coins: 1 denarius, 16 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2631

summary: The hoard comprised a coarseware vessel containing silver and billon coins (denarii and antoniniani (radiates). Although the hoard was immediately dispersed, 183 coins were examined by M. Le Pesant: Antoninus Pius - Postumus (AD 260-269)
718 coins: 2 denarii, 2 quinarii, 667 antoniniani (radiates), 3 sestertii/double sestertii: Elagabalus - Postumus (AD 262-265); silver weight: 203.3-1735.5g.

The hoard comprised a black ceramic jug containing 8,500 coins (22kg). A list of types that would interest collectors was produced. Fillon notes that coins of Gallienus, Victorinus, Tetricus I and Claudius II made up the majority of the hoard and that were about 20 coins of Aurelian. There was a radiate of Victorinus with a IOVI CONSERVATORI reverse copying an issue of Aurelian in that it reproduced the officina mark P for Milan. The hoard was found by a farmer in his field. The vessel was kept in the Collection de Rouchebrune. Fillon bought the coins for the Soc. Antiq. Ouest.
100 provincial bronze coins entered the museum collection in Shumen: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 13604/1-100 (100 coins)

summary: 4500 antoniniani: Gordian III - Tacitus (AD 276).
disposition: Musée Chambéry, France, 1344 coins, Musée Château d'Annecy, France, Registre d'entrées, II, nos. 6480-6482, 9046 (137 coins and one vessel); Musée d'Art et d'Histoire de Genève, Switzerland

summary: During the drainage of a moor several small Roman coins were unearthed. The names of six emperors are mentioned. Some coins seem to be plated.
Unknown original number of coins. Only 10 pieces were recovered: 8 denarii, 1 antoninianus (radiate), 1 plated denarius: Trajan - Gordian III (AD 241-243).

Over 120 silver coins. Among issuers: Gordian III, Philip I (Marcia Otacilia, Philip II), Trajan Decius and Trajan Decius (Herennia Etruscilla). Three coins were bought by the Coin Room of the National History Museum in Bucharest.
disposition: National History Museum, Bucharest, Romania (3 coins)

summary: 195 Roman imperial bronze coins: 192 sestertii, 3 dupondii/asses: Trajan - Gallienus (AD 260-268).
Unknown initial number of coins. 264 Roman provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Vratsa, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 9811-10060

summary: 84 sestertii and 1 forgery: Trajan - Elagabalus (AD 218-222).
The hoard comprised 70 antoniniani (radiates) imitations of Tetricus I and II.
6 coins: 4 bronze republican (!), 1 denarius Nero, 1 antoninianus (radiate) Aurelian (AD 270-275).
Sometime before 1869, somewhere in the vicinity of Nantes, a hoard comprising several hundreds antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I and Tetricus II was discovered.
The hoard comprised 8 antoniniani (radiates) of Gallienus' joint reign and Postumus with a tpq of AD 260 to 269. FMRL suggests that it was a small part of a much larger hoard.
Unknown silver coins. 45 coins were bought by the museum in Traismauer. One of the coins is an anotninianus of Probus.
A small ceramic vessel with 6 silver coins: 2 denarii, 4 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2601

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. 72 antoniniani (radiates) were available for study: Valerian I and Gallienus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).
(circa 80) 26 silver coins: 3 denarii, 23 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
disposition: Muzeul de Istorie a Județului Vâlcea, Râmnicu Vâlcea, Romania;

summary: 363 silver coins which were first placed in a bag and then in a ceramic vessel: Marcus Aurelius - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2205

summary: 149 Roman provincial silver and bronze coins found with a bag during archaeological excavations: 10 silver coins (4 didrachms, 6 drachms) of Caesarea in Cappadocia, ranging from Hadrian to Septimius Severus; 139 bronze provincial coins of Trapezus, ranging from Commodus (?, or Septimius Severus?) to Philip I (certainly AD 244/5, as this is the last time Trapezus produces coins). Authors disagree on the identification of the coins of Trapezus. These are badly preserved and were never published in detail. The list given here follows Kropotkin, as given in Depeyrot's translation. Golenko has a slightly different breakdown, including the mention of 4 coins of Clodius Albinus, allegedly from Trapezus. Kapanadze and Golenko also list 7 coins of Commodus, though these were grouped with Septimius Severus as uncertain by Kropotkin. The list provided in Tsotelia / Depeyrot 2010 does not offer further clarifications.
161 coins: 19 denarii and antoniniani, 142 provincial bronzes: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 4428-4588

summary: More than 1,500 coins were discovered in a bowl. However, only 77 pieces are known in any detail, 5% of the original hoard: Caracalla - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 258-259).

Around 5,000 antoniniani (radiates), 13.5 kg. The majority of coins belonged to Tetricus I and Tetricus II. Other issuers: Gallienus, Salonina, Victorinus, Postumus, Marius, Cludius II, Quintillus, Quintillus (Divus Cludius II), Aurelian.
108 antoniniani: Gordian III - Postumus (AD 265-266); silver weight: 26.4-195.3 g.
1,486 tetradrahms of Alexandria: Aurelian - Diocletian-Maximian (AD 295-296) in a disintegrated cloth bag on the floor of underground room J during excavations of a house.
The hoard was concealed under three stone slabs. There was no evidence of a container.
20 coins: 2 antoniniani (radiates), 18 sestertii: Trajan - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
The hoard comprised 120 sestertii from Vespasian to Philip I (AD 244-249).
15 bronze coins: 8 sestertii, 1 dupondius, 6 asses: Gaius (Agrippa) – Severus Alexander (AD 228).
disposition: Regional Museum, Hradec Králové, Czech Republic (inv.nos. N 2963-2977)

summary: Unknown number of silver coins found in a ceramic vessel. 105 pieces entered the museum collection in Plovdiv: 100 denarii, 5 antoniniani: Trajan - Gordian III (AD 243-244); silver weight: 148.6-305.1 g.
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2226, 105 coins

summary: 7 antoniniani (radiates) and 1 imitation: Claudius II - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
2211 silver coins: 10 denarii, 2201 antoniniani: Antoninus Pius (Diva FaustinaI) - Valerian I (AD 259); silver weight: 2765.1-5725.2g

1610 antoniniani and fragments of a ceramic vessel with lid: Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282). The coins were minted in Siscia, Sirmium, Serdica and other mints. The majority of the coins belong to Gallienus and Claudius II. Due to poor condition of reservation 157 coins could not be identified; silver weight: 244.1-1686.4 g.
disposition: Regional History Museum, Kyustendil, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 2731-4172, 4319-4414; 1,538 coins

summary: The hoard comprised one silver coin and 18 bronze coins dating from the 3rd c. AD, found close to Metsovo (BCH 1939). Touratsoglou mentions 18 sestertii (Maximinus Thrax - Gordian III), next to 1 denarius / antoninianus, with the find spot Anthochori. No further information available.

The hoard comprised approximately 1,200 sestertii 'of 25 emperors, caesars and empresses' from Vespasian to Gordian III, mostly in a corroded or worn condition. There was also a single unworn bronze of Postumus
273 denarii: Nero - Septimius Severus (AD 193-211).
Part of a larger hoard. 17 provincial bronze coins: Hadrian - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 1701-1718

summary: Unknown number of Roman provincial bronze coins were found in unknown circumstances. 38 pieces are kept in the museum collection in Ruse: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 22168-22205

summary: On July 28, 1937, a hoard of 1478 silver and 2 copper coins was found in Rochester Road, St. Anne's, Bristol, in a pit that was being dug for a garage. No trace of any container could be found, though careful search was made. The silver coins were 1476 denarii (Mark Antony to Septimius Severus) and two drachms (Caesarea in Cappadocia and Lycia). Please note that Pearce and Mattingly's coin summary lists 128 denarii of Hadrian and 66 of Faustina I, but the catalogue includes 126 Hadrianic denarii, and 68 denarii of Faustina I.
disposition: British Museum (part); City of Bristol Museum and Art Gallery (part)

summary: The hoard comprised a vessel containing approximately 2,000 small bronze coins of the Late Empire, including issues of Galerien [sic for Valerian], Gallienus, Claudius II and a considerable quantity of Tetricus I. A large number of coins were illegible. Blanchet mistakenly doubled the total of the coins in the hoard and placed it in the parish of Aubigné-Racan.
The hoard comprised 300 coins of Claudius II, along with finger rings and intaglios intended for finger rings. Found in a sewer.
disposition: Museu Nacional de Arqueologia, Lisboa, Portugal

summary: 112 silver coins found in a ceramic vessel with one handle: 34 antoniniani, 78 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv.no. 2745

summary: 7 antoniniani (radiates) of Postumus (AD 260-269).
1,764 coins, probably antoniniani (radiates), found with two ceramic vessels: Valerian I - Diocletian and Maximian I (AD 284-293).
758 coins from Augustus to Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268).
disposition: Medagliere del Museo Nazionale Romano, Roma, Italy

summary: Hoard was found at a brickworks called Les Caves du Roi, between the road from Paris to Calais and Estrées and on the route of the trainline towards Berck. Three sestertii were overstruck upon pieces of Antoninus Pius (1) and Marcus Aurelius (2). Together wuth These coins were found: a coin-die (!); a pickaxe (dolabra); a spearhead.
Hoard of 32 coins found with ceramic vessel: 21 denarii, 11 sestertii: Trajan - Severus alexander (AD 222-235).
Circa 100 provincial bronze coins minted in Nicopolis ad Istrum, Marcianopolis, Odessus, Tomis, Dionysopolis: Elagabalus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
The hoard contains in total 18 coins. 1 antoninianus, 17 denarii. Coins of Septimius Severus, Julia Mamea, Severus Alexander, Maximinus I Thrax, Philip I (AD 244-246).

The hoard was found in a copper-alloy vessel covered with a silver plate and comprised 73 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) vfrom Vespasian to Valerian I. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of between 55.4g and 208.8g.

The hoard comprised more than 35,000 antoniniani (Aurelian - Diocletian, all dating from before the reform of AD 294), found off the coast of Syrna at cape Fteni Punta. The hoard was found on a shipwreck (Syrna I) and has been interpreted as carrying wages or money for military expenses. The hoard was first found by a sponge diver, rescue excavations followed in 2002.
The hoard comprised 53 bronze coins dated between AD 69 and AD 247-249.
980 antoniniani (radiates) found in two lots, in 1962, 1980, in a ceramic vessel: Septimius Severus (Geta Caesar/Augustus) - Tetricus I (AD 272).
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles du Bibliotheque Nationale de France, Paris

summary: 17 antoniniani (radiates) found in the wall plaster of a domestic building: Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver weight: 5.6-20.3g.
431 coins: 295 denarii, 136 antoniniani: Commodus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 253); silver weight: 584.0-1024.5 g.
276 denarii found with a ceramic vessel: Marcus Aurelius - Gordian III (AD 241-243); silver weight: 387.6-713.7 g.
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles, Bruxelles, Belgium (3 coins); May 1967, 273 coins and the vessel

summary: 4 denarii, 1 antoninianus (radiate) and 3 sestertii were found with fragments of a 'terra nigra' pot. The sestertii were found above (ca. 30cm) the coin hoard.

A hoard of 15,000 - 20,000 coins, found ploughing a field at Riby Wold Farm on the east side of Lincolnshire Wolds, some 4-5 miles north-east of Caistor. The coins are all antoniniani, ranging from Gordian III to Probus, AD 281. Included were many coins of Gallienus, and of emperors from the Gallic Empire.
disposition: Lincoln City and County Museum (part: pot and 24 coins); Ashmoleum Museum (part)

summary: 6 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I - Victorinus (AD 269-271).
The hoard comprised 76 double sestertii, sestertii and asses from Domitian to Postumus (AD 260-268).
26 bronze coins. Among them, 1 billon coin of Alexandria for Diocletian.
26 antoniniani (radiates) found with traces of textile recipient: Aurelian - Carinus (AD 283-285).
disposition: Laboratory of Restoration of Soprintendenza Speciale per i Beni Archeologici di Roma (inv. nos. 508899-508924)

summary: 6 coins: 4 AE and 2 AR; Trajan-Elagabalus, with no further details currently available.

53 antoniniani (radiates) were found on Hosenstraße 4-5. They were purchased in 1903. "The coin series is so unified that it seems reasonable to accept it as a small hoard; the state of preservation is especially uniform."
Originally 164 coins, only 45 were identified: Valerian I and Gallienus - Tetrarchy (AD 299).
Antoniniani (radiates): Gallienus - Aurelian (AD 270-275).

3rd century. Roman fort at Watercrook S of Kendal was excav by Potter in 1975-5. In square stone guard chamber to NE gate of fort, one charcoal rich layer sandwiched in between two occupation layers/phases of use contained a 'large quantitity of objects' incl. pottery, bronze finger ring, arrowhead, calthrops, iron lock & building fittings, a surgical probe, & 4 coins close together. These dated to post-AD 268-273, & were of Claudius II, radiate copies of Victorinus, & Tetricus I. T.W. 1979. Romans in North-west England. Excavations at the Roman Forts of Ravenglass, Watercrook, and Bowness-on-Solway, pp. 158-160, figs. 60-61.
(235) 234 silver coins, denarii and antoniniani (radiates): Hadrian - Philip I; silver weight: 294.1-665.3 g.
The hoard comprised 292 denarii from Domitian to Maximinus (AD 238).
359 billon coins. Acquired by J.P. Six together with another two (?) hoards, consisting in Ptolemaic bronze coins and 178 Roman folles respectively.
Unknown originally number of denarii and antoniniani (radiates). Three coins are known: Hadrian denarius, Septimius Severus denarius, Philip I antoninianus (radiate).
18 antoniniani (radiates) found stuck together on the elbow of a skeleton in a grave: Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
The hoard comprised an unknown number of silver Roman coins, of which 23 were catalogued: 1 denarius, 22 antoniniani (radiates); silver weight: 29.5-57.9g.

The hoard was found in a small square cairn created with Roman tiles stuck together with red Roman cement and was surrounded by numerous stone sarcophagi. It comprised 87 sestertii from Vespasian to Gordian III and an oculist's stamp inscribed with the name C. TITTIVS BALBINVS.
1499 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Aurelian - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 295-296) in an amphora beneath the floor during excavations of a house.
5,989 Roman denarii (Augustus - Septimius Severus, AD 209) and one drachm of Caesarea in Cappadocia (Antoninus Pius) were uncovered, hidden under the floor of a house.
357 antoniniani (radiates): Philip I - Claudius II (AD 268-270); silver weight: 97.4-445.3 g.
disposition: Collezioni Governative del Medagliere Milanese, Italy (in 1923).

summary: The hoard comprised 15 coins (2 denarii and 13 Provincial issues: Thessalonica, Amphipolis, Stobi, Cassandrea, Koinon of Macedonia), found in sarcophagus 1 in Ierissos.
A hoard of six provincial coins minted in Alexandria (Claudius II - Aurelian), found in or near Ipswich in 1922.
The hoard was found in a funerary urn and apparently comprised 50 'small bronzes' or radiates of Gallienus.

A third century hoard of 99 antoniniani (radiates) interpreted as a savings hoard. Found during development control excavation in advance of building new housing estate: Gordian - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 258-259).

There is debate about whether 2-3000 coins were found (Lebarbier-Arnoux) or 5-6000 coins (Bottin). The librarian in Valenciennes, Hécart, saw about 500. An English officer, Drummond Hay, took a large portion of the hoard. Found with a ceramic vessel Severus Alexander - Postumus (AD 260-269).

In 1906, a find of 107 small bronzes (radiates) was reported in Treffieux. These are very likely to be part of the same find as those reported by Fabre as being found in a garden in the early 20th century AD. This hoard comprised two lots of 909 and 44 radiates respectively which were studied in 1953 and 1958. Silver: 908, 1 coins; Silver weight: 246.1-1134.0g.
The hoard comprised 43 sestertii from Commodus to Gordian III (AD 241-243).
(247) 162 silver coins: 65 denarii, 97 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Postumus (AD 266-267).
disposition: Musée Curtius, Liège, Belgium (161 coins, 1 fragment of container)

summary: 1,726 coins found in a bronze vessel: 3 denarii, 1,723 antoniniani (radiates): Philip I - Diocletian/Maximian I (AD 293-294); weight: 5,650 kilos.
disposition: Musée d'Archéologie de Jura, Lons-le-Saunier, France

summary: Two coins: 1 Alexandrian bronze of Vespasian, 1 provincial bronze of Elagabalus found together with 6 lead tokens (produced in Memphis) during excavations.
disposition: Museum of Anthropology of the University of California, Berkeley, USA (1935)

summary: The hoard was discovered during antiquarian exploration of a Gallo-Roman site. It appeared to have been originally stored in a cabinet measuring 6 feet square and comprised more than 300 base-silver coins. According to the finder, villagers who knew the findspot continued to find coins in abundance there. 300 silver coins: Severus Alexander - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (AD 253-268); silver weight: 76.1-710.8+g.
It comprised 258 antoniniani (radiates) from Elagabalus to Aurelian (AD 270-275).
539 antoniniani (radiates), ranging from the sole reign of Gallienus to Aurelianus, incl. Vabalathus. Hoard hidden in the debris of an earthquake dating from AD 241, covering the stadium building.
25 silver coins, 5 recovered: Septimius Severus Gordian III (AD 238-244); silver weight: 7.1-9.3 g.
Rescue excavation undertaken by the archaeological service. 20 antoniniani and 3 denarii, ranging from Caracalla to Gallienus (sole reign) were found.
The hoard comprised approximately 500 antoniniani (radiates) of Gordian III, Philip I and Postumus and three bronze coins: 1 Lucilla, 1 Maximinus I Thrax, 1 Postumus (sestertii?) (AD 260-269).
At 3 m from the findspot of MORCHAIN 1, 7 coins: 1 double sestertius, 2 sestertii, 3 asses, 1 antoninianus (radiate): Titus, Hadrian, Faustina I, Marcus Aurelius, Faustina II, Postumus (AD 264-265).
Few hundreds of provincial bronze coins. 92 entered the museum collection in Sofia: Septimius Severus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
disposition: National History Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. nos. 26923-27020 (92 coins)

summary: 16 holed antoniniani (radiates) ranging from Valerian I and Gallienus to Quintillus (AD 270).
2,191 silver coins found with an urn: 2147 denarii, 44 antoniniani (radiates): Mark Antony ´- Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238); silver weight: 3112.7-7821.9g.
disposition: Salzburg Museum Carolino Augusteum (41 coins); Münzkabinett, Kunsthistorisches Museum, Wien, Austria (10 coins)

summary: The hoard comprised 216 coins (without doubt mostly denarii and antoniniani (radiates) and a range of silver vessels, gold and silver jewellery and a copper-alloy figurine. The earliest coin was an aureus of Galba and the latest were issues of Gallienus. The hoard was found close to a mill at a depth of 15 inches. Most of the hoard was acquired by the Musée de Genève. The aureus of Galba was stolen before 1903.
The hoard comprised a deposit of between 300 and 400 denarii and antoniniani (radiates) from Trajan to Julia Mamaea and Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
337 antoniniani, "almost all of them bearing the portraits of Claudius II and Tetricus I" (AD 271-274).

The hoard was found in a ceramic urn which had been placed in a rectangular cavity under a large flat stone. Within the urn, were 100 small gold Roman coins and 200 in silver and bronze, as well as some bones. The hoard was found by a farmer when he lifted a large flat stone in a field which was bothering him. The farmer sold the coins to a collector with the exception of one coin each in gold, silver and bronze.
HER has a record of "a hoard of 22 antoniniani of the period AD259-273" in Swindon Museum.
The hoard comprised c. 3/4000 antoniniani (radiates) ending with coins of Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
5 denarii found with a bronze item in a well: Trajan/Hadrian - Caracalla/Elagabalus. (201-222).
Breakdown of mints is given suggesting that full breakdown is given in articles. Silver: 1406 coins; Silver weight: 40.1g
11 burned antoniniani: Valerian I - Aurelian (AD 270-275). Two lots of 8 (24.09g) and 3 (8.83g) coins.
(700) 659 provincial bronze coins: Marcus Aurelius - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: History Museum, Targovishte, Bulgaria; inv. no. 200

summary: Hoard of 99 electrum and silver stateri of the Bosporan Kings, Cotys III and Sauromates III (AD 232-233).
6 uncertain imperial coins (Vespasian-Aurelian).
138 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Valerian (AD 253-260).

The hoard was found during the excavation of the courtyard of House L in Insula 27 at Colonia Ulpia Traiana. It comprised 5 denarii of Maximinus dating to AD 235-236. The excavation archives provide no further details about the circumstances of discovery.
18 silver coins entered the museum collection in Nova Zagora: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of History, Nova Zagora, Bulgaria; inv. no. 1159

summary: The hoard comprised more than 36,000 coins, probably all antoniniani (radiates) from Valerian I and Gallienus to Aurelian (AD 270-275).
1279 antoniniani (radiates) found with a cooking pot: Gordian III - Gallienus (AD 260-268).
200 gold staters of the Bosporan kings found on the banks of the Mortvyy Donets River: Eupator, Sauromates II, Rhescuporis III.
56 coins found in a ceramic vessel: 21 silver coins, 35 provincial bronzes: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2070

summary: Hoard of 80 bronze staters of the Bosporan king, Rhescuporis V (AD 242-277).

A hoard of 50-60 antoniniani, ranging from Gallienus to Maximian I, uncovered in 1961 at the construction of a garage. Further particulars about the find circumstances are unknown. Only 40 coins have been described.

The hoard was found in a coarseware vessel covered with a tile. It comprised 12 very worn 'large bronzes' of the High Empire (Trajan, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius, Severus Alexander etc) and approximately 400 denarii and radiates including issues of Severus Alexander (one or two), Maximinus, Gordian III (numerous), Philip, Trajan Decius, Herennia Etruscilla, Volusian, Valerian II and Salonina. The majority of the coins were very corroded. The coins were accompanied by seven gold intaglio finger rings and two gold necklaces, one set with emeralds and the other lozengiform blue stones.
Large hoard of silver coins. Only 5 pieces are known: Aurelian 2, Tacitus 1, Probus 2; silver weight: 1.0-1.4g.
This hoard is recorded at the level of the coin: Gordian III - Victorinus (AD 269-271); silver weight: 243.1-1909.4g.
Hoard of 198 coins of the Bosporan kings, Rhescuporis V, Pharsanzes, Sauromates IV, Teiranes (AD 266-278).

Unknown initial number of silver coins. 6 coins are known in the collection of the Salzburger Museum Carolino Augusteum: Septimius Severus 2, Julia Domna 1, Caracalla 1, Maximinus I Thrax 1, Gordian III 1.
3 coins: Marcus Aurelius: denarius, dupondius; Trajan Decius sestertius (AD 249-251).
29 bronze coins: 27 setertii, 1 dupondius, 1 dupondius/as: Trajan - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
The hoard was found in pot with 1,600 low-grade silver coins of Postumus. Silver: c.1600 (500) coins; Silver weight: c.432
2,329 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Aurelian - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 289-290) found in a jar, buried beneath the doorway between a room and the courtyard, during excavations of a house.

The assemblage comprised a) a copper-alloy box containing 2 aurei, items of jewellery and a fragment of silk; b) a further earthenware vessel containing a large quantity (10 kilos in total) of small module coins (radiates). 250 of these coins were examined by F. Rever, with the most recent being an issue of Quietus; c) 50 'large bronze' coins were scattered on the surface; d) some iron tools including pruning equipment. It is not clear whether all the constituent parts of the find should be considered to represent a single hoard deposit or at least two separate hoards. Found in a field belonging to M. Denesle (or Denêle) in the course of digging.
Unknown initial number of silver coins. 174 were studied: Mark Antony - Caracalla (AD 211-217)
disposition: Regional History Museum Vidin, Bulgaria; inv. no. 587 (72 coins)

summary: Ten antoniniani of which one of Tacitus.
21 coins found hidden behind in a wall whole in a Roman villa: 1 antoninianus (radiate), 18 sestertii, 2 asses: Domitian - Philip I (AD 244-249).

A hoard of 71 Pamphylian bronze coins, mostly from Perge (64) and a few other cities, as well as one coin from Selge in Pisidia that ranges in date from Caracalla to Aurelian. These coins were purchased by John Mossop, which the ticket 'Perge hoard, Dec. 66'. It is unclear whether 'Perge' refers to the find spot, or to the fact that most coins came from that city.
The hoard comprised a broken ceramic vessel containing 122 silver denarii and antoniniani (radiates) from Septimius Severus to Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-260).
1,456 antoniniani (radiates): Gordian III - Aurelian/Tetricus I (AD 271-274); silver weight: 394.1-1819.1g.
(488) 168 silver coins: Commodus - Quintillius (AD 270)
disposition: National Archaeological Institute with Museum, Sofia, Bulgaria; inv. no. LXVII (75 coins)

summary: A hoard of more than 212 coins (Valerian I - Postumus) came into view in 1969 on Saarstrasse 135 during building work; it was dispersed. The RLMT bought 91 coins, 121 further coins were seen in private collections.
4 antoniniani: 3 Gallienus (sole), 1 Claudius II (AD 268-270).
The four coins appeared together in the west corner, belonging to a room structure erected with walls of opus vittatum.
On the site of the Roman theatre, a hoard of 24 sestertii wrapped in cloth was found .

The hoard comprised 'several hundred small bronze coins'. Canel distinguishes this hoard from those found in Préaux (TAF IV. 57). The hoard was near the top of the hill, close to the plough, approximately 1km from the ancient abbey of Saint-Léger.
Seven antoniniani (radiates) found in House 1: Gallienus 6, Salonina 1. The coins were stacked to each other.
(c. 18 kg, 4,062) 1,590 silver coins denarii, antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253); silver weight: 5078.8-10559.8 g.

A hoard of 11 provincial coins (Thessalonica, Pella, Dium, the koinon of Macedonia) ranging from Marcus Aurelius to Gordian III, found in a grave, part of a vast necropolis in the eastern part of Veroia.

The hoard comprised a ceramic vessel containing approximately 5,000 bronze coins. They were bought by M. Molchnet who stated that they included coins of Postumus, Victorinus, and a very large number of coins of Tetricus I. The hoard was found by a farmer, leveling of the ground surface in a barn.

108 kg found in a large ceramic jar and, probably, a box or, rather, of a canvas bag or leather, according to the rectangular shape of the second heap of coins: 41,200 antoniniani (radiates) and 1 denarius. Among issuers Valerian I, Gallienus, Quintillus, Aurelian, Claudius II, Postumus, Laelianus, Marius, Victorinus, Tetricus I, Tetricus II. Notably Gallienus and Claudius II (27%), the Gallo-Roman emperors Victorinus, Tetricus I and Tetricus II in particular (56%), and local imitations. A rare denarius of Tetricus I.
13 antoniniani: Gallienus - Tacitus (AD 276).
The hoard comprised 24 antoniniani: Gallienus (sole)-Claudius II (Divus) (AD 270 AD).
disposition: Museo Civico Bottacin di Padova, Italy (inv.nos. 24174-24196)

summary: 73 provincial bronze coins: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Archaeological Museum, Veliko Tarnovo, Bulgaria; inv. nos.1538-1610 (73 coins, 69 have been stolen)

summary: The hoard comprised approximately 300 'small bronze' Roman coins, probably radiates. Only one coin was described, a radiate of Probus with a MARS VICTOR reverse.

A hoard of ca. 2000 bronze coins was discovered in 1902 in Eleusis, a few metres east of the peribolos wall of the sanctuary, in the garden of a coffeehouse belonging to Georgios B. Adam. The hoard was divided into two lots, which were said to have been approximately equal in size. One of these was dispersed. The other, consisting of 972 specimens, was examined and catalogued by Svoronos 1904. It included 958 provincial coins from Athens (time of the Antonines and Gallienus), 1 provincial coin from Thessalonica, 1 from Argos and 12 sestertii (Hadrian à Gordian III).
The hoard comprised 18 antoniniani (radiates) from trebonianus Gallus for Volusian to Postumus with the most recent issue a SAECVLI FELICITAS reverse type (Elmer 593).

543 denarii (of which 5 plated) found with a pitcher: Nero - Macrinus (AD 218); 1768 g. The mints of Alexandria, Antioch and Emesa are represented by one copy each, while the one from Laodicea by a total of 12 coins.

IARCH record for a fused lump of denarii, of which three could be identified as issues of Severus Alexander, The others (3 and a fragment) could not be identified due to the condition of the coins. Possibly burnt as they are deformed into a fused mass (total wt. = 14.01g).For further details and images see YORYM-6C737B
The hoard comprised approximately 200 silver coins, only for 97 of them were known the issuers: Antoninus Pius to Maximinus Thrax (AD 235-238).
Hoard of 17 silver coins, comprising 7 denarii (Elagabal to Maximinus) and 10 radiates (Gordian III to Trebonianus Gallus)

The hoard comprised a black ceramic vessel containing a hoard of coins and jewellery. The jewellery included a gold necklace, 3 gold intaglio finger rings, a gold and silver intaglio finger ring and an iron finger ring with silver decoration. The number of coins in the hoard is not known with any certainty. Pérot claims there were 100 sestertii and 150 denarii, whereas Clément catalogued 92 coins, including 67 bronzes (mostly sestertii) and 25 denarii (and radiates?). There were some identification errors with 1 sestertius and 2 denarii attributed to Antoninus Pius, when in fact they were issues of Caracalla.
Originally, 87 silver coins. 66 pieces were recovered: 18 antoniniani (radiates), 48 denarii: Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-247).
disposition: Collection Nussbaum, Timișoara, Romania; otherwise, dispersed

summary: 34 sestertii: Trajan - Philip I (AD 244-249).
55 silver coins, ranging from Antoninus Pius to Gordian III, found during construction work.
Five denarii: Trajan, Antoninus Pius, Marcus Aurelius (Lucilla), Septimius Severus, Elagabalus (AD 218-222).
79 antoniniani (radiates): Philip I - Victorinus (AD 269-271).
Unknown number of silver coins. 42 pieces are kept in the Regional History Museum in Ruse: Caracalla - Gordian III (AD 243-244).
disposition: Ruse Regional Museum of History, Bulgaria; inv.no. 1600 1-43

summary: 51 bronze coins: 18 sestertii, 2 dupondii?, 31 provincial coins: Marcus Aurelius - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238). Together, were found bronze finger-rings, and fragments of bracelets.
444 silver coins found with a bronze vessel: Domitian - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253). Together were found two silver spoons
The hoard was found in a wall. It comprised c. 400 bronze coins from Nero to Gordian III (AD 238-244). This hoard was divided in two lots.
disposition: H. Ponroy Collection; Berry Museum, St. Moritz, Switzerland

summary: IARCH record of a hoard of 11 sestertii from Devon. For details see DEV-37EC41.
The hoard comprised a ceramic container, the characteristics of which are unknown which contained 667 sestertii, one dupondius from Vespasian to Gordian III and one Provincial bronze of Hadrian.
disposition: Museo Arqueologico Provincial de Alicante, Spain

summary: The hoard comprised a wine amphora containing 953 coins, including 937 sestertii, 6 dupondii and 10 asses from Vespasian to Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238).
The hoard comprised 91 denarii and 416 sestertii from Nero to Gordian III (AD 241-244).
disposition: Musée archéologique départemental de Guiry-en-Vexin, France

summary: A Roman hoard was found and dispersed, in recent years in Nembro. Some bronze coins of the 3rd century were seen. It is an Antoninianus (radiate) from Salamina (sic!) and dupondii of Claudius II and Aurelian (determination of E. Arslan). Soprintendenza Archeologica della Lombardia (7 coins).

Coin hoard discovered during the construction of the airfield in Erding, south-east of Langengeisling. Close to the find spot ground walls of a villa rusticate were excavated in 1912. The hoard originally comprised ca. 300 denarii, of which only 96 could be traced (Hadrian - Maximinus I).

1138 silver coins: 25 Greek drachmas, 1033 republican denarii, 54 imperial denarii and antoniniani (radiates), 2 provincial bronzes, 3 nummi, 21 unknown denomination: 150 BC - Valerian I/Gallienus (AD 253-268). Three coins of the House of Constantine I/Constans (AD 333-350) are most likely intruders; silver weight: 1552.6-3959.8 g.

A hoard of 103 Roman imperial denarii: Otho – Caracalla (AD 211-217) was discovered by two treasure hunters in the mid-October 2009 in the Kyiv region. The first report about the hoard was published on the Ukrainian treasure hunter forum Violity on October 26, 2009, and on October 29, November 2 and 23 photos of the coins were published. According to one of the finders, initially, not far from the unexcavated earlier pits from other treasure hunters, 71 coins were found on an area of 5x5 meters with a depth of 15-20 cm. At a later time, on the findspot was made sondage and the next 19 coins were found, and later – a further 13. The coins were cleaned by finders. The preservation of the coins is mostly good to very good. The further fate of the coins is unknown.
1,892 bronze coins found in a ceramic vessel: Vespasian - Postumus (AD 260-261).
214 radiates after AD 280. Found in a pit post-dating the rampart in a concreted mass. One official coin and 212 barbarous radiates of small module, one illegible coin.

A hoard of 64 provincial AE coins of Ionia, Lydia, Caria, Thrace, Macedonia and Cilicia, dating from Antoninus Pius to Salonina. See also Klose, Smyrna, p. 123 (2 specimens, and not 1 as mentioned in Noe).
(8-10 kg) 36 antoniniani (radiates) of Claudius II, Aurelian, Tacitus, Florian, Probus, Carinus, Magna Urbica, Numerian, Diocletian, Numerian (AD 293-294)

One of three coin hoards found in a villa on Eighteen Acre Field, all buried just before the end of the 3rd c. AD (see Robertson nos. 649 and 888). 67 coins, ranging from Valerian I to Allectus, placed in a cist dug in the earth together with animal bones, pieces of coarse pottery, and a blue bead, nearly the size of a walnut.
102 coins: 5 antoniniani, 23 sestertii, 74 bronze (sestertii?): Domitian - Gallienus/Postumus (AD 260-268); silver weight: 4.0-12.1 g.
disposition: Musées royaux des Beaux-Arts de Belgique, Bruxelles, Belgium (102 coins)

summary: 25 coins: 1 denarius, 12 antoniniani (radiates), 2 quadrantes, 10 unknown denomination: Claudius II - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
The hoard comprised 287 denarii: 93 republican, 194 imperial: Republic - Caracalla (AD 215).
disposition: Cabinet des médailles, Paris, France; collection Favre

summary: 8 coins found in a cave: Antoninus Pius - Quintillus (Divus Claudius II); silver weight: 4.1-13.9g.
Unknown number of silver coins. 29 coins entered the museum collection in Targovishte: Vespasian - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235).

Single finds of 21 Roman coins, Tiberius to Gallienus, found during metal detectorists' surveys on the site of a Roman villa rustica. Some of these might be part of a scattered hoard. Among coins found 1998-2011: 11 antoniniani and 10 denarii, Antoninus Pius to Gallienus (joint reign) and Postumus. 9 of these have been published with full references.
130 silver coins: 109 denarii, 21 antoniniani: Commodus - Philip I (AD 244-246); silver weight: 187.6-294.9 g
The hoard was found in a small wooden box and comprised between 5 and 600 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-260).
992 coins: 14 denarii, 900 antoniniani, 1 sestertius: Septimius Severus - Valerianus I (AD 259); and jewelry of precious metal
3,598 antoniniani (radiates) of which 3,032 are imitations: Valerian I and Gallienus - Probus (AD 276-282).
Around 500 antoniniani (radiates). Only 96 coins were described: Valerian I and Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
140 silver coins: 26 denarii, 114 antoniniani: Septimius Severus to Trajan Decius (AD 249-251); silver weight: 175.6-362.9 g.

The hoard was found in a cave shelter and comprised numerous ancient objects including pottery vessels, hipposandals and a sestertius of Hadrian, a dupondius of Antoninus Pius and a worn coin of another emperor, possibly Macrinus.

On the site of the Romano-British settlement at Camerton, near Bath, a small hoard of barbarous radiates, mostly minimi, was found just outside the wall of a small Roman building. It would appear to have been deposited there after the construction of the wall, which was not earlier than mid-third century. With the exception of the piece of larger module, and some scraps of the more usual imitations, the coins of the hoard are radiate minimi of average diameter of 8 mm.

The hoard comprised 500-600 provincial bronze coins of Byblus, Berytus, and Sidon, found while digging for construction stones, found in a 'cavity' (Höhlung) close to Beirut. Coins range from Macrinus to Severus Alexander, most of which minted in Berytus and Sidon.

The hoard comprised a vessel containing a) 1 or more aurei. Coutil states that there were six. B) approximately 1,600 silver and billon coins, almost all being radiates. C) Three ogold pendants (?) 'coulants' were also recovered. The hoard was sold at auction in May 1880. According to Angérard, the State (the Cabinet des Médailles?) acquired the aureus of Faustina. The Musée d'Évreux has 63 coins from the assemblage and Louviers, 43 (including issues of Valerian, Gallienus, Postumus, Victorinus and Claudius II). Gold: 6? (1) coins; Gold weight: 19.3; Silver: 2, 1343 coins; Silver weight: 365.8-3493.2
(746) 668 denarii and antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253)
23 coins found in three piles found near a wall: 22 antoniniani (radiates).
50 bronze coins, probably, placed in a wooden box with bone hinges: 49 sestertii, 1 as: Trajan - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
Unknown number of antoniani were found in unknown circumstances. 6 pieces are kept in the museum collection in Ruse: Trebonianus Gallus 1, Valerian I 2, Gallienus 2, Claudius ?? 1.
Unknown number of provincial bronze coins. 42 pieces entered the museum collection in Varna: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Archaeology Museum, Varna, Bulgaria; inv.nos. 4328-4372 (45 coins)

summary: Unknown originally number of coins. Only three antoniniani (radiates) are known: Gordian III, Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (Gallienus), Postumus.
357 antoniniani (radiates) and 1 denarius, ranging from Caracalla to Aemilian (AD 253); silver weight: 448.5-804.5 g.
disposition: Archives de la Commission d'assistance publique (358 coins); private collection (3 coins); Musée communal de Bruxelles"

summary: 115 antoniniani: Caracalla to Trajan Decius. Found in two separate but homogeneous groups. Silver: 115 coins; Silver weight: 145.1-297.6g
+8 kg, c. 2000 (515) antoniniani (radiates): Valerian - Claudius II (AD 268-270); silver weight: c. 541.0-2499.0g (after Hobbs).
The hoard comprised 'a block of between 200 and 400 radiates.': Gordian III - Postumus (AD 260-269.
ca. 40 coins in a leather purse, but only 5 coins are identified: Septimius Severus (1), Postumus (4).
32 bronze coins: Augustus - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
Contents of a little purse. Six denarii Septimius Severus - Caracalla.

The hoard consists of 336 coins, most of which are separate, with some bunches of coins stuck together. Additionally, there are eight fragments of pottery, including the complete base of the ceramic vessel with some coins still intact. Most coins are clearly contemporary copies or 'barbarous radiates'.
23 silver coins found in a ceramic vessel: 10 denarii, 11 antoniniani: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2678, 23 coins

summary: The hoard comprised 2,109 antoniniani (radiates) and 'aureliani' dated between AD 247-293.
The hoard, found with a bronze vessel, comprised approximately 1,200 radiates from Claudius II to Diocletian (AD 287-288); silver weight: 133.5-237.1 g.
18 bronze coins found in a grave: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249)
(700) 160 silver coins: Trajan - Valerian I/ Gallienus (AD 253-268). Found in a ceramic vessel together with a silver ring.
46 imitations of antoniniani (radiates) of the Tetricus I and II (AD 271-274)and unidentified onject (button?).
1,204 coins: 4 antoniniani (radiates), 1,199 sestertii, 1 as: Vespasian - Postumus (AD 268).
disposition: Cabinet des Médailles de la Bibliothèque nationale de France, Paris

summary: A hoard of 4 denarii (including a plated one) and 27 bronze coins (5 Hellenistic, 1 Rhoemetalces and 21 provincial coins), found in grave T4 in Lithochori. Only the latest of the provincial coins are identified.
The hoard comprised 4 radiates of Aurelian. It is suggested that the coins were the contents of a purse or part of a larger, scattered hoard.

27 silver denarii, from Vespasian to Severus Alexander (75-235 AD), have been found scattered over a cultivated field by volunteer archaeologists. Coins are now kept in the Archaeological Museum of Povegliano Veronese.

A dispersed hoard of approx. 70 mid-280s coins found, together with another hoard of 100-150 3rd to 4th C. coins. Dawson, M. 1995. Sandy. In A. Brown (ed.) Roman Towns in Eastern England & Beyond. Oxbow, pp. 167-177.
1170 silver coins: M. Aurelius - Philip I; Silver weight: 1463.8-3029.0 g.

A hoard of Roman bronze coins, next to a few gold ones, found during the construction of the railrepair workshop in Neustadt. It was acquired by the museum in three successive lots (A-C: 26 coins, 5 coins, 1 coin).

The hoard comprised a metal vessel containing 43 Roman coins, including 4 bronzes and 39 denarii and radiates from Trajan to Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole)(Gallienus) (AD 253-268). The hoard, missing 10 coins, is in the collections of the Musée de Rouen. The silver mirror and vessel are lost. In the Hoard file in the Archives of the Musée des Antiquités is a handwritten note without a date (April 1912) listing 38 coins.
14 silver coins: 3 denarii, 11 antoniniani (radiates): Severus Alexander - Valerian I (AD 257-258); Silver weight: 17.9-30.6 g.

337 silver coins: 272 denarii, 65 antoniniani: Antoninus Pius - Valerian I (AD 255). The hoard found in an urn contains also jewelry. It was found in an area where other archaeological evidence suggests Roman occupation.

The wooden box contained pieces of silverware and various Roman artefacts. The finder sold the jewellery to the Imperial Library, today the National Library. The coins were dispersed; 1,450 denarii and antoniniani (radiates). The hoard consists of: 8 gold necklaces, pearls or semi-precious stones; 5 gold rings; 6 silver rings; 1 ivory styllus; 1 silver ingot; 1 gold roll of wire; hollow gold fingers (plectrum); a stone statuette of Aesculapius; several rings with intaglio; 2 silver hearts and 1 necklace pendant with a gold coin.
About 20 antoniniani (radiates) found during prospections. Only 10 of them were studied: Valerian I and Gallienus or Gallienus (sole reign) - Aurelian (AD 270-275).

822 billon provincial coins of Alexandria: Marcus Aurelius - Diocletian/Maximian I (AD 294-295). Finding spots according to the Arad dealers from whom Milne bought the hoards in Cairo. The two hoards had almost the same composition, got mixed together on the way back to England, therefore have been listed as a single find.
775 denarii: Nero – Severus Alexander (AD 228).
146 coins: 1 denarius, 91 antoniniani (radiates), 49 antoniniani (radiates) imitations, 3 sestertii, 2 dupondii/asses: Marcus Aurelius - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
5 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-269)
601 silver coins found in a ceramic vessel: Septimius Severus - Gallienus (sole) (AD 260-268).
21 denarii and 28 antoniniani (radiates): Septimius Severus - Trebonianus Gallus (AD 251-253).
58 tetradrachms of Alexandria, 1 bronze coin: Vespasian - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 294-295). Found in a heap beneath the floor of a passageway during excavations of a house.
disposition: 57 in Ann Arbor, the rest in Cairo

summary: 1200-1300 bronze coins, found in a vessel south of the Roman fort, together with a silver ring. The coins were dispersed. 25 of them were described, and 11 further coins are still preserved in the museum Landshut (therefore, 36 are listed in FMRD, ranging from Vespasian to Severus Alexander).
52 coins: 1 denarius, 31 antoniniani (radiates), 5 antoniniani (radiates) imitations, 12 sestertii, 1 dupondius, 2 unknown denomination: Vespasian - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
The hoard comprised 786 or 802 sestertii from Hadrian to Hostilian (or Gallienus, see bibliography).
7 coins found in a money-box: 1 denarius, 1 plated denarius, 3 sestertii, 1 dupondius, 1 as: Nerva - Philip I (Marcia Otacilia Severa) (AD 246-247).
disposition: County Museum of History and Art, Zalău, Romania (inv.nos. M 29)

summary: On the site of a Roman temple or shrine (?) in a field: 30 coins, significantly limited to the inner recessed area. The number joined by corrosion suggests the possibility of a disturbed hoard. They are mainly debased antoniniani covering the same period as the hoard found during the last century. Undated. Late 3rd century AD
The hoard comprised 50 sestertii from Hadrian to Trajan Decius. It was found on the Arcellier property, but dispersed almost immediately.
200 silver coins found with a ceramic vessel. 100 pieces were recovered: 92 denarii, 8 antoniniani (radiates): Vespasian – Philip I (AD 244-247).
disposition: History Museum, Caracal (17 coins); Museum of Oltenia, Craiova (83 coins), Romania

summary: 8 silver coins: 2 denarii, 6 antoniniani: Maximinus I Thrax - Trajan Decius (Etruscilla) (AD 249-251).

The hoard comprised 'numerous Roman coins, which the finder distributed amongst his friends.' The finder's daughter possessed 24 which included coins of Valerian I, Victorinus, and Tetricus I. The hoard was found during ground levelling works
Unknown number of silver coins. 23 silver coins were seen: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249); silver weight: 18.2-34.5 g.
disposition: Museum of History, Karnobat (12 coins); Regional History Museum, Burgas, Bulgaria (inv.no. XVI)

summary: of 4,033 pieces, 3296 were recorded at the British Museum: 592 denarii, Domitian-Gordian III; 2704 antoniniani, Caracalla-Trajan Decius, including 2 “Divi”. The other were all antoniniani of Gordian III, Philip I, Philip II and Trajan Decius.
42 aurei: Vespasian - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 258); Gold weight: 237.9 g.

The hoard comprised an amphora containing 1,400 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Victorinus (AD 269-271). A catalogue exists for 1,335 antoniniani (radiates). Hobbs estimates a silver weight of between 421g and 1,749g.

The hoard comprised a greyware vessel containing approximately 1,200 antoniniani (radiates) from Gordian III to Aurelian. Two catalogues exist for 181 and 178 of the coins respectively. They do not match. Hobbs estimates a silver weight of between 325g and 1499g.
This hoard comprised 3,727 imitations of antoniniani (radiates) of c. AD 265-275.

Hoard of 225 coins: 1 imperial denarius, 8 gold stateri, 216 bronze staters of Bosporan kings: Rhescuporis III, Cotys III, Sauromates III, Rhescuporis IV, Ininthimeus Rhescuporis V, dated between AD 80 and AD 251.
395 silver coins: 280 antoniniani, 115 denarii: Trajan - Valerian I and Gallienus (AD 253-260).
301 antoniniani (radiates): Postumus - Probus (AD 276-282).

The hoard was found in a coarseware vessel and comprised 114 antoniniani (radiates). TAF comments that the presence of the coin of Magnia Urbica is very unusual. It questions whether this coin was added to the hoard after its discovery or whether the hoard was only part of a larger assemblage. The hoard was found in a hole surround by a large amount of masonry (possibly ancient) during the demolition of a fifteenth century building: . Silver: 113 coins; Silver weight: 31.5-140.3g.

Approximately 500 sestertii from Flavian issues to Valerian I found during the construction and landscaping of the military stadium in Cherchell. The hoard was dispersed immediately after discovery, with many being sold to Italian collectors, but some of the coins were acquired by the Collection Bouchereau in Algiers.

The hoard comprised two separate parcels of coins concealed within a cist constructed with five bricks and covered with a silver embossed leaf.
