The first parcel comprised nearly 700 sestertii dating from Galba to Severus Alexander. The second parcel, wrapped in fragments of linen, comprised denarii and radiates from Trajan to Volusian.

The coins (15 denarii, ranging from Marcus Aurelius to Maximinus, with the probable addition of a further denarius of Septimius Severus) were found together at the southwest foothills of the Lehenbühl, SE of Fridingen.
18 provincial bronze coins entered the museum collection in Shumen: Septimius Severus - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 13869/1-18 (17 coins)

summary: 40 billon tetradrachms of Alexandria: Hadrian - VAlerian I and Gallienus (AD 257-258) found at floor level of a room during excavations of a house.
disposition: 34 coins in Ann Arbor, the rest in various Egyptian museums

summary: 21 coins discovered within the ruins of a Roman settlement. 11 pieces in the museum of Targovishte: Gordian - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
15 antoniniani found together: Gallienus - Quintillus (Divus Claudius II) (AD 270).
The hoard was comprised a black pot containing 356 denarii and antoniniani (radiates)
25 provincial bronze coins found in a ceramic vessel: Caracalla - Philip I (AD 244-249).

Hoard found during railway construction work, probably from the area of the site of a Roman villa rustica. It comprisesd at least 2114 coins, but no more than 2300. Coins run from Valerian to Aurelian, mainly Gallienus and Claudius II. Reported coins of Tacitus, Probus and Diocletianus (dated 289) seem to be intruders from the Reichenstein hoard (Schaub-Gysin 1930, p. 70).

The finders show to Abbe Moreau c. 6,700 antoniniani (radiates). The workers discovered the hoard in three vessels and shared the coins. V. Huguenot studied few coins of this hoard, from Antoninus Pius (probably Elagabalus) to Postumus (AD 260-269).

The hoard comprised a white ceramic vessel containing 84 or 85 worn sestertii of Augustus to Trajan Decius. In 1901, a further 5 dupondii and asses of Vespasian, Trajan, Hadrian and Faustina I were found, as well as a worn sestertius and a potin Iron Age coin depicting a horse surmounted by lyre. It is likely that these coins formed part of the earlier hoard.

Several reports mention several silver coins (probably a hoard) ranging from Vespasian to Elagabalus, found on the Flürener Heide, on a sand hill, close to Diersfordt, Flüren. The coins have been dispersed.
155 bronze coins, official and provincial issues of Viminacium and Provincia Dacia: Antoninus Pius - Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).
505 antoniniani (radiates), of which 358 are catalogued: Gallienus (sole) - Diocletian (AD 290).
disposition: Castello del Buonconsiglio di Trento, Italy (358 coins); Museo di Riva, Italy (126 coins, stolen)

summary: 517 bronze and electrum Bosporan coins: Rhescuporis II - Ininthimeus (AD 238).

Several thousand Roman coins reported to have been found in 1852. 32 coins, findspot mentioned "Malvaglia" and "Val di Blenio", entered the collection of the Antiquarische Gesellschaft Zürich (AGZ) and have now integrated the collections of the Schweizerisches Nationalmuseum, Zürich. They are probably part of this hoard (32 antoniniani, Aurelian to Diocletian).
disposition: Schweizerisches Landesmuseum Zürich (32 coins); the other ones are lost.

summary: A mixed hoard of denarii, some sestertii and a few antoniniani, ranging from Hadrian to Trajan Decius. It was found in soil dug out during building work in Niederlahnstein (Weiherstraße). The hoard, which was partly dispersed, might have comprised 200 coins or more, but a description of only 142 exists.
Unknown number of imperial and provincial bronze coins. 36 pieces entered the museum collection in Shumen: Antoninus Pius - Philip I (AD 244-249).
disposition: Regional History Museum, Shumen, Bulgaria; inv. no. 13328/1-35 (35 coins)

summary: Hoard of 14 kilos of antoniniani (radiates) found during the construction of the overpass on the Corso Ivrea. 601 coins were transferred from the Regional Museum of Torino to the Soprintendenza della Valle d'Aosta: Trebonianus Gallus - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (AD 253-268).
445 silver coins probably buried directly in the soil: Caracalla - Trebonianus Gallu (AD 251-253).
A hoard of 201 antoniniani ranging from Elagabalus to the early years of Gallienus, found in the excavations of a bath building.
disposition: The coins are in the archeological Museum in Eretria

summary: The hoard comprised two ceramic vessels containing between 6,000 and 7,000 copper- alloy coins from Macrinus, Severus Alexander, Maximian, Gordian III and Philip I.

A hoard of approximatively 400 silver coins discovered within a ceramic vessel, comprising a large majority of denarii (Trajan - Severus Alexander) and some Cappadocian drachms (up to Caracalla). The hoard was dispersed. Different accounts exist of its content, with Dundua 1979 publishing the 377 coins in the National Museum in Tbilisi (12 Cappadocian drachms and 365 denarii) and Zograf 1945 listing 417 coins (10 Cappadocian drachms and 407 denarii).
415 coins found in a ceramic vessel: 413 antoniniani (radiates), 1 possible bronze coin, 1 possible denarius: Trebonianus Gallus/Volusian - Diocletian/Maximian I (AD 284-293).
Unknown quantity of coins. 3,693 antoniniani entered the museum collection in Plovdiv. No further information.
disposition: Museum of Archaeology, Plovdiv, Bulgaria; inv. no. 2644; 3,693 coins

summary: Around 1,000 antoniniani found with a ceramic jug: Gallienus - Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
131 silver coins: 19 antoniniani, 112 denarii found with an urn: Antoninus - Gordian III (AD 242-244). Some scholars also mention gold coins.
disposition: Münzkabinett Kunsthistorisches Museum, Wien (6 coins); Landemuseum Joanneum, Graz (72 coins); Institut für Alte Geschichte, Universität Graz

summary: Hoard of circa 100 antoniniani (radiates), of which only 39 pieces were seen: Gallienus (sole) - Aurelian (AD 270-275).

Circa two kilos of coins and jewelry (2 bronze bracelets). For years it has been considered that Janapole and Dargeliszkie were two separate hoards. 14 bronze coins are hosted in the Museum "Alka" in Telšiai: Severus Alexander - Gordian III (AD 238-244).
The hoard was found in the northeast part of the Roman fort during an excavation campaign in 1983. It comprised 4 aurei and 70 denarii, ranging from Nero to Septimius Severus.
3,428 antoniniani (radiates) found with a copper alloy pitcher: Trebonianus Gallus - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver weight: 922.5-4265.3 g.
disposition: Museo Civico «Ala Ponzone» di Cremona, Italy

summary: 28 antoniniani: Aurelian - Probus (AD 276-282).
Circa 2,000 coins, only 3 known: 2 of Severus Alexander, 1 of Philip I

Found during construction work, supervised by archaeologists. Among other coins ca. 30 poorly preserved radiates, probably a purse (?), mainly imitations of the Gallic Empire (Tetricus I), plus one Divo Claudio II (altar, cf. RIC V.1, p. 233, no 261 (bust K).
Four coins (two denarii and two antoniniani, Septimius Severus - Gallienus), apparently found together around 1845 on a field between Stegelitz and Fehlitz.
(16-20 kg) (8-900) 501 bronze coins: 459 sestertii, 2 dupondii: Vespasian - Maximinus I Thrax (AD 235-238).
disposition: Town museum, Kortrijk, Belgium (240 coins); Collection Heritiers Adriaen (212 coins); Collection Ms. Depoorter (5 coins)

summary: 10 provincial bronze coins. 1 of Septimius Severus, 1 of Caracalla, minted in Nicopolis ad Istrum and Marcianopolis.
Circa 3,000 antoniniani (radiates).
Unknown number of coins. 5 antoniniani are in the museum collection in Székesfehérvár: Gordian III, Philip I, Trajan Decius (AD 249-251).

A hoard of 127 bronze Bosporan coins of 1st–3rd centuries AD was accidentally found at the Mithradates Mount in Panticapaeum in 2009. It comprises Bosporan staters of the following Bosporan Kings: Sauromates I – 4; Cotys II – 3; Rhoemetalkes – 3; Rhescuporis III – 48; Cotys III – 3; Sauromates III – 8; Rhescuporis IV – 2; Ininthimeus – 31.
Over 2,000 aurei found with a ceramic vessel: Tiberius - Severus Alexander (AD 222-235); gold weight: c. 12801.4-15598.6g.
A hoard of ca. 800 silver and 20 bronze coins, found in a pot while ploughing a field (at Hermendonk?, not far from Wachtendonk). The coins are not preserved, but a list of emperors exists.
8 provincial bronze coins issued under Gordian III by Edessa (6 coins) and either Edessa or Carrhae (2 coins).
(c. 1200) 122 denarii: Nero - Maximinus I Tharax (AD 235-236); silver weight: c. 1,681.7-3,754.3 g.
ca. 50 antoniniani (radiates), but only 28 coins are identified: Valerian I - Quintillus (AD 270).
Unknown originally number of coins found with a ceramic vessel. 151 antoniniani (radiates): Valerian I - Aurelian (AD 270-275); silver weight: 41.7-187.8 g.
disposition: National History Museum, Bucharest, Romania (inv.no. 327, 2 coins)

summary: A hoard of 300-400 antoniniani (radiates). 336 coins were examined by Salama at the home of a dealer in Tunis on 6.5.1965: Gordian III - Valerian I and Gallienus/Gallienus (sole) (AD 253-268).
Hoard of around 200 silver coins comprising Parthian drachms of Gotarzes II, Vologases III; Roman denarii of Otho, Vespasian, Trajan, Hadrian, Sassanid drachms of Varakhran II (AD 274-291).

The hoard comprised more than 100 Provincial bronze coins of Ninica-Claudiopolis (1) and Tarsus (100+, with 115 listed by emperor) with issues ranging in date from Caracalla to Gallienus. Coin Hoards II, 153 gives the end date as AD 260.
379 tetradrachms of Alexandria: Nero - Diocletian-Maximian I (AD 295-296) found in a small amphora at floor level in an underground room during excavations of a house.
disposition: 329 coins in Ann Arbor, the rest in various Egyptian museums

summary: The hoard comprised a tinned copper-alloy vessel containing several hundred antoniniani (radiates) of Tetricus I (AD 271-274).
About 2000 antoniniani were discovered in unknown circumstances. No further Information.
Two ceramic vessels with around 500 coins: Elagabalus (Aquilia Severa) to Carinus (AD 283-285). Hobbs estimates the weight of 63.5-843.8g.
50 radiates, mainly of the Gallic Empire and terminating with Carausius, found near Conwy shortly after 1945. No more specific information on the find spot is available.

A hoard of approximately 1,000 coins, of which only 249 were identified by E. Tordeaux. The closing date for the hoard is based on the assumption that the coins seen were representative of the whole Silver: c.1000 (249) coins; silver weight: c.1250.6-2598.9g.
112 coins: imperial and provincial: Trajan - Elagabalus (AD 218-222); silver weight: 217.0-343.5g.

(1213) 1209 silver coins: 10 denarii, 1199 antoniniani: Caracalla - Gallienus (AD 259-268); silver weight: 1752.4-2218.6 g. The hoard was foun within the ruins of a Roman building placed in a bronze vessel
disposition: Muzeul Na'ional al Unirii Alba Iulia, Romania
